
﻿History of Zoroastrianism 
by

 Maneckji Nusservanji Dhalla 
<span class="t17 t29 hoverable">High</span> Priest of the Parsis, Karachi, India

idha apãm vijasâiti
vanghuhi daena mâzdayasnaish
vispâish avi karshvãn yâish hapta.
"Henceforth from now may spread
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Good</span> Mazdayasnian Religion
Over all the zones that are seven."

NEW YORK
OXFORD UNIVERSITY PRESS
LONDON TORONTO,

1938

TO
KHAN BAHADUR
KAVASJI HORMASJI KATRAK, O.B.E.

at hvo vangheush vahyo nâ aibijamyât
ye nâo erezush savangho patho sîshoit
ahyâ angheush astvato mananghaschâ
haithyeng âstîsh yeng â shaetî ahuro
aredro thwâvãns huzentushe spento mazdâ.
"May that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> attain to better than the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span>
Who helps teaching us the upright paths of blessedness
Of this material <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> and that of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span>
-- The veritable universe wherein pervades Ahura -That faithful, wise, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">holy</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> is like <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> thee, O Mazda."

Zarathushtra

BIBLIOGRAPHY
ABBREVIATIONS
INTRODUCTION
PRE-GATHIC PERIOD
From the earliest times to about 1000 B.C.
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span>
I.
THE SOURCES
The data of information -- The Avestan Nasks -The Pahlavi, Pazend and Persian sources -- ParsiSanskrit and Gujarati sources -- Oriental sources
-- Occidental sources -- Inscriptions, coins and
tablets as the last source of information.
II.
AIRYANA VAEJAH
The Stem-land of the Aryans -- The IndoEuropeans -- The Indo-Iranians.
THE GATHIC PERIOD
About 1000 B.C.
III.
ZARATHUSHTRA
Zarathushtra doubts to know -- Zarathushtra
seeks silent, solitary seclusion -- Zarathushtra
yearns to see Ahura Mazda -- Zarathushtra longs
to commune with Ahura Mazda -- Zarathushtra
is fined with an intense fervour of enthusiasm for
prophetic <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> -- <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">People</span> marvel at the new
prophet -- Zarathushtra definitely breaks with
the religion of his forefathers -- The hostile
Daevayasnian priests -- Friendless and forlorn,
Zarathushtra flees to Ahura Mazda -Zarathushtra's teachings win the ear of the royal
court -- Zarathushtra's mission.
IV.
TOWARDS MONOTHEISM.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Gods</span> in evolution.
V.
AHURA MAZDA
Ahura Mazda is the name Zarathushtra gives to
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> -- Ahura Mazda is the Being par excellence
-- The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of Ahura Mazda -- The
transcendental immanence of Ahura Mazda -Ahura Mazda is the creator -- Ahura Mazda is
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">lord</span> of <span class="t7 t8 t12 hoverable">wisdom</span> -- Ahura Mazda is the lawgiver and judge.
VI.
SPENTA MAINYU
Spenta Mainyu is the self-revealing activity of
Ahura Mazda.

[xxxi]
Notes:
INTRODUCTION
Scope of the Work. This <span class="t6 t8 t10 t11 t16 t20 t21 t27 t28 hoverable">book</span> is the revised and
much enlarged edition of my Zoroastrian Theology,
which has been out of print for the past fifteen years.
The publication of my Zoroastrian Civilization, and Our
Perfecting World, Zarathushtra's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Way</span> of Life, and
professional duties have delayed the completion of
the work. I have inserted new material in several
chapters and added nineteen new chapters to the
book. I have given a concise <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of the religious
beliefs and practices prevalent among the
Zoroastrians and their early Iranian ancestors from
the pre-Gathic times to the present <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> and named
the <span class="t6 t8 t10 t11 t16 t20 t21 t27 t28 hoverable">book</span> History of Zoroastrianism.
Arrangement and method. I have divided the entire
period of the history of Zoroastrianism on the
linguistic basis. The earliest Zoroastrian documents
are the Gathas, <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> in the Gathic dialect. They
represent the earliest phase of the religion of
Zoroaster. But <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> Iran had a religion which
preceded Zoroastrianism in point of time. I have
labelled this period pre-Gathic; for its beginning is
lost in remote antiquity, and the advent of Zoroaster
brings its end.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> when Zoroaster flourished is a moot
question. The approximate date at which he lived is
1000 B.C. Zoroaster revolutionizes the religious <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
of the Iranians, which hitherto represented the
evolutionary phase of religion. It was the movement
in which we <span class="t5 t14 t15 t24 t27 hoverable">find</span> the religious <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> creeping for

ages to rise from the lower to the <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span> level. To put
this in another way, the pre-Gathic religion of Iran is
the evolution of the religious <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> of many <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span>
and many ages; Zoroaster's is the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> of one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span>
and one age. The prophet of Iran establishes a new
religion. In the pre-Gathic religion the trend of
religious <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> struggles from the complex to the
simple, from concrete to abstract, and is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> the
farthest removed from the ideal stage.
Zoroastrianism, on the other hand, as preached in the
Gathas is the very embodiment of the simple and the
abstract. It is the realization [xxxii] of the ideal. It is
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> to which the coming generations have to
conform. Deviation from it means a fall, a
degeneration of the religous life. This <span class="t0 t2 t5 t13 t14 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">second</span> period I
have termed Gathic.
Decay soon begins in the language in which
Zoroaster composed his immortal hymns, and his
successors now write in the Avestan dialect, which
replaces the Gathic. The Avestan language remains
the <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> language of the Zoroastrians from now
onward to probably the last <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span> of the Parthians,
when the Pahlavi language becomes the court
language of the Sasanians and supersedes the
Avestan. The most extensive literature on
Zoroastrianism is <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> in Avestan. This period,
which I have <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Later Avestan period, extends to
the early part of the Pahlavi era and goes even
beyond it. When the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> periods <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> overlap each
other, it often becomes difficult to determine
<span class="t0 t5 t8 t10 t14 t15 t21 t24 t28 hoverable">whether</span> a certain phase of religious <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> is on
one side or the other of the dividing line between
them. The Avestan works, in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> in which they
were <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> in the Avestan period, no longer exist.
They were scattered by the storm that swept over

Persia when Alexander conquered the country, and
shook her religious edifice to its base. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> in
which the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> have reached us is that
which was given them during the Pahlavi period. The
artists employed to restore the broken edifice belong
to the Pahlavi period, but the materials <span class="t0 t12 hoverable">used</span> come
down from the Avestan sources.
The Pahlavi period ranks fourth in the arrangement
of the present work, and it covers a period of about
eight centuries. Although it is most productive under
the Sasanian rule, it does not close with the collapse
of this, the last of the Zoroastrian empires, but
survives it by at least <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> centuries in Moslem
Persia. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> Pahlavi had replaced Avestan, the
early <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> in the <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> language had not
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> ceased to influence the Pahlavi writers. In fact,
some of the most important of the Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> are
either versions of some Avestan <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> now lost to us,
or draw their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> from the Avestan sources.
Thus, the Pahlavi Bundahishn is the epitome of the
Avestan Damdat [Damdad] Nask, which is subsequently
lost. Similarly, not a few of the Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> centuries after the conquest of Persia by
the Arabs tenaciously preserve the tradition handed
down by Sasanian Persia. These are characterized by
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> layers of thought, one traditional, and the other
representing new [xxxiii] <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> current during the
writer's times. The Menuk-i Khrat, for example, betrays
Moslem influence when it preaches fatalism, but is
otherwise faithfully voicing the sentiments of the
orthodox Sasanian Church. This interweaving of old
ideas with the new ones, and the interpolations and
additions of the later writers in the <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> of earlier
generations, often make it hopeless to disentangle the
complications and distinguish between the opinions

and ideas of different periods.
Thirteen hundred <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> have elapsed since the
dissolution of the last of the Zoroastrian empires.
Henceforth we have to record the religious history of
the Zoroastrian remnants in Persia and the
Zoroastrian settlers of India. Zoroastrianism sinks
with the Zoroastrian power, and a <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> period of
obscurity follows. I have named it a period of
decadence.
Under the aegis of the British rule in India
Zoroastrianism emerges once again with the
prosperity of the Parsi community. I have hailed this
as the period of the revival of Zoroastrianism.
These various periods, which represent
chronologically different stages of the historical
development of the religious <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> of Iran, from
remote antiquity down to the immediate present,
will, I hope, give the reader a general and
comprehensive <span class="t25 hoverable">view</span> of the history of Zoroastrian
religion. As the subjects are treated piece-meal in
different periods according to the natural growth of
ideas from period to period, the reader will have to
read crosswise when he needs a complete <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of
any particular concept. For example, if he wants to
know all that the Zoroastrian literature has to say
about Ormazd [Ohrmazd], he will get it as a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">whole</span>
not from any one period, but from all. The detailed
list of contents and the index will help him in his
inquiry.
Transliteration of the technical terms. I have sought
to preserve the changes that these have undergone
during successive periods, and have variously
transliterated them in the treatment of the different

periods, according as they represent the Avestan,
Pahlavi, or Persian pronunciations. Thus, for
example, Ahura Mazda of the Gathic and Avestan
periods become Ormazd [Ohrmazd] in the Pahlavi
period. Angra Mainyu assumes the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> Ahriman in
the subsequent periods. The Avestan Vohu Manah
changes into Pahlavi Vohuman and into Bahman in
Persian. In the frequent <span class="t1 hoverable">use</span> of the name of the
prophet, I have, however, not scrupulously followed
this method. I have distinguished between the
Avestan, [xxxiv] Pahlavi, and Persian forms by
writing Zarathushtra for the first, and Zaratusht for
Pahlavi and Zartusht [Zartosht] for Persian as they
actually occur in these languages; but I have adopted
the more familiar <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> Zoroaster for general use.
Similarly, I have <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the religion of the prophet
Zoroastrianism. With a <span class="t25 hoverable">view</span> to simplicity for the
general reader, I have avoided, as far as it has been
practicable, the <span class="t1 t8 hoverable">free</span> <span class="t1 hoverable">use</span> of diacritical marks, and have
employed simple transcriptions of the names of the
heavenly <span class="t0 t1 t15 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">beings</span> persons, and books when they occur
in the text.

HISTORY OF ZOROASTRIANISM
Notes:
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> I
THE SOURCES
The data of information. The materials that we
gather for the preparation of the history of the
religion that Zarathushtra preached in <span class="t21 hoverable">Ancient</span> Iran
come from varied sources. The earliest native records
are embodied in the sacred <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> in which the
prophet and his immediate disciples propounded the
new religion. These are furnished by the Avestan
literature, which is followed by the Pahlavi and
Pazend [Pazand] <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> and finally by the writings in
Modern Persian down to the end of the eighteenth
century.
Peoples of diverse faiths and nationalities have
likewise, <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> about Zoroaster and his teachings
from the earliest to the modern times. Greeks and
Romans and Christians in the Occident and Indians,
Hebrews, Arabs, Syrians, Armenians, and Chinese in
the Orient have contributed to the fund of
information on the subject. Zarathushtra has founded
a new religion and we shall begin with the
consideration of the materials <span class="t0 t12 hoverable">used</span> in the foundation,
which are to be gleaned from the Avesta, the earliest
literature produced by Iran.
The Avestan Nasks. Tradition credits Zarathushtra
with having <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> profusely. Pliny states that the

early part of <span class="t26 hoverable">third</span> century before the Christian era,
had studied some 2,000,000 verses composed by
Zoroaster.1 The Arabic historians Tabari and Masudi

equal parts of seven each to correspond with them.
These <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> divisions are classified under the
headings: Gasanik, that is, pertaining to the Gathas
or devotional hymns, the Hadha Mansarik, which as

The entire collection of the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> that has
reached us consists of about 83,000 words,9 that is,

about one-fourth of the original twenty-one Nasks.
The Vendidad is the one Nask that has survived the
ravages of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> in its Complete form. Some of the
lost Nasks are preserved in part in the Yasna, Yashts,
and Nirangistan. We shall draw <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> this A vestan
material in our discussion of the Gathic and A vestan
periods.
The Pahlavi, Pazend, and Persian sources. During
the chaos that prevailed in Iran after the downfall of
the Achaemenian empire, the Avestan language
began to decay. When it grew unintelligible to the
people, the learned priests undertook translations and
explanations of the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> into Pahlavi, [5] the
new language which originated during the period.
These commentaries on the original Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> are
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> âzainti in Avesta, and zand in Pahlavi. The
explanatory <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> now came to be known as Avastaku Zand or the Avesta and the commentaries. Pahlavi
was the court language of the Sasanians and it
survived the downfall of their empire by at least <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span>
centuries. Extensive Pahlavi literature that came into 10. See West.
existence under the Sasanians has mostly perished.
GIrPh.2. 90, 91.
The <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> that have reached us were <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> after
the downfall of the Sasanian empire, mostly during
the Abbasid period. The compilation of the most
important <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of the period, the Dinkard
[Denkard], for example, was commenced by the
learned high-priest Atarfarnbarg Farokhzad in the
beginning of the ninth century and completed by one
of his successors, Adarbad Hemed, towards the end
of the ninth century. The Dinkard [Denkard], Vijirkard-i
Dinik, and the Persian Rivayets give us summaries of the
lost Nasks. We gather from the contents of the lost
Nasks given in the Dinkard [Denkard] that, with the
exception of the eleventh Nask, altogether twenty

Avestan Nasks, nineteen along with their Pahlavi
commentaries and one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> it, still existed in the
ninth century. The greater part of these <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> has
perished during the unsettled times when Persia fell
under the barbarous rule of the Tartars. Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span>
on religious subjects that are extant consist of about
446,000 words.10
With the invention of the modern Persian alphabet,
Pahlavi fell into the background. An admixture of
Aryan and Semitic make-up the Pahlavi language as
written. It was later simplified by the elimination of
all Semitic <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> and replacing them with their
Iranian equivalents. The original Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> were
explained and interpreted by the Pahlavi commentary
which, as we saw, was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Zand. A further need
was felt to make explanatory versions of the Pahlavi
<span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> themselves. This further explanation and added
commentary is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Pazand from the Avestan <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span>
paiti zainti. Short benedictory prayers are composed in
Pazend [Pazand] as supplementary prayers to the
original Avestan prayers, The Pazend [Pazand] <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span>
were <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> in Avestan script. With the introduction
of the Arabic script in Persia, the Pahlavi script fell
into disuse.
Zoroastrian <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> came to be <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> in the modern
Persian [6] alphabet. A considerable literature, both
in prose and poetry, has sprung up during the last
11. See West. GIrPh.
seven centuries in Persian on Zoroastrian subjects.11
2. 122-129.
The Pahlavi and Pazend [Pazand] <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> originated in
Persia, whereas both Persia and India contributed in
the production of the Persian works.
Parsi-Sanskrit and Gujarati sources. An Indian
school of Parsi Sanskritists of the thirteenth century,

headed by Neryosang Dhaval, has translated some
parts of the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> into Sanskrit from their
Pahlavi version. Besides these, they have <span class="t1 t7 t12 t29 hoverable">left</span> for us
the Sanskrit translation of a few Pahlavi works.
A considerable literature, in prose and verse, has
appeared in Gujarati on Zoroastrian subjeccts in
India. A Gujarati version of the Yasna and Vendidad
and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> renderings of the Khordah Avesta were
published in the beginning of the nineteenth century,
that is, before the influence of Western scholarship
penetrated into India. <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">Works</span> <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> in Gujarati
continue to be published to the present day.
Oriental sources. The Indo-Iranians shared a
common religious heritage, and the Rig Veda
furnishes us with the earliest sacred <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> that are
helpful in the better understanding of the religious
beliefs of the pre-Gathic, Gathic, and the Younger
Avestan periods of the history of Zoroastrianism.
There are, likewise, scattered passages in the Vedas,
Brahmanas, Smriti, and Puranas that refer to the
Iranians and their religion. Judaism under the Exile
was influenced by Zoroastrian teachings and
furnishes us with points of resemblance between the
angelology, demonology, and eschatology of the
Iranians and the Hebrews. The Armenian historians
<span class="t3 t6 hoverable">Moses</span> of Khoren and Elisaeus, the theologians Eznik
and the Syrian Theodore bar Khoni, the Acts and
Passions of Persian Saints and Martyrs, <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span>
by Zoroastrian converts to Christianity, the Syriac,
Armenian, Judaic, and Christian polemic literature
against Zoroastrianism, and the writings of the
Mandaeans are <span class="t10 t16 hoverable">full</span> of views held by those who
opposed the <span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">state</span> religion of Persia during the
Sasanian period. A host of Arabic and Mohammedan
Persian writers from the <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span> of Ibn Khurdadhbah

(A.D 816) and al-Baladhuri (A.D. 851), al-Biruni
(A.D. 973-1048), al-Shahrastani (A.D. 1086-1153),
to Yakut (A.D. 1250), Kazwini (A.D. 1263),
Mirkhond (A.D. 1432-1498) and Mohsan Fani (A.D.
1600-1670) give valuable [7] information on our
subject. There are stray passages in Chinese literature
with reference to the religious beliefs and practices of
the Zoroastrians.
Occidental sources. The contact of Persia with
Greece began in the fifth century B.C. under the
Achaemenians. It continued with Rome up to the
middle of the seventh century A.D., to the last <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span>
of the Sasanians. Ktesias was the court physician of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> Artaxerxes II. Xanthus and Herodotus began to
acquaint their readers with ihe manners and customs
and religious beliefs of the Persians. Hermippus (B.C.
250) is said to have studied the writings of
Zarathushtra. Theopompus and Hermippus are the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> writers <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> writings on Persian religion
the later writers have drawn considerably. Plutarch
was familiar with the lost <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of Theopompus and
gives useful information on his authority, Diogenes
Laertius says that Aristotle was familiar with the
theory of Persian dualism. Plutarch, Strabo, and a few
others write from their personal observation. Cicero,
Pliny, Ammianus Marcellinus, and other Roman
writers continued to write about Persia up to the
Middle Ages. The writings of the earlier classical
authors throw special <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the religious beliefs
and practices of the Achaemenians.
Inscriptions, coins, and tablets as the last source of
information. The Old Persian Inscriptions with their
Babylonian and New Elamitic renderings found at
Behistan, Persepolis, Naqsh-i Rustam, Elvand, Susa,
Kerman, and Suez; the Babylonian, Egyptian, and

Greek inscriptions, <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> with the <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> of the
<span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> classical writers, furnish us with information
about the religious beliefs and practices of the
Achaemenians. The Pahlavi inscriptions, likewise,
add to our <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of the religious <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the
Sasanian period. The names of about ten Zoroastrian
Amesha Spentas and Yazatas that appear on the coins
of Indo-Scythic rulers of Northwestern India in
Greek characters and the epigraphic <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> in
Babylonian, Egyptian, and Greek contribute to the
information that we get about Zoroastrianism from
varied sources.
[8]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> II
AIRYANA-VAEJAH
The Stem-land of the Aryans. The problem of the
cradle of the Aryan race will probably never be
solved with' certainty. Airyana-vaejah, 'the stem-land
of the Aryans,' is spoken of as the first of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span>
lands created by Ahura Mazda.1 It had a mild and
genial climate, with long, pleasant summers and short
winters. Unlike Indian Yama, who chose the realm of
the dead and established his suzerainty in the
heavenly world, Yima was the illustrious <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> who
ruled over <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> and beasts and converted his
kingdom into a veritable paradise <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> earth.
Animals and mankind prospered and grew in such
large numbers in his memorable reign, which
tradition has subsequently regarded as the Golden
Age of Iran, that the country could no longer hold
them. Ahura Mazda, thereupon, bade him to lead his
overflowing population to migrate southwards, on
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> of the sun. Yima carried out the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span>

1. Vd. 1.3.
2. Vd. 2.9-19.
3. Vd. 2.21.
4. Vd. 2.22-24.

behest and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> the difficulty was not solved, for the
numbers kept on increasing steadily. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span>
organized a <span class="t0 t2 t5 t13 t14 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">second</span> migration again towards the
south and still a <span class="t26 hoverable">third</span> in the same direction.2
Moreover, the happy home of the Aryans was
destined to be further disturbed, Ahura Mazda knew
this through his omniscience and he <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> a
conference of the angels and summoned Yima to
attend it with the best of his men.3 He then warned
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> that Angra Mainyu, the enemy of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> and
men, contemplated invasion of Airyana-vaejah. He
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> cause <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> winter to fall that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span>
fierce, deadly frost. Such dense desolation <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span>
follow the icy deluge that every vestige of <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span>
habitation <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> disappear and it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be a wonder
if even a footprint of a sheep could be seen.4 Angra
Mainyu did invade the happy home of the Aryans
and plagued it with a deluge of snow and ice.
Forewarned by Ahura Mazda, the mighty <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> <span class="t2 t4 t6 t9 t18 t19 t22 hoverable">took</span>
timely measures, and before Angra Mainyu [9] cause
destruction and death, through deadly deluge, or, in
the language of geology, before the glacial cataclysm
rendered the primeval Aryan home unfit for
habitation, he led a further successful migration
towards the hospitable south.
The Indo-Europeans. This virile race, white in
colour and fair of complexion, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> itself Aryan or
noble. It was the parent of the Indo-European
peoples of history, These members of the Aryan
family lived <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> as a homogeneous <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> speaking
the same language with dialectic differences and
shared many beliefs and practices in common.
Pressure of growing population, thirst for adventure,
sharp divisions caused by the fermentation going on
in the minds of thinking persons over religious beliefs

and practices continued to disintegrate them. During
the early part of the <span class="t0 t2 t5 t13 t14 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">second</span> millennium B.C., nomad
tribes <span class="t1 t7 t12 t29 hoverable">left</span> their home and turned westwards and
reached the Aegean lands or turned southwards in
successive waves from the steppes of the Caspian Sea.
Scattered tribes passed by the chain of Caucasus,
entered Armenia and spread southwards. Some of the
more virile tribes succeeded in founding small Aryan
kingdoms. They have <span class="t1 t7 t12 t29 hoverable">left</span> traces of their Aryan beliefs
and practices. The Kassites, who rose to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> in the
Zagros in 1700 B.C., designated godhead by the
Indo-European term bugash, Av. baga, Skt. bhaga, Slav.
bogu, Phrygian, bagaios, and worshipped Suryash, Skt.
surya, the sun, as their chief god. The Mitannis, who
founded an Aryan empire between the Euphrates and
the Tigris, have <span class="t1 t7 t12 t29 hoverable">left</span> behind them the record of their
own names, such as Dushratta, Artatama, and the
names of the Aryan divinities Mitra, Indra, Varuna,
and Nasatya in an inscription dating 14th century
B.C. at Boghaz-Keui. The trend of migration
continued until We see the Aryan Medes at a later
date facing the Semitic Assyrians as their immediate
neighbours.
The Indo-Iranians. The other migratory wave
extended earlier towards the Elburz [Alburz] range
and to the southern belt of the Caspian an Sea and
<span class="t2 t4 t6 t9 t18 t19 t22 hoverable">took</span> the tastward course. The Vendidad opens the
enumeration of the sixteen <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> places created by
Ahura Mazda, ranging between Airyana-vaejah in the
5. Vd1.1-20.
north and Hapta Hindu or Sapta Sindhu, the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">land</span> of
seven (later five) rivers, the Panjaub.5 The names of
these lands may not be <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> as marking [10] the
successive stages of the Aryan migration showing the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> leaving their original habitat, descending
downwards through the Caucasus, crossing the

Elburz [Alburz] range, entering eastern Iran or
modern Afghanistan, passing the Hindukush and
terminating their peregrinations in Sapta Sindhu. But
the test may be <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> as recording historicogeographical reminiscence on the part of the writers
of the south-eastward migration of the Aryan race.
Of the various sections of the Aryan family, the
ancestors of those that later became known in history
as the Indians and the Iranians lived longest and
closest <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> in eastern Iran. They sacrificed to
the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> and entertained the same <span class="t25 hoverable">view</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> earth. They separated at a later period and a
group turned towards the south, crossed the
Hindukush and entered the Panjaub by about 2000
B.C.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Aryan family <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> dispersed during several
generations and the members sought out for
themselves new settlements in Asia and Europe. Of
the various groups that separated from the main stock
at different times, the Iranian group preserved most
faithfully the original name of the primeval home of
the Aryans. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> of residence had changed, the
surroundings had altered beyond recognition, and
the communities that lived and shared <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> with them
had gone. But the deeply cherished name Airyanavaejah had been indelibly imprinted on their minds.
The veneration for the stem-land lived, the memory
of its paradisaic condition still lingered, the
auspicious name Airyana-vaejah continued still to be
passionately loved, and the Iranians resolved that
their latest settlement should be known for ever by
no other name than Airyana vaejah of happy
memory.

[11]
THE GATHIC PERIOD
ABOUT 1000 B.C.
[12 is blank]
[13]
Notes:
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">III</span>
ZARATHUSHTRA
Zarathushtra doubts to know. Prophets are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> in
the flesh, and Zarathushtra, the prophet of Iran, was
such a man-god. His date of birth, as we shall see in
subsequent chapters, is placed anywhere between 600
B.C. and 6000 B.C. It is an uncontested <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> that
there is a marked closeness between the grammar,
metre, and style of the Rig Veda and the Gathas. The
Gathic inflexions are more primitive than the Vedic.
The period of the position of the Gathas, therefore,
cannot be separated from the Vedas by any
considerable distance of time. Zarathushtra's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> of
birth is of equal uncertainty. His earliest appearance
in the Gathas is at the period of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> when he has
<span class="t1 t7 t12 t29 hoverable">left</span> his pupilage behind. He has evidently learnt all
he could from what the teachers of his <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span> could
give him. He has conversed with the <span class="t5 t8 hoverable">wise</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> of his
country. He has often visited the central places
where trade routes from distant lands converged and
has gathered information and experience from the
worldly-wise travellers, merchants, and pilgrims. But

the more he has learnt, the more eager his <span class="t0 t10 t11 t17 t25 t28 t29 hoverable">desire</span> to
learn further has grown. His teachers had instructed
him in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> based on tradition. But tradition is
stagnant, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> is ever on the onward move.
Besides, tradition is wedded to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> that is dead,
and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> looks to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to be <span class="t9 t24 hoverable">born</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span>
end. Moreover, tradition demands its instruction to
be <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> on trust, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> is based on inquiry
and discussion. <span class="t1 t11 t16 t20 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">Reason</span> is shadowed by doubt and
doubt is the parent of knowledge. Zarathushtra, a
paragon of reason, doubts the <span class="t7 t8 t12 hoverable">wisdom</span> of his teachers.
Zarathushtra resolves to be his own teacher, and to
learn by observation and thinking. He thinks and
thinks deeply and comprehensively on the conditions
prevailing around him. He considers that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> is not
woven of the tissues of joy and happiness alone, but
of considerable sorrow and misery also. Injustice and
inequity, strife and oppression, poverty and
destitution, greed [14] and avarice, wrath and rapine,
falsehood and deceit, envy and malice, hatred and
jealousy, crime and vice, sorrow and suffering, filth
and disease confront him everywhere. He is keenly
responsive to <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> sufferings and the groans and
sighs of the agonized hearts. The misery of the
multitude touches his heart. His <span class="t6 t20 hoverable">flesh</span> creeps, his
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">heart</span> is heavily oppressed, and his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> is depressed
at the sight of this dark side of <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> life. He suffers
at the sight of suffering and, with <span class="t2 t6 t19 t20 t26 t29 hoverable">eyes</span> suffused with
tears, he lives from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> thinking and
brooding over the woes of the world. Zarathushtra
doubts the goodness of gods.
He is religious at heart, but his daily experience of
the religion practised and lived around him tends to
estrange him from the <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> of his forefathers. He sees
with horror temples reeking with the blood of

sacrifical animals. He finds that barren formalism,
sanctimonious scrupulosity, meticulous ablutions,
superstitious fear, and display of external holiness
<span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t11 t12 t19 t22 hoverable">pass</span> for religion. Zarathushtra doubts the religion of
his birth.
Zarathushtra seeks silent, solitary seclusion.
Solitude is nature's sublime temple where <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> can
commune with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> in the surrounding silence and
unruffled calm. Mountains lift their heads
majestically on the Iranian plateau, and Zarathushtra
retreated into the mountain fastness. Here, far
removed from the stress and strife of life, and with no
<span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> sound to distract his thoughts, he made his
home. He breathed the refreshing air. The twittering
and chirping and whistling and singing of birds filled
the air. Here the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> and waters, birds and beasts,
<span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">sun</span> and moon, stars and planets worked as his
teachers. He read some lesson, some message <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span>
by the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">hand</span> of the maker of all on every pebble and
every leaf, every dewdrop and every sunbeam, in
every star and every planet. Here he plunged into a
reverie or gazed into vacancy. The calm atmosphere
is conducive to communion, and here, in the
monastic void; he communed with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> which
inspired solemn thoughts in him. He communed with
his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> and he communed with his inner self. He
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> and he reasoned, he cogitated and he
contemplated, he mused and he dreamed. He
meditated <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the essence of divinity, the anomalies
of life, and the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> destiny after death. Here in
this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> and glorious temple of nature, built by
<span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> hands, his <span class="t2 t6 t19 t20 t26 t29 hoverable">eyes</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> saw what the <span class="t2 t6 t19 t20 t26 t29 hoverable">eyes</span> of
<span class="t6 t20 hoverable">flesh</span> could not see. Here in the sublime sanctuary
spoke the solemn voice of [15] the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> vicar and
he <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t18 hoverable">heard</span> it. Zarathushtra's creative <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> evolved the

highest conception of godhead, whom he named
Ahura Mazda or the <span class="t5 t8 hoverable">Wise</span> Lord.
Zarathushtra yearns to see Ahura Mazda.
Zarathushtra has prepared himself through the <span class="t5 t8 hoverable">wise</span>
discipline of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> and <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">heart</span> and through the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of
piety to receive his message from Mazda. He longs
for the moment when, being enlightened in mind, he
shall visualize Vohu Manah or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Good</span> Mind, Asha or
Righteousness, Sraosha, the embodiment of
Obedience to <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> commandments, and the
sublime seat of beneficent Ahura.1 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Mind</span> alone can

Zarathushtra longs to approach Mazda through Vohu

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> which rests the enlightenment of life, and pure

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> came to him and inquired who he was and to

bound up in one idea: Ahura Mazda.

But the messenger of Mazda is determined to <span class="t3 hoverable">face</span>
them and overcome them and emerge triumphant in
the end. He tells Mazda that he will lead mankind on
the path of righteousness and sing untiringly his
praise all around as <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> as his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> is <span class="t2 t15 t24 hoverable">blessed</span> with
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> and strength.35 He speaks of his <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> in terms
of a universal religion. He is convinced that the
religion that Ahura Mazda has commissioned him to
preach is the best for all mankind.36 He looks forward
to winning all living <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> for the <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> of Ahura
Mazda.37
But the ardent <span class="t0 t10 t11 t17 t25 t28 t29 hoverable">desire</span> of the prophet was not to be
fulfilled [18] at the moment, nor to be accomplished
in <span class="t10 t16 hoverable">full</span> measure in after ages. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> possessed of all
the best elements that fitted it to be a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> creed,
Zoroastrianism has never shown any signs of
becoming a universal religion. In the midst of the
vicissitudes of fortune, it has been a national religion
at best. Little short of a miracle has saved it from
total extinction, and various causes have combined to
reduce it to the narrowest limits today as the
communal religion of a hundred and twenty-five

thousand souls. This <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> will be <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> out more
prominently in the treatment of the religious
development during the subsequent periods.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">People</span> marvel at the new prophet. Zarathushtra
turned his steps to his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> of birth and childhood.
His kinsfolk and friends recognized him and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> they
were bewildered to witness a marvellous change in
him. He was of course grown in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> and stature. But
there was something indescribable that those who
saw him could not realize. His <span class="t3 hoverable">face</span> had grown sweet
and serene. It breathed ineffable kindness and bore
shining reflection of his pure inner life. It wore the
expression of gentleness and cheerfulness, hope and
confidence. A resplendent halo of righteousness
encircled his magnetic face. He moved among <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span>
with a friendly look and a kindly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> to all. His
moral grandeur struck awe <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> those who came near
him. The sublimity of his serene behaviour, the
childlike simplicity of his speech, the unassuming
attitude of his movements, the imperturbable calm
and passive countenance aroused feelings of
reverence in those who met him. They greeted him
with salutations and adoration. His advent soon
became the event of surrounding villages. All eagerly
pointed to him and talked abour him. In dumb
veneration <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> gazed at him, admired him, adored
him, and marvelled at him. He was Zarathushtra of
the Spitamas, they said, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> he was altogether a novel
personality. He was of them and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> above them, he
was akin to them and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> unlike them. He spoke
unheard of words, he talked of unknown things. He
was what they were not. They were but men, he was
greater than man, he was an angel, he was a godling.
Zarathushtra definitely breaks with the religion of
his forefathers. Zarathushtra has seen by this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span>

that there were some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> who were anxious to
hear what he had to say. He now began to give
lengthy talks on subjects of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> importance to his
eager listeners. He saw that he could sway and draw
the [19] hearts of his hearers to himself. He gave
forth publicly that he came from his maker Ahura
Mazda, whom he declared to be incomparably
greater than the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> they had so far known. This
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> had sent him as his chosen prophet to
preach a nobler religion than the one they followed.
Their priests had laid <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> emphasis on outward
observances and carried rules for rituals to meticulous
casuistry. Their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> were fond of sacrificial offerings
of animals and birds. Religion, preached
Zatathushtra, did not consist in a scrupulous
observance of outward forms, but was based mainly
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the heart. A broken <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">heart</span> and a contrite <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span>
were the choicest sacrifices that the faithful could
offer to their creator. Burning tears of a penitent
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">heart</span> were better than a cupful of oblations. The aim
and <span class="t24 t25 hoverable">object</span> and end of the religion that Mazda had
commissioned him to teach was righteous conduct.
His <span class="t0 t5 t11 hoverable">worship</span> was founded on righteousness. Genuine
piety is of the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">heart</span> and its outward expressions are
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> thoughts, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> words, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> deeds. The
beliefs and practices of his hearers were
irreconcilably alien from what he taught. His
outspoken utterances created diverse effects <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
those who flocked to hear him daily. Some felt
themselves moved and influenced by them.
There were others among his hearers who had
approached him specially with the intention of
finding out his views <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> rousing his attention to
their ill-will. They <span class="t2 t4 t6 t9 t18 t19 t22 hoverable">took</span> alarming reports to their
associates. They saw danger ahead of them. They

waited and watched, suspected and spied. They were
adroitly prepared themselves to <span class="t3 hoverable">face</span> the ominous
situation; and they had not to be <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> in waiting.
Signs of disapprobation, whispers of disapproval,
murmurs of indignation now appeared in various
threatened to break out in open revolt.
The hostile Daevayasnian priests. The priests of the
<span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> were now alarmed. They attempted to
dissuade the prophet from disturbing the peace of the
people. They met often to argue with him on the
questions he was raising, but were foiled in the
controversies.38 They felt themselves humiliated
before the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> and gave up meeting the prophet.
They began to <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> against him and tried in all
possible manners to frustrate the effect he was daily
producing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> his hearers. They were accustomer to
fatten <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the profits of the elaborate ceremonials
[20] and rich sacrifices that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> offered under
their guidance. They were renowned as exorcists who

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> doing him the utmost harm that they can, that

The Kavis and Karapans carried on vehement counter
propaganda against Zarathushtra. They persuaded,
denounced, cajoled, flattered, and threatened in one
breath those that showed signs of being influenced
by the new doctrines. They terrorized them with
excommunication from society, and with persecution
in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> and tortures awaiting them in the next life.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">People</span> dreaded their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> and were not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> swayed
so completely by the new teachings as to <span class="t3 hoverable">face</span>
persecution. The history of religions teaches us that a
new religion does not spread through well-balanced
and reasoned arguments and convictions. It is borne
on the wings of the unbounded enthusiasm and
overflowing emotion that a prophet can create. If a
prophet succeeds in preaching the new ideas that fill
his being, with passionate and frantic zeal, if he
succeeds in kindling the flame of emotional, nervous
enthusiasm among his hearers by his fervent
preaching, if he succeeds by means of his whirlwind
campaign to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> the spark that can <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">whole</span>
country on fire, his religion becomes a living faith.
Zarathushtra's teachings had not so effectively stirred
them. Consequently, those that followed him
hanging with enthusiasm on the unheard of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span>
that he uttered, gave up going after him when they
saw the vehement opposition of the custodians of the

old faith. Those that had seriously <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t18 hoverable">heard</span> him but
were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> undecided and hesitating in the choice
between the charms of the new and the dictares of
the old religion, deserted him. The ignorant and
unthinking people, who had, with child-like
curiosity, turned wherever his footsteps trod, imitated
the elders of <span class="t5 t11 hoverable">society</span> and <span class="t1 t7 t12 t29 hoverable">left</span> him. Those who were
proud to claim him as their friend forsook him when
the hour came for them to stand by him. Those that
were his kith and kin disowned him, because he had
disavowed their ancestral faith. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> did the
wavering, timid, half-hearted followers fail him in his
hour of need and leave him. Ahura Mazda alone did
not leave him and, [23] with him on his side,
Zarathushtra felt that he was not alone in his
loneliness. His prestige, however, is shattered and all
restraint is broken. Respect for him is gone. He is
now greeted everywhere with hostile feelings and
coarse jokes. The mob that was hilarious in his
commendation becomes furious in his condemnation.
It mocks and maligns, jeers and insults him.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> fashions religion as an ideal aiming at
cohesiveness, brotherhood, and unity among
mankind. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> makes it disturbing, disruptive, and
divisive. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> ideal recedes from the very
inception of religion, until it grows dim and distant.
It does not die, because ideals are immortal. Hope,
ingrained in <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> heart, holds out the <span class="t0 t28 hoverable">eternal</span>
assurance of its eventual realization.
Friendless and forlorn, Zarathushtra flees to Ahura
Mazda. He implores him, he cries <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> him to help
him as a friend <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> help his friend. He has no

He <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> have to <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span>

court. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> passed a <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> period of trials and

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> that the new teacher taught as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> had

strewed his path with flowers and worshipped the

74. Y46.12.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> him and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> after <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> he found himself
