ASMAN
Firmament deified. In its original <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> Asman means the sky; it is later
personified as the genius of the sky, and invoked as a Yazata.402 He is
shining, exalted, and powerful. Asman and Vahishta Ahu, or Paradise, are
invoked together,403 and the twenty-seventh <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> of the Zoroastrian month is
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> after the name of Asman.
402 Y1.16; 16.6; Sr. 1.27; 2.27.
403 Sr. 1.27; 2.27.
USHAH
The female divinity of dawn. Ushah is identical with the Vedic Ushas, and
is the female divinity of the dawn in both religions, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> coming down from
the common Indo-Iranian period. It is she who announces as the first glimpse
of light, to creation, the approach of dawn. Ushah's personality is very

faintly pronounced both in the Rig Veda and in the Younger Avestan texts.
The Vedic poets have, however, produced most exquisite lyric poetry in
praise of the dawn in about twenty hymns. There is only a short Avestan
hymn in prose composed to celebrate the dawn and even this has but six
lines devoted to the subject of the composition. Here she is described as
beautiful, resplendent, possessed of bright steeds, blessed, and heroic; and
her <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> illumines all the seven zones.404 Auxiliaries to Ushah are Ushahina
and Berejya and Nmanya. In <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> Ushahina, who is also a male
personification of dawn, is the name of the fifth period of the day, and the
prayer consecrated to Ushah bears his name. The priest at the <span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span>
undertakes to propitiate Ushahina by sacrifice, if he has in thought, word,
deed, or will offended him.405
404 Yt5.62; Vd. 18.15, 23; G. 5.5.
405 Y1.20,21.
[216]
TISHTRYA
The star genius directs the rain. Next in importance to the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">sun</span> and moon,
among the heavenly luminaries, are the countless stars. Among the stars that
are personified as objects of praise and reverence, the most prominent is the
radiant and glorious star Tishtrya. He is the star Sirius in the constellation of
Canis Major. The Yazata who impersonates this brilliant star bears naturally
also the same name. The Tishtrya Yasht (8) sings the <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">glory</span> of the twofold
<span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of Tishtrya, both as star and as the Yazata that presides over it.
Tishtrya is, therefore, the rain-star, and the Yasht gives a lively picture of his
movements in producing clouds and rain and sleet, and distributing them
over all the world. Tishtrya's constant companions are the starYazatas,
named Vanant, Satavaesa, and Haptoiringa, as guardian spirits of different
regions of the heavens.406 The thirteenth <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> of the month406a and the fourth
month of the year are sacred to him.
406 Sr. 1.13; 2.13; cf. Moulton, Early Zoroastrianism, p.23.

406a Y16.4.
Tishtrya's attributes. His standing epithets are 'the radiant' and 'the
glorious.' He is the giver of fertility to the fields,407 the giver of happy and
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> abode <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> men, the white, shining, seen from afar, the healing, and
the exalted one.408 He is possessed of the seed of the waters, the valiant, the
courageous, far reaching, the efficient,409 and of sound eyes.410 Ahura Mazda
has appointed Tishtrya as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">lord</span> of all other stars, even as he has ordained
Zarathushtra as the <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">lord</span> of all mankind.411 The creator has made him
as worthy of sacrifice, as worthy of invocation, as worthy of propitiation, and
as worthy of glorification as himself.412 According to Plutarch he is
established as a scout over all other stars.413

The sacrificial offerings enable Tishtrya to <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> with added vigour and

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> himself successive forms when he goes out for active work. He moves
forward in [217] the heavens for the first ten nights of the month in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span>
of a young man, for the next ten nights in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of a bull, and then for the
last ten nights in the shape of a white beautiful horse.415 In accordance with
the will of Ahura Mazda and the archangels, he traverses the most distant
parts of the earth,416 and the Iranian countries <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> for his advent, for it is
through him that the country will witness a year of plenty or of drought.417

Men and beasts, the waters and all, look eagerly to the rising of the star
Tishtrya, as he will send a flood of rain to fertilize their waste lands with
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> and bestow riches <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the earth, if the righteous faithfully offer him
praise and worship.418 The farmer yearns for a few drops of Tishtrya's rain to
moisten his parched fields, the gardener longs for a shower to brighten the
foliage. The <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">land</span> smiles with rich harvests as a result of his fertilizing waters.

His fight with the demon of drought. Tishtrya is opposed in his <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of
producing rain by his adversary Apaosha, the demon of drought, who keeps
back the rain. The Tishtrya Yasht gives a picturesque <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of the struggle
between them. [218] In the combat with the fiend that holds the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> in
clutch through famine and drought, Apaosha, who appears in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of a
terrifying black horse, assaults his opponent and in their opening combat
succeeds in forcing Tishtrya to retreat. Worsted by the fiend, Tishtrya
mourns his defeat and complains that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> do not sufficiently <span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span>
him as they do <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> other celestial powers, for had they not been sparing in
their invocation, he <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> have been able to <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> a further strength of ten
horses, of ten camels, of ten oxen, of ten mountains, and of ten rivers to his
side. Ahura Mazda himself, thereupon, offers a <span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> Tishtrya and
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> imparts new strength to him. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> emboldened, he now, with renewed
vigour, attacks his rival for the <span class="t0 t2 t5 t13 t14 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">second</span> time, and after a fierce struggle
overcomes him. His triumph is hailed as the triumph of the waters, plants,
and the religion of Mazda, for Tishtrya is now in a position to <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span>
prosperity to the country.424 Ahura Mazda, the Amesha Spentas, as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as
Mithra, Ashi Vanghuhi, and Parendi, are among those that help Tishtrya in
this war of the elements for the benefit of mankind425
424 Yt8.20-29.
425 Yt8.7,38.
VANANT
A star-Yazata. The other important star-Yazata besides Tishtrya who is
classed among the <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t1 t15 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">beings</span> is Vanant. The twentieth Yasht is
composed in his honour. Tradition assigns to him the special <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of
guarding the gates of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Alburz round which the sun, moon and the
stars revolve, and accounts him as the leader of a constellation in the western
heavens in the war against the planets. In the Avestan Yasht bearing this star-

Yazata's name, Vanant is specially invoked to give help to smite the noxious
creatures of Angra Mainyu.426 Some spells to this effect, composed in the
Pazend language, are later appended to this particular Yasht. It is elsewhere
stated in the Avesta that Ahura Mazda has created him,427 and that the
faithful ask him for strength and victory to enable them to remove distress
and tyranny.427a
426 Yt20.1.
427 Yt8.12; Ny1.8.
427a Yt8.12.
[219]
SATAVAESA
An acolyte of Tishtrya. The star Satavaesa is also personified, but his
individuality is very faintly pronounced. He has no Yasht or hymn composed
to glorify him. As an acolyte of Tishtrya, he causes the waters of the sea
Vourukasha to flow down to the seven zones for the nourishment of plants
and animals, and for the fertility and prosperity of the Aryan nations.428
428 Yt8.9; 13.43; Sr. 1.13; 2.13.
HAPTOIRINGA
Another acolyte of Tishtrya. This constellation, Ursa Major, is also raised to
the position of a lesser divinity. Ninety-nine <span class="t6 hoverable">thousand</span> nine hundred and
ninety-nine Fravashis watch over this stellar cluster.429 The genius of this star
is invoked to enable mankind to oppose the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> caused by the sorcerers and
fairies.430
429 Yt13.60.
430 Yt8.12; Sr. 2.13.
VAYU

The deification of the wind. Vayu, or Vata, is the Indo-Iranian
impersonation of wind. The terms Vayu and Vata are variously <span class="t0 t12 hoverable">used</span> to
represent either the wind or the genius of wind in both the Rig Veda and in
the Avestan texts. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Yet</span> Vayu is chiefly the personification of the wind. As we
have already seen, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">whole</span> of the Ram Yasht treats of the exploits of
Raman's comrade Vayu. Vayu's wind is divided into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> parts, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> and
the evil. The wind is productive of good, but it also causes harm. That part
of Vayu which is supposed to be the source of harm is branded as evil, and
classed among Angra Mainyu's creations. Hence the faithful <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> care to
<span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> that part alone of Vayu which is the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> of Spenta
Mainyu.431 The twenty-second <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> of the month is named after Vayu.432
431 Y22.24; 25.5; Yt15.5,42,57; Sr. 1.21; 2.21.
432 Y16.5.
Vayu’s attributes. The genius of wind is most frequently <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> 'working on
high.' He strikes terror among all, and [220] fearlessly enters the deepest and
the darkest places to smite the demons.433 He is high-girt, of strong stature,
of <span class="t17 t29 hoverable">high</span> foot, of wide breast, of broad thighs, and of powerful eyes.434 He
wears a golden helm and a golden crown, a golden necklace, and golden
garment; he has golden shoes and a golden girdle; and armed with golden
weapons he rides in a golden chariot rolling on golden wheels.435 A fine
image this, to immortalize Vayu in a golden statue! The poet gives a <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> list
of the names of Vayu, and is very prolific in ascribing <span class="t17 t29 hoverable">high</span> attributes to him.
In this the <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> composer follows the Yasht dedicated to Ahura Mazda. In
<span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> Vayu is the only angel who is known, like Ahura Mazda, by many
names. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">text</span> enumerates about forty-seven of such titles. Almost all of
these attributes of Vayu are derived from the function of Vayu as wind,
rather than from his activity as the genius of wind. They pertain to the
atmospheric phenomenon more than to the abstract ideas about the angel.
Some of the more important of the names of Vayu are as follows: the
overtaker, the all-vanquishing, the good-doer, the one going forwards and
backwards, the destroyer, smiter, usurper, the most valiant, the strongest, the
firmest, the stoutest, the vanquisher at one stroke, the destroyer of malice,
the liberator, the pervading one, and the glorious.436

433 Yt15.53.
434 Yt15.54.
435 Yt15.57.
436 Yt15.43-48.
Those who offer sacrifices <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> Vayu. The recital of his names has a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
efficacy, and Vayu asks Zarathushtra to invoke these names in the thick of
the battle, or when the tyrant and heretic threaten him with their havocking
hordes. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> in heavy fetters finds himself freed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the recital of these
names.437 Vayu is the greatest of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> and the strongest of the strong.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">text</span> briefly describes how some of the most illustrious personages
invoked Vayu and begged of him various boons, and in this connection we
may recall that Herodotus438 mentions the <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> that the Persians sacrificed to
the winds among other <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> forces in nature. The list of Vayu's supplicants
in Yasht 15 is headed by Ahura Mazda himself, who desired the boon that he
may smite the creatures of Angra Mainyu, but that none may smite the
<span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> of Spenta Mainyu.439 Among the kings, renowned heroes. and other
personages who sacrificed [221] <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> Vayu, and to whom the angel granted
their boons, are Haoshyangha, Takhma Urupi, Yima, Thraetaona, Keresaspa,
Aurvasara, Hutaosa, and such maidens as are not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> given in marriage.440
Even the wicked Azhi Dahaka begged also of him a boon, but Vayu rejected
his sacrifice.441 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Men</span> <span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> Vayu with libations and prayers and ask
for strength to vanquish their adversaries.442 Vayu asks Zarathushtra to
invoke him, in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> that neither Angra Mainyu, nor the sorcerers, nor the
demons may be able to injure him.443

ATAR
The <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> cult in Iran. The cult of the sacrificial <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> goes back to the IndoEuropean period. The Skt. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> agni, 'fire,' has for its equivalent Latin ignis
and Slavonic ogni. The most prominent divinity after Indra in the Vedas is
<span class="t0 t3 t5 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t21 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Agni</span> and more than 200 hymns and several stray passages are devoted to his
glorification. The Iranian <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> for <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as for the Yazata presiding
over <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> is Atar. Among both the Indians and the Iranians <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> occupies the
central position in all rituals. The priest who tended the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> is known by a
common name among both the peoples. Among the Indians he is atharvan
and among the Iranians âthravan, literally meaning, 'one who tends fire.’ A
litany is composed in honour of Atar and he is celebrated many other
passages. The ninth month of the year and the ninth <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> of the month are
named after Atar.444 444 Y16.4.
Atar, or Fire, is most frequently <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> of Ahura Mazda in the
Younger Avestan texts. The devout hunger in <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">heart</span> to reach Mazda through
him as a mediary.445 Asha Vahishta’s association with the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> continues and
they are often together. As the most <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">holy</span> symbol of his faith, the house-lord
prays that the sacred element may ever burn in his house.446 We have already
seen that the Avesta speaks of some fires consecrated by the pre-Zoroastrian
kings in Iran. The Avestan <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> refer to the dâitya gâtu, 'proper place,' for
the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> and the Old Persian Inscriptions <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of the âyadanâ as the places of
worship.447 The bas-relief sculpture at Naksh-i-Rustam [222] over the royal
tomb shows an altar with <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> on it. Herodotus, the earliest of the Greek
writers on Persia, however, informs us that the Persians did not erect temples
in his days, but sacrificed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> the elements sun, moon, earth, fire, water,
and wind on the summits of mountains.448 Dino, the contemporary of
Alexander, does not mention the fire-temples and says that the Persians

worshipped in the open air.449 It may be that the early writers did not come
across temples in Iran, in the Greek <span class="t0 t1 t7 t12 t13 t14 t17 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">sense</span> of the term. But there must
certainly have been some <span class="t23 hoverable">kind</span> of structures to protect the sacred <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> from
being extinguished. Strabo450 for the first <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> mentions in Cappadocia
places dedicated to fire, and speaks of enclosures with <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> altars in the
centre. No sacrifices, we are told, were offered to any divinity <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> the
accompaniment of the invocation of fire. These altars, we are further
informed by Strabo, were filled with ashes over which the sacred <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> burned
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> and night. The Magi, he adds, tended the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">holy</span> flames, and with
Baresman twigs in their <span class="t20 hoverable">hands</span> daily performed their devotions for about an
hour.451 Pausanias (A.D. 173) corroborates this statement from his personal
observation in Lydia.452 Xenophon and Curtius Rufus acquaint us with the
practice of carrying <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> on portable altars in religious processions.453

Atar is both the genius of <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> and the element <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> itself. As the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> dwells
in every house, he is constantly spoken of in the Rig Veda as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">lord</span> of the
house. The Yasna in the manner calls him the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">lord</span> of all houses.454 He is the

great Yazata.455 He is the most bountiful,456 of renowned name457 the
beneficent warrior, and <span class="t10 t16 hoverable">full</span> of <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">glory</span> and healing.458 Besides being the angel
that presides over fire, Atar is also <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> as such. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> concepts are often so
mixed up <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> that it becomes difficult to distinguish between the
blazing <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> burning <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the [223] altar and the angel that personifies it.
The difficulty is still more increased when we see the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> on the hearth
conceived of as speaking and blessing as a person. The householders pray
that the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> may ever burn and blaze in their houses.459 In the Vedas, <span class="t0 t3 t5 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t21 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Agni</span> is
a friend of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who entertains him as a guest and feeds him with fuel.460
The <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> of Mazda, likewise, solicits devotional offerings from those persons
for whom he cooks the evening and the morning meal, he looks at the <span class="t20 hoverable">hands</span>
of all passers-by, to see if they <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> some present for him or not, even as a
friend for a friend. When the faithful <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> to him fuel, dry and exposed to
the light, he is propitiated, and in the fulfillment of his wish blesses the
votary with a flock of cattle and a multitude of men, an active <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> and an
active spirit, and a joyous life.461 During the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> watches of the night Atar
wakes up the <span class="t0 t1 t8 t11 t15 t21 t23 t24 hoverable">master</span> of the house, the husbandman, and calls Sraosh for
help.462 Here also it is not so much the angel Atar that acts, as it is the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span>
itself, for the <span class="t0 t1 t8 t11 t15 t21 t23 t24 hoverable">master</span> of the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> and the husbandman are asked to wash
their <span class="t20 hoverable">hands</span> and <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> fuel to it, lest the demon Azi should extinguish it.463
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who responds with alacrity, and is the first to wake up and tend the
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> with dry wood, receives Atar's blessings.464 The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who sacrifices <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span>
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> with fuel in his hand, with the Baresman in his hand, with milk in his
hand, with the mortar for crushing the branches of the sacred Haoma in his
hand, is given happiness.465 Phoenix of Colophon (280 B.C.), cited in
Athenaeus, speaks of the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> ritual of the Magi and mentions the Baresman466
In the litany to the fire, the faithful are enjoined to feed the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> with fuel
that is dry and <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> exposed to the light,467 and Strabo tells us that the firepriests fed the sacred <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> with dry wood, fat, and oil; and he further adds
that some portions of the caul of the sacrificed animal were also placed on
it.468

abundance, knowledge, holiness, a ready tongue, comprehensive, great, and
imperishable wisdom, manly valour, watchfulness, an innate offspring worthy
to sit in the assembly and <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> for the renown of his <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> and village, town
and country, [224] and for the <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">glory</span> of his country, name and fame in this
world, as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as the shining, all-happy paradise of the righteous.469 Whoso
does not treat the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> displeases Ahura Mazda.470 Zarathushtra blesses

His work. When Mithra goes on his usual round in his golden chariot, Atar
drives behind him along with the other <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> personifications.472 Like <span class="t0 t3 t5 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t21 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Agni</span>
who knows the paths leading to the gods,473 Atar shows the most upright
path to those who lie not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> Mithra.474 When Angra Mainyu breaks into
the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> of righteousness, Atar in company with Vohu Manah opposes
the malice of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> Spirit.475 When Yima, reft of his senses through the

vanquishes him.477 472 Ytl0.127.

What causes grief to Atar. Angra Mainyu has created the inexpiable crime of
burning or cooking dead matter,478 and the Vendidad enjoins capital
punishment for those who commit it.479 We are informed that the Persians
considered it a mortal <span class="t2 t5 t8 t17 t18 t19 hoverable">sin</span> to defile <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> by blowing it with the mouth, or by
burning dead matter over it.480 The Achaemenian monarch Cambyses roused
the indignation of his countrymen when he burnt the corpse of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Amasis
at Sais.481 It is, therefore, a crime to <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> back <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> into a <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> in which a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> has died, <span class="t0 t1 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t28 t29 hoverable">within</span> nine nights in winter and a month in summer.482 Highly
meritorious is the deed of bringing to the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> altar the embers of a <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span>
desecrated by dead matter, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> shall be the doer's reward in the [225]

next world, when his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> has parted from his body483 Elaborate rules are
accordingly laid down for the purification of the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> defiled by the dead.484
There is no purification for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who carries a corpse to the fire.485 In the
<span class="t5 t16 t21 t24 t25 hoverable">case</span> of every pollution of the pure element. Atar is inexorable.

NAIRYOSANGHA
Mazda's celestial herald. Nairyosangha corresponds to the Vedic
Narashamsa, generally applied to <span class="t0 t3 t5 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t21 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Agni</span> as his epithet. He is expressly spoken
of as a Yazata,486 and is well-shaped.487 Like <span class="t0 t3 t5 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t21 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Agni</span> who is often <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the
messenger of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> between <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> and earth, Nairyosangha is the
messenger of Ahura Mazda.488 When the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Spirit</span> introduces disease and
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> in the world, Ahura Mazda dispatches him as his envoy to Airyaman to
come with his healing remedies.489 He is invoked along with Atar, for he is
Atar's associate. He is termed the offspring of sovereignty490 and as such he is
entitled to go in Mithra's chariot with Sraosha.491 He has his Fravashi.492

ARDVI SURA ANAHITA
The angel of waters. Ardvi Sura, who bears the standing epithet anâhita,
'undefiled,' is the name of a mythical river as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as that of the female
divinity of the waters. She resides in the starry regions.493 This deity of the
heavenly stream gets recognition of the Achaemenian kings, and is included
in the extremely short list of the Iranian divinities expressly mentioned in
their inscriptions.494 Classical writers <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of her sanctuaries founded at
Pasargadae, Ecbatana, Kangavar and other places.495 At a very early date her
cult migrates to distant countries and is there assimilated to Artemis,
Aphrodite, Athene-Minerva, Hera, Magna Mater, Ishtar, and Nanaia.496 She
overleaps the barriers [226] of Mount Alburz and gains her votaries in the
far-off lands of East and West, where occasionally her cult degenerates into
obscene rites. Herodotus who confuses her with Mithra says that her cult
came to Iran from the Semites of Assyria and Arabia.497 493 Yt5.85, 88, 132.
494 Art. Sus. a; Ham.
495 See Gray, op cit., p. 57, 58; Fox and Pemberton, op. cit., 34-39, 58, 66, 68,
79.
496 Gray, ib., p. 57.
497 Herod. 1.131.
She is celebrated in one of the longest Yashts and In 65th <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">chapter</span> of the

Yasna. She is described as the most courageous, strong, of noble origin,498
good, and most beneficient.499 Ahura Mazda has assigned to her the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of
guarding the creation, like a shepherd guarding his fiock.500 The eighth of
the year and the tenth <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> of the month are named after waters of Ardvi
Sura.501

Her image in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> found in the texts, corresponds with her statue in
stone. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">text</span> gives a fine descriptive image of the female deity. She is a
maiden of fair body, well-shaped, pure, courageous, tall, bright, beautiful,
and glorious. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Upon</span> her <span class="t1 t4 t9 t16 hoverable">head</span> she wears a golden crown studded with a
hundred stars and beautifully adorned, square golden earrings adorn her ears,
a golden necklace decorates her neck, she wears a golden mantle, she has
tightly girded her waist so that her beautiful breasts come out prominently,
her white arms graced by elegant bracelets are stouter than a horse, she
wears golden shoes, a rich garment of gold or of the skin of the beavers.502
Pliny says that a statue made of solid gold was <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> up in the temple of
Anaitis.503 We have already seen on the authority of Berosus that Artaxerxes
Mnemon (B.C. 404-358) introduced the <span class="t0 t5 t11 hoverable">worship</span> of the images of Anahita
among the Persians.504

503 Historia Naturalis, 33, 4 (24) 82f.

Idols (Persian) in ERE. 7. 151-155; cf. Cumont, Anâhita, in ERE. 1. 414, 415.
Ahura Mazda heads the list of the sacrificers who entreat her for various

boons. The Yasht dedicated to Ardvi Sura Anahita furnishes us with the
names of those who have sacrificed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> her and begged of her various
boons. The <span class="t8 t21 t27 hoverable">number</span> of her supplicants exceeds that of any other angel. Ahura
Mazda and Zarathushtra invoke her, with Haoma and Baresman, with spells
[227] and libations, whereas the majority of her other votaries severally offer
her a hundred stallions, a <span class="t6 hoverable">thousand</span> oxen, and ten <span class="t6 hoverable">thousand</span> sheep.
Haoshyangha, Yima, Thraetaona, Keresaspa, Kavi Usa, Haosravah, Tusa,
Vafra Navaza, Jamaspa, Ashavazdah, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> of Pourudakhshti, and
Ashavazdah and Thrita, the <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t25 t26 hoverable">sons</span> of Sayuzhdri, Vistauru, Yoishta, the
members of the Hvova and Naotara families, Vishtaspa, and Zairi-vairi are all
granted their diverse boons. These ask for sovereignty over all countries,
victory on the battlefield, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> to smite the adversaries in battle, to rout the
sorcerers and fairies, the fiends and the demons; they pray likewise for bodily
health, <span class="t7 t8 t12 hoverable">wisdom</span> to answer the riddles of heretics, and for riches and swift
horses.505 The boon that Ahura Mazda seeks is that he may win over
Zarathushtra to think after his reljgion, to <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> after his religion, and to act
after his religion; the prophet in turn begs of her that he may gain to his side
the mighty <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Vishtaspa as a patron to embrace his religion.506 The rulers
and chiefs invoke her that they may defeat their enemies and smite the
demons, sorcerers, and fairies, the warriors beg of her swift horses and bodily
health and glory, the priests and their disciples pray for knowledge, the
maids beseech her to grant them strong husbands.507 Ardvi Sura Anahita
bestows fruitfulness to women; she purifies the seeds of all males and the
wombs of all females for bearing. Shes, as a <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> bestower, gives easy
childbirth to all females, and gives them right and timely milk.508 Ardvi Sura
likewise grants boons <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> all, because it lies in her <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> to do so. The
sacrificing priest implores her to come down from the stars to the sacrificial
altar, and to grant riches, horses, chariots, swords, food, and plenty to
men.509 She gives health and increases flocks, possessions, and wealth.510

She reluses to concede the wicked persons their wishes. Azhi Dahaka
wickedly besought her to grant him a boon that he may make all the seven
zones empty of men, and the Turanian Franrasyan sought her favour to
secure the Glory, and the <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t25 t26 hoverable">sons</span> of Vaesaka implored her to grant that they
may smite the Aryan [228] nation by tens of thousands and myriads; Arejataspa and Vandaremainish craved for the defeat of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Vishtaspa, Zairivairi,
and the Aryan nation; but Ardvi Sura Anahita refused to grant the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> wishes
to these national foes of Iran.511

The offerings of libations. Ardvi Sura Anahita desires that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> invoke her
with libations and Haoma;512 these libations are to be drunk by the priest
who is <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> versed in religious lore, and not by any wicked and deformed
person.513 The faithful are to <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> libations <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> her at any <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> between
the rising and the setting of the sun. Those <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> to her after sunset do
not reach her; on the contrary, they go to the demons, who revel in these
misdirected offerings.514 We are informed that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who dedicates these
libations before sunrise or after sunset does no better deed than if he should
pour them down into the jaws of a venomous snake.515 Besides invoking
Ardvi Sura Anahita as the Yazata of water, the waters themselves are
collectively invoked to grant boons. Zarathushtra is asked to offer a libation
to the waters and to ask from them riches, power, and worthy offspring,516 a
happy and a joyful abode in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> and the next, accompanied by riches
and glory.517 The faithful pray that these waters may not be for those of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span>
thoughts, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> words, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> deeds, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> religion, neither for the tormentors
of their friends, neighbours, relatives, and priests.518 Nor may they be for
their evil-wishers,519 nor for thieves and robbers, murderers and sorcerers,
buriers of the dead, jealous and niggard, and heretics and wicked persons.520

Animal sacrifices to Anahita. Strabo relates the mode of sacrificing to the
waters. The sacrificial animal, we are told, is <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> to the bank of a river or a
lake; a ditch is formed into which the animal is killed. The pieces of meat are
then placed on myrtle or laurel, and holding tamarisk twigs in his hands, the
priest pours oil mixed with honey and milk on the ground and chants the
sacred formulas. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span> care is <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> that no drop [229] of blood falls into the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> while the animal is being immolated; nor must the mixture of oil,
honey, and milk be poured into water.521 This precaution is <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> lest the
waters be defiled.
521 Strabo, p.732.
Any defilement of the waters evokes Ardvi Sura's displeasure. It is sinful to
contaminate the waters. Such an act incurs <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> displeasure on the part of
the genius of waters. Those who wilfully <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> dead matter to the waters
become unclean for ever and ever.522 If a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> while walking or running,
riding or driving, happens to see a corpse ftoating in a river, he must enter
the river and go down into the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> ankle-deep, knee-deep, waist-deep, nay

even a man's <span class="t10 t16 hoverable">full</span> depth if need be, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> out the decaying <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span>
it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the dry ground exposed to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of the sun.523 Herodotus informs
us that the Persians do not make water, wash or bathe in a river.524

Ardvi Sura's chariot. Like some of the Yazatas, Ardvi Sura Anahita has a
chariot of her own, in which she drives forth in majesty. She holds the reins
in her own hands, and controls four <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> chargers who are all of white color,
of the same stock, and who smite the malice of all tyrants, demons, wicked
men, sorcerers, fairies, oppressors, as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as those who are wilfully blind and
wilfully deaf.525 The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">text</span> enables us to understand the allegorical statement
regarding the steeds that are yoked to her chariot, for we are told that the
four chargers of Ardvi Sura are the wind, the rain, the cloud, and the sleet;
and it was Ahura Mazda who made them for her.526

APAM NAPAT
His <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> and work. This Indo-Iranian divinity of waters seems very early
to have been eclipsed by Anahita, who remains the chief genius presiding
over waters in the cult. Apam Napat's Vedic counterpart has an aqueous as
<span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as an igneous nature. In the association of the Avestan Apam Napat with
the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> angel Nairyosangha, Spiegel sees traces of this secondary nature.527
Apam Napat literally means 'the offspring of waters,' and, like [230] the
Vedic genius, lives beneath the waters.528 He is the exalted <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">lord</span> and
sovereign, the shining one, and the swift-horsed.529 The waters are addressed
as females. Apam Napat in the Vedas is nourished by females.530 The Avestan
<span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of him as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">lord</span> of females.531 He is the most prompt to
respond when invoked,532 and co-operates with Vayu and distributes the

waters on earth.533 He furthers the riches of the countries and allays
misfortunes;534 and when the Kingly <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">Glory</span> escapes from the contest of Atar
and Azhi Dahaka to the sea Vourukasha it is Apam Napat who takes and
protects it.535 This Yazata is also credited with having made and shaped
men.536

AHURANI
Another <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> genius. A female Yazata, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> of no <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> importance, is
Ahurani, corresponding to the Vedic Varunani. She impersonates the
Ahurian waters.537 She is invoked in company with the sea Vourukasha and
other waters.538 The faithful devotee prays that if he has offended her in any
way, he is ready to expiate his <span class="t2 t5 t8 t17 t18 t19 hoverable">sin</span> by an <span class="t6 hoverable">offering</span> of the libations.539 She is
implored to descend in <span class="t0 t4 t5 t10 t22 t25 t28 hoverable">person</span> and grace the <span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span> with her presence and
be propitiated by it.540 She is likewise invited to come with her gifts of

health, prosperity, renown, the enlightenment of thoughts, words, and
deeds, and for the well-being of the soul.541 She is asked to give offspring
that will further the prosperity of the house, village, town, and country and
add to the renown of the country.542 Riches and glory, endurance and vigour
of body, a <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> and the shining, all-happy abode of the righteous are the
boons that the devout ask from her.543 The libations offered her are the most
excellent and the fairest, and are filtered by pious men.544 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Good</span> thoughts,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> words, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> deeds also serve as her libations.545 The libations
offered [231] to Ahurani cause joy to Ahura Mazda and the Amesha
Spentas.546

ZAM
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> deified. The Avestan term for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> is zam, from which the angel
Zam, or Zamyat, derives her name. Her personality is very insipid as
compared with Armaiti, who, as we have seen, has the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> under her care
and is, in fact, a more active guardian genius of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> than Zamyat. The

twenty eighth <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> of every month is sacred to Zamyat.547 The poet who
composed the Yasht in honour of Zamyat does not sing the <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">glory</span> of his
heroine, but occupies himself rather with a description of the mountains of
the world,548 and with the celebration of the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">Glory</span> that descends
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the Aryan race, symbolizing the greatness of the kings and the
consecrated piety of the sainted souls.549 Cyrus, says Xenophon, sacrificed
animals to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> as the Magians directed.550

<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XXIII
FRAVASHIS
The <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> double in man. The belief in a double of
the living and dead, animate or inanimate things,
which influences the objects or persons has prevailed
among different peoples from primitive times.
The Egyptians believed in man's <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span> double
whom they named Ka. The Ka, in the early period of
history, was supposed to belong only to the kings,
but later all <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t0 t1 t15 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">beings</span> were believed to possess it.
At the individual's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> he <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">went</span> to his Ka who
interceded for him with God, provided him with
<span class="t0 t14 t23 t24 hoverable">food</span> and looked after his welfare and protection.
In the Vedas the disembodied spirits are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the

[233] Plato taught that the sensual objects that
constitute the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> were but the imperfect copies or
reproductions of the quasi-personified Ideas that
constituted <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> reality. These transcendental Ideas
the contents of the creative <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> of God. This
supreme Deity creates the World-Soul, whom we
have equated with Spenta Mainyu in previous pages.
The Avestan <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">text</span> says the Fravashis stood ready for
help, when Spenta Mainyu created the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> with
Angra Mainyu.11 It is expressly said in a <span class="t28 hoverable">passage</span> that
the souls of the dead that have become the Fravashis
of the righteous owe their origin to Spenta Mainyu
and to Best Mind.12 Plato likewise says that the
World-Soul who bears the images of the Ideas,
fashioned the World-Body or the creatures after the
pattern of the Ideas.

Aristotle postulated a <span class="t0 t2 t5 t13 t14 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">second</span> independent principle
in addition to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> which moved the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and
carried on rational activity. This is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> which
constitutes the real essence of the individual. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> is
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> divided into body, soul, and spirit.
Philo distinguishes between the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> and the pneuma.
This pneuma which the Platonists, Aristotelians, and
Stoics of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> <span class="t8 t13 t21 hoverable">call</span> Nous, is the image of the deity
and constitutes the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of man. The
transcendent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> reveals himself through the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> 13 Yt13.17.
Ideas which are his thoughts and will, in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of
creative forces. As the Fravashis are not classed
among the Yazatas, so these <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> Ideas, says Philo,
are not angels, but are personified abstract ideas.

They manifest the energy of God. The Fravashis, as
we shall see anon, help Ahura Mazda in the
maintenance of the world, so these Ideas administer
the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of God. They impart reality to the creation.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Order</span> in the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> is preserved through them. The
Fravashis are not all of equal grade,13 so these Ideas
also are not of equal rank. The Fravashi represents
Ahura Mazda in man, so does the rational part of the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> stand for the type of the Logos. Plutarch speaks
of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> principles in man, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> and the soul. The
spirit, he says, is immortal, whereas the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> is not. In
the <span class="t6 t8 t10 t11 t16 t20 t21 t27 t28 hoverable">Book</span> of the <span class="t7 t8 t12 hoverable">Wisdom</span> of Solomon, Wisdom, an
emanation of God, selects from the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> Ideas those
that are fit for actualization and creates them.
[234]The dead, according to the early Roman belief,
were gathered to a group of spirits <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Di Manes.
The <span class="t0 hoverable">idea</span> of the Genius or the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> double
accompanying every <span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span> during his lifetime
arose in the period of the Republic. The Genius lived
with the <span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span> as <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> as he lived. At <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> he
lost his individuality and was gathered to the Di
Manes. Under Greek influence the <span class="t0 hoverable">idea</span> of
individuality developed. The <span class="t0 hoverable">idea</span> arose that the
Genius lived after death. Di Manes became
individualized protecting spirits instead of an
individualized group. During the lifetime of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> his
Genius was divine, after his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> the Genius
continued to live as one of the Manes. During
lifetime the Genius received <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> honours, after
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> his Manes received offerings as a God. The
Manes came down to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> and influenced the living
members of the families among whom they had lived.
They required propitiation.
Numenius of Apamea, writing in the <span class="t0 t2 t5 t13 t14 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">second</span> century, 14 Y16.7; 26.7, 11;

speaks of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> souls in man. The one is rational and 71.23; Yt22.39.
the other is irrational. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Alexandrian
theologian Origen (A.D. 185-254) speaks of the

He then
explains the relation between the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> and the spirit,
which exactly resembles that between a man's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span>
and his Fravashi in the Avestan texts. The Fravashi of
a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> serves as an ideal, which the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> has to
endeavour to realize. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> has to strive after,
imitate and emulate its Fravashi and ultimately
become one with it after death. The <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of
the souls of the dead that are the Fravashis of the
righteous.14 Origen's teachings help us to understand
the final identity of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> and the Fravashi. The
spirit, he says, is like <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> a <span class="t0 t1 t8 t11 t15 t21 t23 t24 hoverable">master</span> or director of the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> during lifetime. It applauds or accuses the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span>
for its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> or bad deed, and reminds it of its duty. If
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> behaves according to the dictates of the
spirit, it ultimately becomes the spirit, but if it revolts
from the spirit, it remains divided from the spirit,
when the bodily <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the <span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span> ends. The soul,
he says, is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> in the process of redemption. It
has <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> to put off its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> and become
spiritual.
What are the Fravashis. A class of <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span>
intelligences playing a most prominent part in the
Mazdayasnian pantheon, and receiving sacrifices and
adoration from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> of humanity, [235] is that
of the Fravashis, or guardian spirits and prototypes of
mankind in its purest creation. The Gathas do not
mention these beings, but the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> fravashi, or
fravarti, has a corresponding <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> in the Persian
name of the Median <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Phraortes (647 B.C.), and
also of the Median rebel mentioned in the Behistan
