inscription of Darius.15 The Yasna Haptanghaiti
mentions them for the first time.16 One of the longest
of the Yashts is dedicated to the Fravashis. The last
ten <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span> of the year, including the five intercalary
days, are specially <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> apart for their cult. Besides, the
nineteenth <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> of every month is consecrated to their
memory,17 and the first month of the Iranian calendar
receives its name after them.
The Fravashis, we have seen, resemble the Vedic
Pitrs, the Roman Manes, or the Platonic Ideas. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">True</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> it is that they share some common traits with
these and have striking resemblances to them, yet,
after all, they are not wholly the same as these. The
manifold <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of their cult offers a complicated and
stubborn problem to students of Iranian theology.
Primarily, the Fravashis constitute a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> of
homonyms of the earthly creations, and they have
lived as conscious <span class="t0 t1 t15 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">beings</span> in the empyrean with Ahura
Mazda from all eternity. The multifarious objects of
this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> are so many terrestrial duplicates of these
celestial originals. The Fravashis constitute the
internal essence of things, as opposed to the
contingent and accidental. Earthly creations are so
many imperfect copies of these types. They are the
manifestations of the energy of Ahura Mazda. When
nothing existed and Ahura Mazda lived in his sublime
singleness, he had the ideas, concepts of the material
and <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> which he contemplated
creating in time. We have recognized the projection
and manifestation of his will and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> and the
emanation of his creative <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> as Spenta Mainyu.
Origen, the Alexandrian philosopher, is right when
he says that the Logos represents the sum total of the
world-thoughts of God. Spenta Mainyu is the

embodiment of Ahura Mazda’s prototypal ideas
which are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Fravashis in the Avestan texts.
<span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Creation</span> is the materialization of these idealized
contents of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> and through him of Ahura
Mazda's mind. [236] These idealized contents of the
<span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> are the Fravashis and the creatures are
their feeble replicas. The Fravashis are not mere
abstractions of thought, but have objective existence
and <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> as <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> entities in heaven, like the
angels and the archangels, until they come down to
this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> voluntarily, as we may infer through later
statements in the Pahlavi texts. They migrate to this
world, and are immanent in the particular bodies that
come into being after their <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> images.
Everything that bears the hall-mark of belonging to
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> <span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> has its Fravashi. Every <span class="t24 t25 hoverable">object</span>
which has a name, common or proper, is endowed
with a Fravashi. Ahura Mazda, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> of all
existence, has his Fravashi, and so have the Amesha
Spentas and the Yazatas.18 Ahera Mazda's Fravashi is
the greatest, the best, the most beautiful, the most
courageous, the most wise, the most efficacious, the
most righteous.19 Even the sky, waters, earth, plants,
animals, and all objects of the kingdom of goodness,
are not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> their special Fravashis.20 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span>
beginning from the supreme godhead down to the
tiniest shrub growing in the wilderness, every <span class="t24 t25 hoverable">object</span>
has this <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> element implanted in it. It is only
Angra Mainyu and the demons, who are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> by
nature, that are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> it.
As Spenta Mainyu is not a personal being, he has no
Fravashi. On the other <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">hand</span> he seems to us to be the
Fravashi of Ahura Mazda.21 The ideal of Fravashi
implies imperfection in the <span class="t0 t4 t5 t10 t22 t25 t28 hoverable">person</span> to whom it

belongs. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> becomes perfect when his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> realizes Sanjana, p. 115, 116.

The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> evolving

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> out. Ahura Mazda, therefore, will realize his
Fravashi or Spenta Mainyu, when Angra Mainyu, the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> of imperfection, will perish and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> will
be a new world, a better world, a perfect world, an
ideal world.
[237] During the lifetime of the individual, his
Fravashi accompanies him to this earth. When a
child is <span class="t9 t24 hoverable">born</span> its Fravashi that has existed from all
eternity now comes down to this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> as the <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span> 22 Y26.4; 55.1.
double of the child's soul. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> is the ego proper,
the real I-ness. Every <span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> is accompanied
by its Fravashi.22
This Fravashi acts as a guardian spirit, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> friend,
and an unerring guide of the soul. Here is the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span>
voice of an infallible monitor who now advises and
now admonishes the soul, now applauds its action,
and now raises a voice of warning at a threatening
<span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> danger. This <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> agent in man, we may
infer, sits enthroned by the side of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> as an ideal
ever attracting the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> towards herself. This ideal
goal is the one towards which the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> should strive.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> living in the tabernacle of clay on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> with
the soul, and in the midst of the storms of passion
and vice, the Fravashi remains unaffected and
untouched, ever pure and ever sinless. From the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span>

the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> embarks on its unknown voyage to this
world, as we can judge from Zoroastrian teachings,
its Fravashi leads it, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> and night, to the path of
safety, and warns it of the rocks and shoals, storms
and cyclones. If it is off the track, the Fravashi hoists
the danger signal. The bark moves smoothly so <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span>
as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> follows the <span class="t5 t8 hoverable">wise</span> counsels of its guide. But
as soon as it revolts from the heavenly pilot, it
exposes the bark to danger at every turn. The vessel
now drifts along on the unmapped ocean <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> any
one at the helm to direct it to the right course, is
tossed on the roaring waves, is <span class="t1 t7 t12 t29 hoverable">left</span> to the mercy of
the changing wind, and is in danger of being
wrecked.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> alone is responsible for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span>
deeds done in this world, and it receives reward or
retribution in the next <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> according to its desert.
At the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> of the <span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span> when the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span>
advances to meet its fate, its guardian Fravashi returns
to the celestial realm, but lives now an individualized
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> as the Fravashi of a certain <span class="t0 t4 t5 t10 t22 t25 t28 hoverable">person</span> who has lived
his short span of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> on earth.

They are the strongest in moving onwards, the least 29 Yt13.64.
failing wielders of weapons, the invulnerable, the
shield-bearing, clad with iron helmets and weapons.28
Their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> and efficiency are simply inconceivable
and beyond description.29
Their work. Like the <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span> celestial beings, the
Fravashis are allotted their respective tasks in the
<span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> of Ahura Mazda. They are the ones who
stood ready for help to the godhead when the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
spirits first met to create the universe.30 It is through
them that Ahura Mazda maintains the sky and the
earth.31 Ahura Mazda expressly is stated as saying
that, had they not rendered him help, animals and
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> could not have continued to exist, because the
wicked Druj <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> have smitten them to death,
except for the guardianship of the Fravashis.32 The
waters flow, and the plants spring forth, and the
winds blow through their glory.33 Through their
radiance and <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">glory</span> females conceive offspring, and
have easy childbirth.34 Through them it is that Ahura
Mazda forms and develops the organs of child in the
womb of its mother, and protects it from death;35
moreover, patriotic <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t25 t26 hoverable">sons</span> destined to win distinction
are <span class="t9 t24 hoverable">born</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> women on their account.36 They first
gave movement to the waters that stood for a <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> flowing.37 The trees that stood <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span>
growing began to grow, and the stars and the moon
and the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">sun</span> that had stood motionless, owing to the
opposition of demons, received their movement
through them38 and have ever since gone along their
paths of progress owing to the influence of the
Fravashis.39 They protect the river Ardvi Sura
Anahita40 and watch over the sea Vourukasha and the
stars [239] Haptoiringa.41 They uphold the sky and
the waters, and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> and the cattle, and preserve

Fravashis <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> down <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> them from the <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span>
64 Y60.4.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> the very best of blessings. But those who
neglect or offend them are cursed; and their curse is 65 Yt13.18.
terrible indeed. It brings untold harm to the family.
Loving as the Fravashis are when propitiated, they
become dreadful when offended.60 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Yet</span> they never
harm until they are vexed.61 The wise, therefore,
propitiate them to gain their goodwill, and placate
them to allay their wrath. The householder prays that
they may walk satisfied in his house, that they may
not depart offended from his abode, but may leave
the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> in joy, carrying the <span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span> and prayer to
Ahura Mazda and the [241] Amesha Spentas.62 They
are implored to accept the offerings and be
propitiated thereby.63 They are asked to come with
riches as widespread as the earth, as vast as the rivers,
as <span class="t17 t29 hoverable">high</span> as the sun, in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to help the righteous and
harm the wicked.64 Those who honour them attain to
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> and greatness.65
Fravashis of the righteous ones of one's family,
clan, town, or country invoked individually. The
survivors of the dead commemorate the pious
memory of their departed ancestors. The members of
a family <span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> their elders, the citizens laud
their patriots and heroes, and the devout revere the
sacred memory of their sainted dead. The latter part
of the Yasht that is consecrated to the Fravashis treats
of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> personalities of Iran that have illumined
the pages of her history in various ways. The
Fravashis of the righteous <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as women of

all times and places who have worked for the
furtherance of righteousness, and who have
contributed to the welfare of mankind are constantly
commemorated.
Fravashis of the righteous ones of all ages and all
places invoked collectively. These celestial <span class="t0 t1 t15 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">beings</span>
are invoked in a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> by the faithful. The supplicant
generally winds up his prayers by announcing that he
sacrifices <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> the Fravashis of the righteous from the 66 Yt13.145.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of the first man, Gaya Maretan, up to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span>
of the advent of Saoshyant at the end of the world.66 67 Y24.5; 26.6; Vsp.
11.7; Yt13.21.

who are righteous among the Turanians, the national

70 Herod. 1. 132.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> taught to recognize the fellowship with the
<span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t0 t1 t15 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">beings</span> of all ages and all [242] places.
Herodotus attests that a Persian does not pray for
himself, but for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">whole</span> nation and his king.70
The faithful may infer from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> that runs
through the Zoroastrian scriptures that there are no
breaks in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> story of humanity. Each <span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span> is
a unit in the <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> line of countless generations
between the first and the last man. He realizes his
individuality in his own age and place. Each

generation is the product of the past and parent of
the future. It finds itself placed in the midst of
religious, social, economical, and political institutions
of the past and inherits the accumulated heritage of
the <span class="t7 t8 t12 hoverable">wisdom</span> and civilization of the collective
humanity that has lived before it. The past has made
the present in body, mind, and spirit; and the present
has to make the future physically, mentally, and
spiritually. No generation can live exclusively by
itself and for itself. To the past it owes a deep debt of
gratitude, to the future it is bound by parental duty. A
<span class="t5 t8 hoverable">wise</span> parent instinctively <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> of his
children, and no age can be regardless of the material
and <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> welfare of those that are to follow it in
time. Each age has its righteous persons by the
million, who further the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> progress. The
Fravashis of such only are commemorated. Those
that have willfully chosen to tread the path of
wickedness and hamper the onward march of
humanity towards perfection do not share this
honour, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t22 t23 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">highest</span> that collective humanity confers
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> its dutiful <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">children</span> of all ages and places. The
Pneuma, likewise, in the New Testament is not
associated with unrighteous persons.
Dual <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of the Zoroastrian ancestor-worship.
The commemoration of the Fravashis of the dead
represents but one phase of ancestor-worship. As we
have already seen, the <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> prototype of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> is
something apart from and above his soul. It is the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> that constitutes the individuality of his person,
and it is natural for the survivors to feel that they
should look to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> of the dead for the continuity
of communication with them. The sacrifices and
prayers offered to the Fravashis are primarily for
soliciting their help and favour. Those offered to the

soul of the dead on the anniversaries soon <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> a
vicarious <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> and rest on the central <span class="t0 hoverable">idea</span> that the
performance of rites by the descendants enables the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> of the dead to progress from a lower to a <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in the next world. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> man's [243] Fravashi
and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> both are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> to claim respectively their
commemoration from the relatives of the departed
one. These <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> distinct forms of ancestor-worshipthe one of invoking the Fravashis of the dead for the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> of the living, and the other of sacrificing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span>
the souls with the <span class="t0 t10 t11 t17 t25 t28 t29 hoverable">desire</span> of contributing to their
betterment in the next world-often overlap each
other. The intermingling of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> becomes so
complete that the souls and not the Fravashis are
supposed to come down to the rituals even on the
<span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span> originally consecrated to the Fravashis.

<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XXIV
PERSONIFIED ABSTRACTIONS
The infinity of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> and the immensity of space
personified. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> and Space seem to have been the
alternative answers to the early gropings of the
primitive Iranian thinkers to <span class="t5 t14 t15 t24 t27 hoverable">find</span> some solution for
the problem of the origin of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> in the universe;
and these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> elements, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> and Space, are
incorporated in the Zoroastrian theology of Later
Avesta after being shorn of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> assigned to
them in the pre-Zoroastrian period. In the extant
Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> they hardly have any individuality.
They are barren concepts sharing invocation along
with the celestial <span class="t0 t1 t15 t22 t25 t29 hoverable">beings</span> and sanctified objects. The
later works, however, <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of sects flourishing as
late as the Sasanian period and even much later, who

held these concepts as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t22 t23 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">highest</span> categories in
religious <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> and drew the names of their sects
from them.
Zrvan Akarana. This genius of Boundless Time, like
several abstract ideas which are in course of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span>
personified and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> are not classified among the
Yazatas, is not listed as an angel. He is often invoked
by name in company with Space and Vayu, the
genius of wind.1 He has made the path which the
righteous or the wicked <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> has to traverse,2 and the
plants grow in the manner he has ordained according
to the will of Ahura Mazda and the archangels.3

BAGHAS
The divinities. One of the names for divinity in
general is Bagha, literally <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> 'dispenser.' We
have seen that its history goes far back to the IndoEuropean period. In the Rig Veda, Bhaga is one of the
Adityas, and one hymn is dedicated to him. Unlike

the term Yazata, which retains its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> as a <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span>
appellation throughout the history of Zoroastrianism, Dk. SBE., vol. 37, bk.

<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XXVI

Notes:

PRAYERS AND RITUALS
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of the Younger Avestan prayers. The
Younger Avestan propounds a ritualistic religion.1
The <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> do not contain short or <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> continuous
compositions that may be classed as prayers which
can help <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> to give expression to the various
feelings, moods, desires, and aspirations that agitate

1. For rituals see Modi,
The Religious Ceremonies
and Customs of the Parsis;
Pavri. 'Ancient
Ceremonies' in Iranian
Studies, p. 194-229,

the deepest depth of his <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">heart</span> and the innermost
Bombay. 1927; Haug,
recesses of his mind, beget emotional exaltation and Essays on the Parsis,
devotional fervour in him, and inspire him to strive (3rd. ed.) p. 393-409.
after an ideal life. only some scattered sentences and
short passages, occurring at rare intervals, can be
collected from the mass of the liturgical <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> to serve
such a purpose. Ahura Mazda, Amesha Spentas,
Yazatas, Fravashis, souls of the righteous <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> and
women of all times, celestial and terrestrial beings,
sun, moon, stars, sky, fire, wind, earth, water, rain,
time, space, trees, mountains, rivers, places, fields,
the season festivals, years, months, days, periods of
the day, religion, customs, spells, texts, chapters,
verses, metres, virtues, qualities, thoughts, words,
deeds, intellect, self, priests, warriors, agriculturists,
artisans, laymen, teachers, pupils, ritual implements
and various other objects are enumerated by name
with or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> their attributes and functions, and
receive praise and homage. They are all alike
commemorated with the common <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> yazamaide,
'we worship,' in innumerable passages that <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t11 t12 t19 t22 hoverable">pass</span> as
insipid, laudatory prayers.
Yasna Haptanghaiti or the Yasna of Seven Chapters,
the earliest of prose compositions, made in the
Gathic dialect, in the Younger Avestan period,
contains more passages that can be termed proper
prayers than any other <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">text</span> in the Avestan literature.
It is significant to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">note</span> that the supplicants who pray
for several boons ask them from Haoma, Ardvi Sura
and her waters, Fire, Mithra, and Sraosha rather than
from Ahura Mazda himself.
[249] We have collected references to such passages
as can be termed prayers and classified them under
the headings: Supplicatory, Confessional,

Devotional, Benedictory, Imprecatory, and
Exorcising prayers. We shall now turn to these.
Supplicatory prayers. The faithful pray <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> the
Amesha Spentas and ask them to extend their
protection, as they say they do not see others than
the archangels who can <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> them under their
protection.2 The Yazatas are asked to grant
something greater and better and nobler than what
their supplicant asks.3 Haoma is asked to keep his
votaries far from harm,4 and give them
foreknowledge of thieves and murderers and wolves
for their safety.5 It is prayed that Sraosha and Ashi
may dwell in the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> in which Haoma is the
honoured guest and that Ashi may give joy there.6
Haoma is implored to bestow <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> his praisers the
healing remedies and victory over their enemies.7 He
is further asked to give bodily health and <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> life,8
courage and victory9 that the righteous may be the
courageous smiters of falsehood and malice.10 In the
end, the divinity of the sacrificial plant is asked to
give the shining, all happy abode of the righteous.11
Mithra is besought to give swiftness to the teams of
his worshippers, strength to their own bodies so that
they may watch successfully their enemies and smite
them,12 and also the demons and sorcerers and fairies
and those that are seeingly blind and hearingly
deaf.13 Those that have not lied <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> the angel of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> ask him to <span class="t1 t8 hoverable">free</span> them from distress and to give
them riches and strength, victory and happiness,
name and fame14 and joy.15 Sraosha is asked by his
invokers to grant strength to their horses and
soundness of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and strength to themselves, so
that they may be able to defeat the jealous and
inimical.16 He is asked to protect them in both the
worlds from the onslaughts of the demons of wrath

Priestly functionaries who conducted the sacrificial
ceremonies. The priestly hierarchy that was firmly
established during this period was headed by the
<span class="t17 t29 hoverable">high</span> priest, who was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Zarathushtrotema. He is
invoked by this name.77 The Rig Veda speaks of
about sixteen priests that performed ceremonies and
we have in the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> eight different
functionaries who were employed in the performance
of the Yasna ceremoNy These are zaotar, 'sacrificer,'
hâvanân, 'the pounder of Haoma,' âtravakhsh, 'tender
of the fire,' fraberetar, 'carrier of things,' âberetar,
'bringer of things,' âsnâtar, 'cleanser,' raethwishkara,
'auxiliary priest,' and sraoshâvarez, 'master of rituals.'78

Magi placed the consecrated <span class="t6 t20 hoverable">flesh</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the tenderest

by the Magi when he stood praying before the fire.84
These are the baresman twigs employed in varying
numbers in different ceremonies by the Zoroastrian
priests. They correspond to the Vedic barhis, the
carpet of straw <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> which the heavenly lords sat
when they attended the sacrifices.85 Some of the
minor ceremonies among both peoples resemble one
another and same corresponding terms are employed
for many ceremonial utensils, implements, and
articles of offerings.86
Animal sacrifices. Meat was a principal article of diet
among the Iranians and it was, likewise, <span class="t0 t12 hoverable">used</span> in
sacred feasts and festivals, or in funeral repasts. We
learn from the Denkard that the Pazag Nask dealt with
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> in which an animal was to be slaughtered
according to the religious rites.87 The Nirangisan, has

Angra Mainyu.

of Aristoxenus (about 320 B.C.), that the Persians

Sovereign of Evil, bereft of power, will bow to his
final fate and flee,41 and will hide himself forever in
the bowels of the earth.
DAEVAS
The Demons. The daevas, or demons, are of both
sexes, as are their heavenly counterparts. Over
against the vispe Yazata, or 'all angels,' stand in sharp
contradistinction the vispe Daeva, 'all demons.'42 The
greatest of all the demons is Angra Mainyu,43 who
has created these fiends in opposition to the [262]
Yazatas. The archangelic host of the Amesha
Spentas, and some of the angel band of Yazatas have
each a Daeva as a special adversary engaged in
thwarting the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> will. Plutarch states that when
Oromazdes created the six archangels, Areimanios
counter-created an equal <span class="t8 t21 t27 hoverable">number</span> of fiends.44 The
arrangement, however, is perfunctory, if we examine
the Younger Avestan text. The personality of the
majority of these demons is not sharply defined, and
the <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of their activities, as found in the Later
Avestan texts, is very vague and meagre. Some are
mentioned simply by name, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> any <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of
their function being added; it is only through the
help of the Pahlavi literature that we can get a more
definite <span class="t0 hoverable">idea</span> of their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in the infernal group. Not
only are the wicked spirits spoken of as the Daevas,
but also the nomadic hordes of Gilan and
Mazanderan, realms designated as Mazainya in the
Avesta, that constantly burst with their infidel hordes
of invaders into the settlements of the faithful,
menacing their properties, devastating their fields,

and carrying away their flocks, are branded as
Daevas.45 The wicked sodomite is equally a daeva,
and a worshipper of daevas, as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as a paramour of
daevas; he is a daeva during life, and remains a daeva
after death.46 All moral wrongs and <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> obstacles
are personified and catalogued in this scheme of
demonology. To every disease is assigned its own
demon as having been the cause of the malady. The
germs of disease and death, of plague and pestilence,
are spoken of metaphorically as Daevas. The <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Fire</span> of
Ahura Mazda serves to kill such Daevas by thousands
wherever the scent of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">holy</span> flame may spread.47 It
is said that if the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">sun</span> were not to rise, and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> should not curb their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> to do harm under
the cover of darkness, the Daevas <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> kill all living
beings.48 In connection with such ideas of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span>
of evil, it may be understood that the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span>
teach that the ground wherein are interred the
corpses of the dead is infested with myriads of the
demons, who feed and revel on the spot as a
consequence, for such a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> is their favourite
haunt.49 Even the dropping of nails and hair on the
ground is an act of [263] uncleanness that is
equivalent to <span class="t6 hoverable">offering</span> a <span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span> to the demons, as
spirits of pollution. Such a careless act of uncleanness
results in the production of demoniacal foes to health
and purity such as lice and moths, which are equally
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the daevas.50 The northern regions are peopled
with the demons.51 They are evil, bereft of good, illbehaved, evil-doing, worst liars, most loathsome, and
most wicked.52
The <span class="t8 t21 t27 hoverable">number</span> of the demons is said to be legion, even
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> mention only about fortyfive more explicitly by name. As in other cases of the
fiendish crew of hell, many of these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> powers have

no story in particular to tell, but we shall deal with
the more important ones in the sections that
immediately follow.
The <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of the demons. The demons have all been
allotted their special provinces of <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> in both the

The Daeva-worshippers. In opposition to the faithful
who are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Mazdayasnians, or the worshippers of
Mazda, all unbelievers and wicked persons are styled
the Daevayasnians, that is, as being worshippers of
the demons. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> worlds of the righteous and the
wicked are rent asunder. The barrier between them
cannot be broken. Mazda extends his helping <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">hand</span>
to the righteous, but leaves the wicked to themselves.
Nay he hates them.
As the dregvant, or the wicked one, stands in

75. Vd7.36-40.

antithesis to the ashavan, the righteous one, in the
sphere of morals, so the Daevayasnian, or worshipper 76. Yt5.94, 95; Nr.68.
of demons, stands in contradistinction to the faithful
Mazdayasnian in the matter of belief. Both words,
dregvant and daevayasna, are Zoroastrian synonyms
also of heretic. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of a Daevayasnian is not of
equal value with that of a Mazdayasnian; this is
shown in the Avesta by the <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> that the new surgeon
who intends practising among the Mazdaworshippers must first prove his skill on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> of the
[265] Daeva-worshippers; and if his operations are
successful he may then be given permission to
practise among the faithful, but if his tests prove fatal
he is to be disqualified forever.75 In regard to acts of
worship, moreover, those misguided sacrificers who
<span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> libations <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> Ardvi Sura after sunset are
classed among the worshippers of the Daevas, for the
libations <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> after the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">sun</span> has <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> reach the
demons.76
Zoroastrianism is anti-daeva, or against the
demons. In the hymn of the Confession of <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">Faith</span> that
the faithful recites from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> when he as a child is
invested with the sacred cord [kusti], and which he
thereafter repeats throughout his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> at the opening
of each daily prayer, he proclaims himself a
worshipper of Mazda and a foe to the demons.77 In 77. Y12.1.
this antagonistic attitude to all that is evil, he abjures
everything relating to the demons and all that may 78. Y12.4-6.
accrue from them, exactly as the prophet
Zarathushtra did.78 One of the Nasks, or books of the
Avesta, moreover, derives its name from this very
expression and is called, accordingly, the Vendidad,
more correctly 'Vidaeva-dâta,' or 'law against the
demons.'

AKA MANAH
The demon of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> Mind. Angra Mainyu has created
Aka Manah, or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> Mind, as a counterpoise to the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Good</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Mind</span> of Vohu Manah. The fiend occupies,
after his father, Angra Mainyu, the <span class="t0 t2 t5 t13 t14 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">second</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span>
among the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">whole</span> host of demons. In spite of this, he
figures very rarely in the Younger Avesta and we do
not hear so much of his activity as in the Pahlavi
works. Aka Manah, in the scene of the temptation of
the prophet, joins in the stratagem of the demon Buiti 79. Vd19.4.
to assail Zarathushtra, and as an impersonation of the
baser side of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> he practises his wiles 80. DRUJ
The embodiment of wickedness. In his inscriptions,
Darius concentrates all <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> in Drauga or Lie, as the
Gathas did in Druj. Druj is feminine in gender and,
like other demons, is a spirit.82 This <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> genius of
Wickedness of the Gathic period preserves her
original traits in the Yasna and Yasht literature, but it
seems, if we judge rightly, that she gradually
undergoes a transformation in the Vendidad. The
Gathic prayer of the faithful to enable the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span>

Other Drujes. The Gathas knew but one Druj, the
one that <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> in opposItion to Asha. In the Later
Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> Druj [267] becomes a class designation
of minor female demons. These fiends are styled the
Drujes, and Yt2.11 speaks of vispe druj, 'all drujes,' in
the same strain as vispe Yazata, 'all Yazatas,' and vispe
daeva, 'all demons.' From the sacred <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> we learn
that there are drujes who come openly, and there are
those that come in secret, and again there are those
that defile by mere contact.95-96 The term druj itself is
loosely applied likewise to other demons and wicked

mountain Arezura in the northern region, but at the 108. Vd7.78, 79.
same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> her presence is everywhere manifest on
109. Vd19.12, 13.
this earth.103 Her chief function is to spread
defilement and decay in the world. Immediately after
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> of an individual, when the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> leaves the

body and decomposition sets in, the Druj Nasu
comes [268] flying from the north in the shape of a

She is expelled, however, when a dog or the corpseeating birds have gazed at the dead body,105 and
when certain pious formulas have been recited. In
reply to the inquiry how one may best drive away the
Druj Nasu that rushes from the dead and defiles the
living, Ahura Mazda bids the faithful to recite the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">holy</span> spells.106 When the purifactory rites have been
performed and the sacred formulas uttered <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the
one defiled by the dead, the Druj Nasu becomes
weaker weaker and weaker and flees from one part of
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> to the other, until finally she vanishes
towards the northern regions.107 Whoso offers for
consecration <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> that has in any <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> been defiled
by the dead, or proffers libations after the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">sun</span> has set,
even <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> intent, feeds the Druj and
thereby hinders the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of righteousness.108 The
religion of Mazda, as a <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> paramount, dispels best
this Druj of defilement.109
The barrier between the ashavans and dregvants is
still impassable. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> the concept Druj as the
genius of wickedness has undergone a change in the
Later Avesta, the adjectival form, dregvant, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span>

dregvant.110 The term is applied to Dahaka,111
Arejataspa,111a to all Daevayasnians, and to all of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span>
thoughts, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> words, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> deeds. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> of

Along with the employment of this term, the

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> 'one who destroys Asha, Righteousness,' has

121. Yt15.51.

dead, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> being well-versed in the Zoroastrian
rules of cleanness, is also an ashemaogha. Such a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span>
retards the progress of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> by his false deed.116
If a priest of this character were to give a
benediction, his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> of blessing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> go no
further than his lips.117 Whoso gives the consecrated
<span class="t0 t14 t23 t24 hoverable">food</span> to a sinner of that type brings calamity to his
own country.118 He himself is a heretic, for he does
not acknowledge any temporal or <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> master.119
Ahura Mazda accordingly advises Zarathushtra to

<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> him to utter his sacred names when in danger of

INDRA

A <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">god</span> in the Vedas, a demon in the Avesta. This
demon furnishes us with an instance of degrading one
of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Indian divinities to the rank of a demon
in the Iranian theology. He is mentioned in the
Boghaz-keui tablets, recently discovered in Asia
Minor, that are supposed to date from about 1400
122. Vd19.43.
B.C. His name occurs but twice in the extant Avestan
text: he is mentioned as one of the ribald crew routed
123. Vd10.9.
by Zarathushtra;122 and in another <span class="t28 hoverable">passage</span> a spell
mentioning him by name is recited to drive away the
demons.123 These <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> Avestan passages, however, do
not give us an inkling of the function of this fiend. In
the Pahlavi period he assumes the part of Asha
Vahishta's adversary.
SAURVA
Foe to the archangel Khshathra Vairya. The Indian
counterpart of the demon Sauvra is Sharva. The
Avestan texts, [270] which make <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> mentions of the
name of this demon, do not give us his life-story.124 In 124. Vd10.9; 19.43.
the diabolical host he is the adversary of the
archangel Khshathra Vairya, through whom shall be
lished the Kingdom of Ahura Mazda.
TAROMAITI
She thwarts devotion. This feminine demoniacal
impersonation of heresy and counterpart of Spenta
Armaiti is to be smitten by the recital of the sacred 125. Yt3.8, 11, 15.
formulas; she will flee away as soon as the Airyaman
126. Y60.5.
Ishya prayer is uttered.125 The faithful, in
consequence, pray that the genius of devotion may
dispel this demoness from their houses.126
NAONGHAITHYA

A demon of incipient personality. Naonghaithya
corresponds to the Vedic Nasatya, the epithet of the
heavenly Ashvins, and is likewise mentioned in the
Boghas-keui tablets, but is classed in the Zoroastrian
<span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> among the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> powers. The demon is twice
mentioned in the Avestan texts,127 but the passages in 127. Vd10.9; 19.43.
question shed no real <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> on the sphere of his
activity. During the Pahlavi period, however (and the
same may reasonably be presumed for the Avesta),
Naonghaithya, or Naunghas, as he is then called, is
seen working in antagonism to Spenta Armaiti.

The adversaries of Haurvatat and Ameretat. The
names of the dual demons Taurvi and Zairicha
personify, in later <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> at least, fever and thirst. They
occur <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> and are mentioned in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> places in
128. Vd10.9; 19.43.
the Younger Avesta,128 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> any special
description of their work. They are in the Pahlavi
<span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> depicted as the adversaries of the dual divinities
Haurvatat and Ameretat, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> active mission in the

ASTOVIDHOTU
The fiend of death. As indicated etymologically by
the root of the Avestan <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> maretan and mashya,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> is mortal. This mortality applies to his material
frame only. At <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> he dies in the flesh, but he lives
forever in the spirit. Astovidhotu, literally 'the bonedivider,' who impersonates death, awaits all. When a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> is burnt by <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> or drowned in water, it is
Astovidhotu who binds his breath and hastens him to

The death-toll which Astovidhotu exacts from the

BUSHYANSTA
Sloth personified. Idleness and inactivity tend to
strengthen the Kingdom of Evil. The demoness
Bushyansta, or sloth personified, literally
'procrastination,' is commissioned by Angra Mainyu
to inculcate the habit of sleep and procrastination
among mankind. She, the long-handed, as she is
called,139 lulls the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">whole</span> living <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> to inordinate
slumber. Timely sleep as such is of Ahura Mazda's
making and it receives even adoratiuon;140 but
Bushyansta, the inordinate, tempts the idle to be
unduly <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> in bed,141 and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> prevents the practice
of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> thoughts, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> words, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> deeds.142 At
dawn the cock Parodarsh, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> name literally
means 'one who sees ahead,' flapping his wings and
crowing aloud, warns slumbering humanity of the
stratagem of Bushyansta, and informs the faithful that
it is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to wake up and proceed to work.143 When
Mithra comes in his chariot, he puts the fiend to
flight;144 the Aryan <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">Glory</span> and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">holy</span> spells join
<span class="t20 hoverable">hands</span> as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> to render powerless this demoness of
laziness.145

APAOSHA
The demon of drought. The Yasht dedicated to
Tishtrya gives a picturesque <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of the battle

153-154. Yt8.13-19.

waged between the angel of rain and the demon of
drought. Tishtrya assumes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> different forms for
ten nights each. For the first ten nights he takes the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of a youth of fifteen <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> of age, for the <span class="t0 t2 t5 t13 t14 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">second</span>
ten nights he moves along in the shape of a goldenhorned bull, and the last ten nights in the shape of a
beautiful white horse, with golden ears and a golden
caparison, seeking libations and offerings, so that he
may bestow <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> his supplicants oxen, children, and
horses.153-154 When he proceeds to his <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of
pouring [274] down <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> on the earth, he is
confronted by demon Apaosha, who has assumed the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of a dark horse.155 A severe struggle ensues,
lasting for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> nights. Apaosha
comes off first as the victor in the combat and puts
the genius of rain to flight.156 Tishtrya bemoans his
lot and complains before Ahura Mazda that mankind
had neglected to <span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> him. If only he were
strengthened by their offerings, he <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> carry with
himself on the battlefield the vigour of ten horses,
ten camels, ten bulls, ten mountains, and ten rivers.157
Ahura Mazda, thereupon, offers a <span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span> to the
unfortunate angel and gives him the desired
strength.158 Girt with this added power, Tishtrya now
boldly marches against his rival, and engages in
combat with him, until, to the joy of the waters, and
plants, and lands, and fields, Tishtrya comes out
triumphant and Apaosha is defeated.159

VAYU
A collaborator of Astovidhotu. We have already

and is impersonated by a demon of the same name.

The Yatus, or sorcerers, usually associate with this
class of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> beings.184 The faithful declare in the
Confession of the <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">Faith</span> that they abjure the sorcerers
and those addicted to the sorcerers.185 Ahura Mazda's
names, and the most efficacious prayers Ahuna
Vairya, Ashem Vohu, Yenghe Hatam, and Airyaman
Ishya rout the sorcerers.186 The recital of the hymn to
Sraosha frightens and forces them to flee.187 The
prayers and sacrifices <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> the fire,188 the sun,189
Vayu,190 Tishtrya,191 Haoma,192 enable the faithful to
disable the sorcerers. The Fravashi of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Haosrava
is invoked to rout them.193 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Takhma Urupi
subdued them.194 They failed in their attempts to
compass the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> of Zarathushtra.195 The West has
derived the term magic from Magi, the priestly class
of the <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> [277] Persians. The Zoroastrian <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span>
of all periods, however, detest sorcery as an <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> of Angra Mainyu.196 The verdict of the
Greek writers regarding this is unanimous. Dino
states in his Persica that the Magi abhorred divination
by magic, and Sotion on the authority of Aristotle
and Dino says that sorcery was unknown among the
Magi.197
