<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XXXIV
ZOROASTRIANISM AS TAUGHT BY THE PAHLAVI <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">WORKS</span>
Ardashir, a Magus, rejuvenates Zoroastrianism. With the fall of the
Achaeraenian empire were extinguished the last sparks of the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> of racial
jealousy between the Medes and Persians. Common hardships and common
sorrows had obliterated all traces of bitter feeling for one another. The
Seleucid period and the five centuries of Parthian rule, as another <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
empire in Iran, served all the more to make them now one compact
homogeneous people, thinking with one mind, feeling with one heart, and
acting with one aim. As already pointed out, the Magi did not receive
recognition in the Avesta. It is not so in the Pahlavi period. The Avestan
term athravan remains during this era as a class designation alone, but
magopat, which later becomes mobad, is <span class="t0 t12 hoverable">used</span> throughout the Pahlavi
literature, equally as a class designation for priesthood and as a personal title
of a priest to distinguish him from a layman. Significant in this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> becomes
the <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> that although the Persians of old had defeated the Medes and their
sacerdotal caste, the Magi, it was now a Magus again that was destined to
revive the national <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">glory</span> of Iran, and restore their <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> faith. The Kingly
<span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">Glory</span> of Iran clave to a hero of the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> of Sasan in the province of Fars,1
who was alike priest and king.2 Ardashir was his name, and the Iranian <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span>
rang with the praises of this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> of Babak, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> fame is writ large in the
history of Zoroastrianism. 1. Karname-i-Artakhshir-i Papakan, 3. 10-18.
2. Agathias, 2.26. This founder of the Sasanian dynasty won his spurs in. the
battle against Ardavan, the last of the Parthian kings, in a.d. 224. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">People</span>
turned their eager <span class="t2 t6 t19 t20 t26 t29 hoverable">eyes</span> to him for the national emancipation from the heavy
yoke of the foreigners. His was the task of rebuilding the shattered fragments
of the <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> Persian empire <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the ruins of the Parthian empire. When
he succeeded in [319] consolidating the various states of Iran into one
mighty commonwealth under his sceptre, he proceeded vigorously
thereupon to establish a polity in conformity with the teachings of Zoroaster
which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> unite his empire as Church and State. It was through Ardashir
that Zoroastrianism became once more enthroned as the creed paramount,

after a lapse of fully five centuries, and remained so for four centuries under
the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">House</span> of Sasan. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> himself, being of sacerdotal caste, strongly
upheld the doctrine of the unity of the Church and the State. The two, he
said, are like brother and sister; neither can flourish <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> the other.3 They
both are interwoven <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">together</span> like <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> pieces of brocade.4 The Denkard,
which is the greatest of the Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> of this period, upholds the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span>
right of kings and states if the temporal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of the glorious <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> Jamshed
had been blended with the <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of the supreme priest Zoroaster,
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Spirit</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> have lain low <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> ere this, and the Kingdom of
Righteousness <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> have been established on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> once and forever.5 Both
of these powers will be concentrated in the final saviour, who is to enable
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> to gain the final victory over the Kingdom of Wickedness.6 3. Masudi,
tr. Barbier de Meynard, 2. 162.
4. ShN. 6.286.
5. Dk., vol. 3, p. 175, 176.
6. Ib., p. 176. Ardeshir, as a pontiff-king himself, commissioned his highpriest Tansar to collect the scattered Avestan <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> to prepare an
authorized compilation of the sacred texts.7 The enthusiasm evoked among
the faithful at the restoration of their lost scriptures presents a situation
seldom paralleled in history, and certainly never surpassed in the religious
development of Zoroastrianism.
7. Ib., vol. 9, p. 578. The revival of Zoroastrianism continues with
unabating zeal. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> inaugurated by the first of the royal <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">House</span>
of Sasan was zealously continued by descendants and notably by Shapur II,8
who <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> to completion with the help of his illustrious Dastur
and premier Adarbad Mahraspand.9 Mani's heresy was at its height during
this period, and Adarbad strove hard to restore the <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> that
was undermined by the misguided leader's heretical teachings. In <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to
prove the marvels of the faith, Adarbad is reported to have submitted himself
to the ordeal of the molten metal and to have [320] come out unscathed.10
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Shapur thereupon declared the work, as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> redacted, to be
authoritative, and he commanded that anything outside this canonical

collection should not be countenanced. Another source states that still
further steps were <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> to put the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> of the religion to the test. Several
pious mobads were convoked to attend at the temple of the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> Froba, and
there to consider the momentous question of deputing one of their <span class="t8 t21 t27 hoverable">number</span>
to visit, in a vision, the <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> to <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> back from the angels
themselves a first-hand <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of matters <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> for the complete
restoration of the religion. Seven <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">holy</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> were first elected from the
assembly. Out of this <span class="t8 t21 t27 hoverable">number</span> Arda Viraf was selected as the most righteous
and saintly. After preliminary ceremonies this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">holy</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> entered into a trance
for seven <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span> and nights, during which he was transported in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> to the
other world. His <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> ascended into the realm of heaven, traversed the
<span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> regions, and after beholding paradise visited likewise the inferno.
Viraf described the experience of his visions and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> contributed to
rehabilitating the <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> in their historic religion.
8. A.D. 309-379.
9. Dk., vol. 9, p. 579.
10. SLS. 15. 16; Sg. 10. 70; Dk., SBE., vol. 47, bk. 7. 5. 5, p. 74, 75; AV. 1.
16. The Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> are <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> by many <span class="t20 hoverable">hands</span> in successive periods.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> the canon was declared closed by the edict of Shapur II, the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of
rendering the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> into Pahlavi with exegetic commentaries, and the
composition of original <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> in the court language, continued throughout
the Sasanian period, and even <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> after the downfall of the empire. Few if
any of the exegetical <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> of Zoroastrianism <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> during the Sasanian
period have survived the devastating <span class="t20 hoverable">hands</span> of the conquering hordes of the
Arabs, and almost all the important Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> that we possess today were
<span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> under the Abbasid Caliphs. The Persians in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> veins flowed the
kingly blue blood had helped the Abbasids in overthrowing the Umayyads,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> avenging themselves <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> their national foes, the Arabs. This greatly
elevated the position of the Zoroastrians at the royal court of Bagdad.
During this period it was that the composition of the Pahlavi treatises was
undertaken with renewed vigour. To the ninth century we owe much of the
Pahlavi literature that has come down to us. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> the Pahlavi literature
covers a period of about seven centuries, beginning [321] from the first

Sasanian ruler, Ardashir, or still earlier, and stretching downwards to the
times of the illustrious Caliph of the Abbasid dynasty, al-Ma'mun, or even
later. The invention of the modern Persian alphabet restricted the <span class="t1 hoverable">use</span> of
Pahlavi to the learned clerics, who continued to make some slight additions
to the Pahlavi literature up to the end of the eleventh century.11
11. West, Pahlavi Literature, in GIrPh. 2. 80. The Pahlavi literature has its
roots in the Avestan soil. The Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> allege that the Avestan Nasks
had perished, but the tradition transmitted orally from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> and the
fragments of the sacred <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> did not suffer the Avestan lore to die out
entirely. The extant Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> contain quotations from Avestan <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span>
that have not come down to us, and this may help to show that the later
writers either quoted from memory or that they had access to Avestan works,
since lost, when they wrote their Pahlavi treatises; or possibly it may serve to
prove both facts. Nay, some of the Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> seem to be wholly or in
part reproductions of some of the Avesta Nasks, and most scholars agree
with West that the Pahlavi Bundahishn is an epitome of the Avestan Damdad
Nask, that has since disappeared.12 This leads to the probable conclusion
that besides the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> archetype copies deposited in the royal treasuries at
Persepolis and Samarkand, there may have existed other copies of these
Nasks, in <span class="t10 t16 hoverable">full</span> or in part, in private possession or in the more notable firetemples. The internal evidence of some of the most important Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span>
show us that they preserve much of the material derived from Avestan
sources, which still existed in their days, but has been subsequently lost, and
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> make up for the loss of the original Avestan books to a considerable extent.
12. SBE., vol. 5. int. xxiv. The Pahlavi literature is the completion of the
Avestan works. The Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> explain, elaborate, and describe in detail
much of what is stated in brief in the original Avestan texts. This is the
inestimable value of the Pahlavi literature. A few examples may serve to
illustrate this statement. The Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> frequently mention 'the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> of
<span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">Long</span> Duration,' a period carved out from eternity as the age for the duration
of the present world, but give no idea, as far as the <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> have been
preserved, as to the length of this mighty aeon. It is to [322] the Pahlavi
books that we have to turn to ascertain the specific duration of this period,

for the millennial doctrine is recognized but not described in the Avestan
writings that we possess today. It is worked out in <span class="t10 t16 hoverable">full</span> detail in the Pahlavi
works. This <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> might even suggest that the <span class="t0 hoverable">idea</span> originated with the
Pahlavists but such is not the case, for we know from Plutarch that
Theopompus, who flourished in the fourth century B.C., or a little before the
close of the Avestan period, was <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> acquainted with this doctrine of the
Zoroastrians, and wrote about it in his works.13 13. Is. et Os. 47. The Later
Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of the future judgment, the rising of the dead, the
renovation, but it is the Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> that acquaint us with the method of
the administration of justice in the heavenly tribunal and the final restoration
of the universe.
The <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> of the Younger Avesta, as noted above, <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of different heavens
and hells, but the Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> locate them, and give a detailed description
of the area they cover, the boundaries that divide them from one another,
and the conditions that prevail in them.
The trend of the religious <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> of the Pahlavi period. We have
described the change from the Gathic to the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> as a retrograde
step; the Pahlavi <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> are still farther removed from the Gathas. The Gathic
ideal lingers and continues to be admired, but it has ceased to influence. It
evokes praise from the Pahlavi writers, but fails to inspire them with its
abstract tone. Zoroaster is a historical personage in the Gathas. In the Later
Avesta he becomes super-human; but in the Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> his personality is
enshrouded by miracles, and he is transformed into a myth. The fascination
for marvels in religion is an unmistakable sign of the times. Christian
bishops, who, as we shall see in the further stage of our inquiry, carried on
inveterate disputes with the Zoroastrian clergy in Persia, based the claim of
the greatness of their own religion on miracles. Perhaps in consequence the
life-story of Zoroaster, as told by the writers of the Pahlavi period, is
similarly stamped with the mark of the miraculous. The Gathas and the
Younger Avesta <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of the prophet's conferences with the Amshaspands,
or archangels, and his communing with them. The Pahlavi texts, as we have
seen, <span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">state</span> [323]that they came to the court of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Gushtasp as the envoys
of Ormazd, to give proof of the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> calling of the prophet. Moreover,
when Zoroaster met Vohuman, he actually saw the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and the <span class="t3 hoverable">face</span> of the
archangel, his size, and his garments, and in these celestial conferences with

the archangels the prophet was requested by each in turn to command
mankind to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> due care of the concrete <span class="t3 t5 t6 t7 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t28 t29 hoverable">thing</span> under the special charge of
each as an Amshaspand and not the abstract virtue that each impersonates.
Vohuman, for instance, as the genius of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> mind, did not emphasize the
faithful adherence to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> thoughts, but contented himself with reminding
the prophet to teach mankind to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> care of the cattle. Artavahisht, the
genius of righteousness, gave no command to Zaratusht to exhort <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> to
follow the path of righteousness, but taught him that the best <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> of
propitiating the heavenly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> was to propitiate his fire. Similarly the other
archangels in these celestial interviews did not hold up as the ideals the
virtues over which they presided, but they inculcated due preservation of
their respective earthly objects. A Pazend penitential prayer, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span>
authorship is attributed to Dastur Adarbad Mahraspand, the high-priest and
premier of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Shapur (309-379 a.d.), mentions the Amshaspands by name,
and exhorts the penitent to atone severally for the sins committed against
them. In every <span class="t5 t16 t21 t24 t25 hoverable">case</span> he addresses each archangel in turn and craves
forgiveness for any offence that may have been committed by ill-treating the
earthly <span class="t24 t25 hoverable">object</span> over which the genius presides. Offences against the abstract
virtues which the archangels impersonate are not meniiored in this treatise,14
and this <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> tends decidedly to show that phase of Zoroastrianism in which
abstract ideas were gradually losing in importance, and the concrete side of
the religion was coming out with greater prominence. 14. Pt. 8. This process
of materializing the original abstract concepts reaches its climax in the
eschatological notions of this period. The several heavens and hells, as also
the bridge of judgment that leads to them, are now completely materialized.
All the splendours of a royal court with its golden thrones, rich carpets, fine
cushions are transferred to paradise. On the other hand, all sorts of <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span>
tortures that man's ingenuity can devise prevail in hell. [324] Fifteen hundred
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> separated Zoroaster from the Sasanian period, and a thick veil began to
hide the pristine <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> religion from his followers.
The Sasanian Church became an arbiter of the <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> of Zoroaster. It was
through the Church that the religious teachings filtered into the populace.
During the period of her <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> influence, when the <span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">State</span> was practically
under her tutelage, the Church rendered a lasting service by her attempts to
reinvigorate the Mazdayasnian faith. She triumphed when she stood for the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of the religion of Mazda; but she failed when she descended to rigid

formalism, stifled independent inquiry, stigmatized honest doubt as
Ahrimanian, and sought to overrule original thinking by dogmatic assertions.
Religion defeats its own ends when it degenerates into dogmatic theology.
And it was not otherwise in Persia.
[325]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XXXV
THE ACTIVE PROPAGANDA OF THE <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">FAITH</span>
The Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> on proselytism. Zaratusht first preached his new religion
to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> of Iran where he was born; but Ormazd has commanded that
the excellent religion should be spread among all races of mankind
throughout the world.1 In their commentary on the oft-recurring Avestan
formula fravarâne, the Pahlavi versionists add an explanatory gloss that every
believer undertakes to proclaim the Zoroastrian religion of Ormazd to the
entire world. It is said that the act of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t22 t23 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">highest</span> merit that a non-believer
can perform in his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> is to his religion and embrace the Mazdayasnian
faith.2 The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Sasanian monarch, Shapur II, zealously worked for the
restoration and promulgation of the <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> among the unbelievers with the aid
of his illustrious Dastur Adarbad.3 The Denkard sanctions even the <span class="t1 hoverable">use</span> of
force for the conversion of the aliens.4 A Pahlavi treatise devoted mostly to
the Zoroastrian rituals attests the practice of admitting outsiders into the
Zoroastrian fold.5 Another Pahlavi tractate treating of the social and legal
practices of the Sasanians lays down that if a Christian slave embraces the
<span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> of his Zoroastrian master, he should be given freedom.

5. Aerpat. bk. 1. 4. 28, 29; 1. 5. 4.
6. Mâdigân-i Hazâr Dâdistân, ed. Modi, p. 1, Poona. 1901. An Armenian
<span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of the Zoroastrian propaganda. Elisaeus, bishop of the Amadunians
in the fifth century A.D., in his historical <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> states that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Yazdagard II
and his royal court resorted to both persuasion and force in their attempt to

subjects of the Persian <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> in Armenia, we are informed, were promised
<span class="t17 t29 hoverable">high</span> positions, court distinctions, royal favours, and the remission of the
taxes, if they accepted the national <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> of Iran. Mihr Narsih, the premier of
Yazdagard II (A.D. 438-457), in the proclamation to the Christian
population in Armenia that he issued at the royal command, exhorts them to
adopt the religion that their sovereign holds, and adds that those that do not
acknowledge the Mazdayasnian <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> are deaf and blind, and are misled by
Ahriman.8 Elisaeus informs us that this proselytizing movement on the part
of the Magi of Sasanian times was not confined to Armenia alone, but it
extended further to Georgia, Albania, and various other countries.9
7. The History of Vartan, p. 8, 9, 11, 31, 32, 35, London, 1830. 8. The History of
Vartan, p. 11,12.
9. Ib., p. 26. Judaism and Christianity penetrate into Persia as the
formidable rivals of the national faith. When the Zoroastrian Church was
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> engaged in promulgating the <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> of Zoroaster outside Persia, her
religious supremacy was challenged at home by Judaism, and more
aggressively by Christianity.10 Ardashir had established Zoroastrianism as the
<span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">state</span> religion of Persia, but there were in the empire colonies of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span>
following other religions. Iran had <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> ceased to be a religious unit, and the
vast <span class="t8 t21 t27 hoverable">number</span> of Jews, Christians, and others of divergent faiths and creeds
contributed towards disunion. Referring to the presence of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span>
professing different religions in his kingdom, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Hormizd IV once
remarked that his throne rested on four feet;11 and troublesome these outside
elements certainly proved to the sovereign occupying the throne. A fairly
tolerable latitude was conceded to these adherepts of the alien faiths, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span>
occasional persecutions of them were not unknown. These non-Zoroastrians
frequently occasioned heated polemics in which virulant criticism and

derisive terms were exchanged between the the Zoroastrian priests on the
one side and the prelates of the rival faiths on the other. Iranian <span class="t5 t11 hoverable">society</span> was
often convulsed with the storm of controversy. The alien faiths were branded
as the promptings of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> Spirit, and were declared to be teaching a vile
law, [327] opposed to the pure <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">law</span> of Mazda.12 The religions that most
struggled in this manner with the national <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> during the Sasanian period
were Judaism and Christianity, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> position in Persia we shall now discuss.

12. SLS. 6. 7. Judaism in Persia. Judea had come under the Persian rule at
the very early period. The Babylonian exile <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> the Jews into close
touch with the Persians in the sixth century B.C. We have already referred to
the <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> that the restoration of tbe temple at <span class="t2 t6 t26 hoverable">Jerusalem</span> was executed at the
royal command of the Persian kings Cyrus and Darius. The Jews had settled
in Persia in large numbers from very early times, and had planted their
colonies all over the country. They thrived peacefully and were given
privileges to manage their own civic affairs <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> molestation from the
state. Some of the members of the royal <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">house</span> had even married Jewish
princesses. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Yazdagard I, for example, had a Jewish consort.13 But in
general those who contracted matrimonial alliances with Jewish women were
disliked, and the Denkard inveighs in strong terms against the practice of
contracting such unions.14 In the course of time, the Persians and the
Israelites seem to have been sharply divided in religious matters.
Disputations on questions of belief must have been frequent. All of the
Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> denounce Judaism in unsparing terms. The writer of the
Denkard, for instance, avers that Judaism is not a <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> religion,15 and points
to Zohak, the most detested of men, as the originator of the Jewish
scriptures,16 branding elsewhere the Jewish books as utterances of the
demons.17 Seno, a Zoroastrian sage, is reported to have said, in his
admonitions to the kings of Persia, that the sovereign of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> ought to

keep aloof from the religion of the Jews, as bringing devastation to the
world.18 The progress of the Jewish belief be arrested, lest it spread its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span>
among the faithful.19 The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of this religion produces baneful
influences <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the Mazdayasnians,20 it implants vice,21 and [328] aggravates
immorality.22 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Men</span> become of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> disposition through it.23 Those who
belong to this <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> cannot be said to be related to the Prime Source.24 Such
violent attacks on the beliefs of a race which had settled in Persia from the
very early period of her history show us the bitterness of feeling that must
have prevailed between Zoroastrians and Jews. A later writer, confounding
Kai Lohrasp with Nebuchadnezzar, states that one of the meritorious deeds
done by Lohrasp was that he destroyed <span class="t2 t6 t26 hoverable">Jerusalem</span> and scattered the Jews.25

25. Mkh. 27. 64, 67; see also Jackson, Zoroaster, p. 209. Christian propaganda
in Iran. Christianity had entered Persia during the Parthian period, and the
Sasanians found the creed of <span class="t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t13 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">Christ</span> more or less current when they
established their empire. Of all the alien faiths in Persia, Christianity was the
most aggressive. The pertinacious attempt of the Christians to win over
converts to their <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> from the ruling nation, often caused shedding of
<span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> blood. There was a <span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">state</span> of perennial war between Sasanian Persia
and Byzantine Rome, which had embraced Christianity. The sympathy of
the Christian population naturally <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">went</span> to their Roman co-religionists and
caused disturbances in Persia. Moreover, the fanatic zeal of the priests on
both sides fomented communal strife, which often resulted in the destruction
of the Zoroastrian fire-temples and Christian churches, and the consequent
persecution of the Christians. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span> as are the resemblances between the
fundamental teachings of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> religions, their ethical systems show a
glaring distinction. Christianity exalted monastic virtues, and glorified
celibacy. The Zoroastrian priests vehemently denounced the foreign priests
who preached a mode of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> which clashed with their ethics.26 Reckless
utterances of the Christian priests often aggravated the ill-feeling between
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> peoples, and violent scenes ensued. An enthusiastic bishop once
regaled his congregation by saying that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> would, in his
future life, be <span class="t9 t24 hoverable">born</span> in hell-fire with Satan, whereas the Christians <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be
translated to heaven,27 while another patriarch urged the Roman bishops to
<span class="t1 t8 hoverable">free</span> them from the accursed rule of the [329] Persians.28 The priests on both
the sides became zealots, and occasionally fell into the slough of fanaticism.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Great</span> was the fury of religious rancour that prevailed on such occasions. The
seceders from Zoroastrianism were persecuted; apostasy was made a capital
crime by the Zoroastrian Church, and the renegades were put to death.
Notwithstanding such harsh measures adopted by the Iranian clergy,
numerous converts were made throughout the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">whole</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of the Sasanian
rule from Zoroastrianism to Christianity. Some of the greatest saints were
won from the Zoroastrian community. A noted Zoroastrian preceptor
embraced Christianity, and later became the Patriarch under the name Mar
Aba the Great. The Zoroastrian priesthood clamoured for his death, and the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">law</span> of the country supported them. It was the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> admiration that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span>
Noshirvan held for the Patriarch that saved his life.29 Yazdagard I and
Hormizd IV ascended the throne with proclivities for Christianity, and

Noshirvan and Khusru Parviz had wedded Christian princesses. Nushzad,
one of the <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t25 t26 hoverable">sons</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Sasanian <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> Noshirvan, was <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> up a
Christian.30o Another ruler of the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">House</span> of Sasan, Parviz, built a monastery
to please his favourite Christian wife.31 Such royal examples encouraged the
Christian propaganda in Iran. Yazdagard I, who favoured the Christian
cause, was hailed by the Christians as the <span class="t2 t15 t24 hoverable">blessed</span> king, but was branded by
his own co-religionists as the wicked sinner.32

<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XXXVI
SECTS
Zoroastrianism split up into a <span class="t8 t21 t27 hoverable">number</span> of sects. As indicated above, the
Zoroastrian church had lost all control over its adherents. Sect after sect
arose, each claiming to interpret the religion of Zoroaster in its own light.1
The <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> that numerous sects flourished in Iran at this period is proved by the
frequent allusions to them by Greek, Arabian, Syriac, and Armenian writers.
Shahrastani, as we shall see later, speaks of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> sects, namely the
Zarvanites, the Gayomarthians, and the Zardushtians. Mohsan Fani refers to
fourteen sects as he witnessed in his <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span> in the seventeenth century. Several
of these, he adds, flourished from early times. Unfortunately the accounts of
those sects, which we <span class="t5 t14 t15 t24 t27 hoverable">find</span> in the extant Zoroastrian literature, is very
meagre. Several of them, about which we get some information from the

non-Zoroastrian sources, are not even mentioned by name in the Iranian
works. The Armenian writers, Eznik and Elisaeus, writing in the fifth century
about the Zoroastrians of their own time, <span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">state</span> they were split into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> rival
sects <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Mog and Zendik. Damascius (529 A.D.), on the authority of
Eudemus states that sects flourished in Iran which held space as the
primordial being that created the rival spirits of goodness and evil.2 The most
formidable of the sects, which counted eminent persons among its adherents
during the Sasanian period and which had a considerable following <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span>
after the disappearance of this last Zoroastrian empire, was that of the
Zarvanites. Zarvan, or Time, accompanied Mithra in his migration to the far
West and as Kronos was placed at the pinnacle of the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> hierarchy in the
Mithraic cult.3 Antiochus I of Commagene speaks of Boundless Time. 1.
Jackson, Zoroastrian Studies, p. 174-177, Edwards, Sects (Zoroastrian) in ERE. 11.
345-347.

1898.
3. Cumont, The Mysteries of Mithra, Eng. tr. McConnack, p. 107, Chicago,
1903. [331]
ZARVANITES
Zarvan according to the Pahlavi writers. This image of the <span class="t0 t28 hoverable">eternal</span> duration
of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> is as cold and lifeless in the Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> as it was in the Avestan
texts. Ormazd created it, and with its <span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> the entire existence came into
motion.4 or according to another passage, Boundless <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> is eternally in
Ormazd, and the very first <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of his in <span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> appertained to Time.5 He
<span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> into being the earthly and heavenly creatures through his own
splendour and through the blessing of Time.6 Zarvan, or Time, is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span>
hungerless and thirstless, painless and deathless, ever-living and everpredominating over the fleeting <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> of the universe.7 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> the
authoritative Zoroastrian <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of Boundless <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> in its relation to
Ormazd; just as any system of philosophy or theology may <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of the
eternity of God. The demon Arashk is alleged to have said that Ormazd and
Ahriman have been <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> brothers in one womb.8 Mani calls Zarvan in his
heresy, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> Eternal, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Father</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> of Light.9

Zoroastrians regarded <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> as the source and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> of existence.13
According to Photius this being was looked <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> as the ruler of the universe;
he offered <span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span> in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to beget Hormizdas, but gave birth Hormizdas
and Satan.14 Damascius quotes Eudemus (about [332] 306 B.C.) as stating
that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> of Oromasdes or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Light</span> and Arimanius or Darkness.15

generative principle of everything, and it was from this primordial principle
that both Ormizd and Arhmn have sprung. They are its twin children.16 The

speaking of Zarvan as the prime originator of Ohrmazd and Ahriman.17 According to the teachings of this sect, as portrayed by these writers Zarvan
existed when the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> was not, and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> was not, and brooded over
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> of begetting a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">son</span> who <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> create the universe. A doubt
crossed his mind, the <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> claims, at the end of a <span class="t6 hoverable">thousand</span> years, lest his
<span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span> should turn out fruitless and he <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> not be <span class="t2 t15 t24 hoverable">blessed</span> with a child.
The sacrifice, however, turned out fruitful, but not <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> mishap. Zarvan
conceived <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> offspring, one as the result of his sacrifice, the other as the
outcome of the doubt that had desecrated his mind. He resolved to give
sovereignty to him who was <span class="t9 t24 hoverable">born</span> first. Ohrmazd, who seems to have been
possessed of fore-knowledge even before he was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> born, read the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span>
of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> Zarvan, and gave it out to his comrade in the embryo. Ahriman
thereupon perforated the womb and came into existence before Ohrmazd.
He demanded sovereignty from his begetter, Zarvan, who disowned this
ugly, dark creature, and gave the sceptre into the <span class="t20 hoverable">hands</span> of Ohrmazd, who
was resplendent with light. Ahriman now charged his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">father</span> with breaking
his vow. In <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to <span class="t1 t8 hoverable">free</span> himself from this accusation, Zarvan entered into a
covenant with Ahriman, and decreed that the empire of the universe should
be conjointly ceded to both Ohrmazd and Ahriman for nine <span class="t6 hoverable">thousand</span> years,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> the right of priority was ever to be with the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Good</span> Spirit. After the
expiration of this period, Ohrmazd, it was destined, should be at liberty to
deal with his wicked brother as he liked.18

left no traces whatever in the extant Pahlavi works. They do not even

Shahristani,
who wrote in the early part of the twelfth century, attests, as we shall see
later,, that he met the followers of this sect in his day.
FATALISTS
Superstitious belief in Fate that weaves the web of events in man's life.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> has willed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> to be the architect of his destiny and endowed him with
the freedom of will, says Zarathushtra.19 Man's ignorance and superstition
have led him to the belief that he is not a <span class="t1 t8 hoverable">free</span> agent who can control and
shape the actions of his life. <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Human</span> happenings, it is believed, are regulated
by the position and movements of the stars and planets and constellations.
Ingenious brains have laboured to <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> the future from the careful
observation of the movements of the heavenly bodies. They have practised
augury by watching the flight of birds and have drawn omens from the stars
and other sources. They have endeavoured to read the course of the stars and
to study with utmost scrupulous care and anxiety, worthy of more rational
and useful pursuits, the phenomena, in the vain hope that they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span>
thereby be able to foretell coming events and forestall coming misfortunes.
Fate, they have taught,, dogs man's footsteps and overtakes him unawares. It
hunts. him like wild animals to and fro. Nothing could be done against it. In
vain <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> struggle to save himself from being drowned in the floods
of fate. The mightiest among <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> has to yield submission to the decrees of
unrelenting fate. This credulous belief in the inevitability of the decrees of
Fate has led <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> and women to accept with fatalistic resignation what befell
their lot. It has led them to submit and succumb to the buffetings of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
where they should have braved them and fought [334] them and
overpowered them. The belief in Fate and Kismet and Karma have all been
equally paralysing. In one <span class="t5 t16 t21 t24 t25 hoverable">case</span> it is the movements of the stars, in other the
arbitrary will of Providence and in the third, actions of past life, that grip the
<span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span> at every step he takes in his life. Anything and everything that
happens is predestined either by the stars and planets or by the inscrutable

decree of Kismet or by the inexorable <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">law</span> of Karma. The fatalistic belief has
crippled the activities, cramped the progress, stifled the spirit, and blighted
the ardour of countless millions of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> in the East. 19. See Jackson. The
Zoroastrian Doctrine of the Freedom of the Will in Zoroastrian Studies, 219-244.
Mithraism is loaded with fatalistic ideas which it received from Babylonia
before going to Europe. Orthodox Zoroastrianism did not entirely escape
the Babylonian influence. The Babylonian and Magian diviners played
important part in the lives of the people. Shah Namah abounds in instances
of superstitious regard for omens and portents and astrological auguries. The
court astrologers read the stars to indicate the future events. The kings did
not embark <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> war <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> consulting the diviners. According to the
Pahlavi Aiyadgar-i Zariran, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Vishtasp asks his <span class="t5 t8 hoverable">wise</span> diviner, Jamasp, to
foretell the consequences of the war.20 When Xerxes was marching against
the Greeks, an eclipse of the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">sun</span> <span class="t2 t4 t6 t9 t18 t19 t22 hoverable">took</span> place. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> was <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> with alarm
and consulted the magicians about the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> of the portent.21 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Men</span> and
women regulated the chief events of their daily lives according to the
dictates of the planetary movements. Fate generally became the ruling force
of life.

21. Herod. 7. 37. Fate is the decree of Time. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> and Fate are indissolubly
linked together. They are often spoken of as identical with each other.22 The
movements of the heavens regulate Fate, and the planets and constellations
are the arbiters of man's fortune.23 The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> stars determine man's
lot, which is linked with the course of the stars. Every <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> event
that falls to the lot of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> comes to <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t11 t12 t19 t22 hoverable">pass</span> through the doings of the twelve
constellations that are ranged on the side of Ohrmazd, or through the
baneful influence of the seven planets, as their special antagonists, arrayed on
Ahriman's side. Both of these agents combine to administer the affairs of the
world.24 22. Theodore of Mopsuestia, apud Photius, Bibl. 81.

not receive it, it is owing to the extortion of these planets.25 Like brigands

and highwaymen they rob the righteous of their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> lot and bestow it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
the wicked.26 Ahriman has specially created them for the purpose of

every deed.30 That which is ordained to come to <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t11 t12 t19 t22 hoverable">pass</span> will unfailingly happen;
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> should not worry over <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">things</span> over which he has no control. He should
learn to receive with tranquillity and calm whatever falls to his lot.31 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span>
nothing in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> can rescind the inexorable decree of Fate,32 <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span>
Providence, moved by the prayers and supplications of mortals, can still, in
special cases, intervene in mortal behalf. Owing to the counter-movements
of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> planets, Providence rarely interferes.33

humility is apt to degenerate into servility in <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> affairs, or into fatalism
in their relations with the superhuman powers. In Persia, the dissolution of
