Zartusht's fabled religious debate with Indian and Greek sages. It is said
that there lived a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> sage named Changranghacha in India at this time. He
claimed many foreign pupils of distinction and Jamasp was one of them.
When the news of the conversion of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> Gushtasp reached him he wrote an
epistle to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> and dissuaded him from embracing the new faith. On the
invitation of the king, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> philosopher came to Balkh with his disciples
to hold a disputation with Zartusht and refute his doctrines. Learned <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span>
from various parts of the country attended the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> debate. Before the sage
propounded his questions, Zartusht ordered one of his disciples to read a
Nask. Herein were already recorded all the questions that the Indian sage
was to ask as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as the answers to them. The sage was utterly confused and
he saw that the new prophet had premonition and he knew beforehand what
particular questions <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be put to him. He acknowledged his defeat and
accepted Zartusht as the prophet of God. He embraced the new religion,
<span class="t2 t4 t6 t9 t18 t19 t22 hoverable">took</span> a copy of the Avesta with him to India and converted in a short <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span>
eighty <span class="t6 hoverable">thousand</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> to the religion of the Iranian Prophet.
When the news that Changranghacha was defeated by Zartusht [456]
reached abroad, another Indian controversialist, Bias by name, came to the
court of Gushtasp. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> organized a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> assemblage to which the

learned <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> came from distant lands. Bias opened the debate and addressing
Zartusht said that he had <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t18 hoverable">heard</span> that the <span class="t5 t8 hoverable">wise</span> Changranghacha had adopted
the new faith. He had <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t18 hoverable">heard</span> in his country, of the many miracles performed
by the new prophet, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> he challenged him to disclose the secret
thoughts he had kept pent up in his bosom and had not transferred from his
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">heart</span> to his lips. Zartusht, thereupon, <span class="t2 t4 t6 t9 t18 t19 t22 hoverable">took</span> out a <span class="t6 t8 t10 t11 t16 t20 t21 t27 t28 hoverable">book</span> that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> sent to him
before the coming of Bias to Iran. He then read out all that was concealed in
the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">heart</span> of Bias, with the appropriate explanations. Bias was at once
convinced of the superhuman <span class="t7 t8 t12 hoverable">wisdom</span> of Zartusht and became an ardent
follower of his religion. Tutianush or Niyatus was the other philosopher who
was sent by the eminent sages of Greece to interrogate the prophet about
the tenets of his faith. The distinguished Greek seer was at once convinced
of the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> insight of Zartusht when he beheld his face. Zartusht asked him
to keep in his <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">heart</span> whatever he desired to inquire, for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> had already
acquainted him with it. One of his disciples then read out aloud all that was
in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> of Tutianush. The Greek sage adopted the <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span>
Gushtasp appointed him the <span class="t1 t4 t9 t16 hoverable">head</span> of the priests in his country, where he
propagated Zartusht's religion.14
14 Desatir, tr. by Mulla Firuz Bin Kaus, p. 2.120-144, Bombay, 1818; Db.,
1.276-283; Jackson, Zoroaster, p. 85-90.
Zartusht's death. When Arjasp invaded Balkh for the <span class="t0 t2 t5 t13 t14 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">second</span> time, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span>
Gushtasp, as the Persian writers record, was partaking of the hospitality of
Zal in Seistan. A Turk named Tur-baratur entered Zartusht's oratory and the
prophet received his martyrdom by his sword. Zartusht, however, threw the
rosary that was in his <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">hand</span> at the assailant. An effulgent splendor proceeded
from it and its <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> at once consumed him.15
15 ShN. 5.92; Db., 1.371, 372; Jackson, Zoroaster, p. 130, 131.
[457]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> XLIX
PERSIAN <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">WORKS</span> ON ZOROASTRIANISM
Rivayats, or codes of usages and rituals. We have again to <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t11 t12 t19 t22 hoverable">pass</span> over a
period of about <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> centuries, or from about the thirteenth century to the

latter part of the fifteenth century, before we come across a further record of
literary activity. After the convulsions that the small band of fugitives
experienced, they had settled down as the tillers of the fields, sellers of liquor
and toddy, as minor traders and merchants, or as members of petty
professions. By this time, however, the Parsis of Gujarat had begun fairly to
prosper. Some of them had even succeeded in building up modest fortunes,
and had spread abroad their fame for liberality. This beginning of the
economic welfare of the community shows the first signs of the new life, and
among these signs was the <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> that the community began eagerly to turn its
attention to the necessity of gaining authentic information on the religious
questions about which they were in doubt. The Parsis of India <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> that
their co-religionists living in Persia must be better informed on religious
matters than themselves, and must have preserved the old-time tradition
more faithfully than they themselves did. They <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> drew up certain
religious questions on which they needed enlightenment, and in 1478
commissioned a daring Parsi to go to Persia and lay their questions before
the learned Dasturs of their fatherland. The news that a band of fugitives
lived in India who were one in <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> with them, and shared their common
traditions, had <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> since filtered through to the Zoroastrians of Persia. In
<span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> it is possible that the connection between the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> bands of the faithful,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> imperfect, had never been quite broken. Intercourse through trade, as
<span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as other factors, must have helped to keep up some connection. Great,
therefore, was the enthusiasm caused by the fresh opening of a closer
communication with them; and for nearly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> centuries (1478-1766), a
more immediate interchange of views <span class="t2 t4 t6 t9 t18 t19 t22 hoverable">took</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> between the Zoroastrians of
India and Persia. [458] No less than twenty-two messengers had <span class="t1 t7 t12 t29 hoverable">left</span> India
during this period with questions pertaining to ritual observances,
ceremonial ablutions, purificatory rites, forms of worship, rules of adoption
and marriage and other miscellaneous subjects. These collections of
traditions, customs, and rites, arranged in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of questions and answers,
are composed in Persia, which became the literary language of the Parsi
scholars under the influence of the Moslem rule in Gujarat. These
compilations are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Rivayats, and provide a wealth of information on
liturgical and social matters.1 Side by side with a score of important subjects,
the disquisitions sometimes fall to the level of barren theological
disputations. Among such discussions, for example, were points like these:

Whether the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> could be copied with ink prepared by a nonZoroastrian, <span class="t0 t5 t8 t10 t14 t15 t21 t24 t28 hoverable">whether</span> the faithful be polluted by conversing with the nonZoroastrians while they are carrying a dead body, <span class="t0 t5 t8 t10 t14 t15 t21 t24 t28 hoverable">whether</span> a Mobad who has
eaten clarified butter prepared by a non-Zoroastrian can ever regain bodily
purity by means of ceremonial ablutions.
1 The dates of the Persian Rivayats in Studies in Parsi History, by S. H. Hodivala, p.
276-349, Bombay, 1920; Darab Hormazyar's Rivayat, edited by M. R. Unvala,
with an introduction by J. J. Mody, 2 vols; The Persian Rivayats of Hormazyar
Framarz and others by B. N. Dhabhar; Darab Hormazdyar's Rivayat by J. J. Mody,
in the Journal of K. R. Cama Oriental Institute, 23. 109-238. Theology of the
period. Bundahishn and Sad Dar, Jamaspi and Arda Viraf Namah inspired
the clergy and laity in their conduct of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> at this period rather than did the
Gathas and other Avestan works. The formal rather than the spiritual, the
concrete rather than the abstract, seem to be the prominent feature of the
beliefs that we can glean from the Rivayats. The hope of the joys of a
materialized <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> and the <span class="t9 t19 hoverable">fear</span> of the sufferings of a <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> hell guide and
control man's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> earth. Man's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> and his Farohar are taken, in the
Rivayats, for one and the same. The souls and not the Farohars are believed
to come down on <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> on their monthly or yearly anniversaries. The souls
of the righteous persons descend on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> and remain here for <span class="t10 t16 hoverable">full</span> ten
<span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span> of the Farohar festival, but the souls of the wicked ones are given only
five days' leave of absence from hell to visit their earthly homes. If the souls
are properly propitiated, they rejoice and bless; if not, they complain and
curse. It came to be believed that the Yasna sacrifices [459] offered in the
name of Farohars, or of the angel Hom, or of those of Zartusht, Gushtasp,
and other sainted dead persons, could thwart the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> designs of their
enemies; could rout the demons and fairies; could oppose the tyrant kings;
could withstand famine and plague, retard the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> consequences of bad
dreams, gain favour of kings and noblemen, and secure various advantages.
We are informed, moreover, that the <span class="t1 t11 t16 t20 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">reason</span> of consecrating a <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> of white
garments on the fourth <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> after <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> is to provide a corresponding
heavenly garment to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> in the next world; because, we are told, the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> is quite naked, when it is liberated from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> at death, and is
naturally ashamed to enter the assembly of the heavenly souls who are all
clad in fine raiment. The souls are awarded heavenly garments in proportion

to what is consecrated to them by their kinsmen in this world. The richer the
quality of the garment consecrated here, the finer the raiment bestowed
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> in heaven.
Bull's urine, or golden water, as it is now called, has been an indispensable
article in the purificatory rites and ceremonial ablutions among the
Zoroastrians from the earliest times. From the strong belief in the efficacy of
its giving external bodily purification, it was but a step to the <span class="t0 hoverable">idea</span> of
attributing to it the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of purifying the internal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of man. A most
extravagant sanctity came to be attached to the drinking of it. Elaborate
rituals are now performed over the liquid and the drinking of this
consecrated fluid <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> an indissoluble part of certain Zoroastrian
ceremonials. The Rivayats tell us that the drink gives <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> glory, and makes
man's inner <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> as bright and as pure as the sun.
Bull's urine has been, since <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> times, an essential auxiliary of spells or
formulas <span class="t0 t12 hoverable">used</span> to exorcise those possessed by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> power; but the original
Avestan and Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> gaomaeza or gomez fell into disuse by the Rivayat
time, and the term nirang, which originally meant spell only, now signifies
both spell and bull's urine, and henceforth conveys both the meanings. Such
in general is the <span class="t25 hoverable">view</span> that we gather from the Rivayats regarding the
conditions prevailing in that period.
Other <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> in Persian. Besides the Rivayats, several works, both in prose
and in verse, have reached us. The most important of these is the Zartusht
Namah or <span class="t6 t8 t10 t11 t16 t20 t21 t27 t28 hoverable">Book</span> of Zartusht composed in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> by Zartusht Bahram Pazdu in the
thirteenth [460] century.2 The <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the prophet is based
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the Pahlavi works. Several Pahlavi <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> are rendered into Persian. The
Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> are translated into Persian with the help of their Pahlavi
version. A considerable devotional literature and treatises on miscellaneous
subjects are extant. There are about forty short prayers in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> and gazal
form, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Monâjâts composed by about a dozen different priests. The
earliest in point of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> are the four hymns attributed to the authorship of
Zartusht Bahram Pazdu, the author of the Zartusht Namah. The latest are
composed in the <span class="t26 hoverable">third</span> quarter of the last century.
2 West, GIrPh. 2.122, 123; Eastwick, tr. in English in Wilson's Parsi Religion,

p. 477-522; Rosenberg, Le Livre de Zoroaster.
[461]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> L
MYSTICS AND MYSTICISM
To know <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> one must become <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> is the dictum of mysticism. Religions
have looked to <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> revelation as the real source of <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> wisdom. The
faculties of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> mind, it is believed by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> of mystic temperament,
cannot give the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of God. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Knowledge</span> gathered through the
senses is illusive. <span class="t1 t11 t16 t20 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">Reason</span> is not capable of comprehending God. To attempt
to see him through the medium of <span class="t1 t11 t16 t20 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">reason</span> is to lose him. Intuition is <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span>
than reason. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> <span class="t1 t11 t16 t20 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">reason</span> may conduct the adept to the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> portal,
intuition alone can enable him to penetrate into the sanctuary and have a
vision of God. <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Human</span> <span class="t5 t15 t21 t27 hoverable">intelligence</span> is debarred from entering this inner
sphere. <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Divine</span> <span class="t7 t8 t12 hoverable">wisdom</span> dawns <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> when it renounces its own
thoughts and reflection, and loses all self-consciousness. In such an entirely
passive and receptive <span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">state</span> of ecstasy, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> is divinely illumined. It is the
outcome of immediate contact of the pure <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> with God. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> that
yearns to know <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> must seek its union with the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> mind. The
transcendental insight gives a supra-rational apprehension of <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> wisdom.
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Truth</span> dawns <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> him, and shines in its effulgence, while an ecstatic
insight is aroused in him and in a moment of ecstasy, when the devotee
transcends all self-consciousness, the wave of the occult <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> surges in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
him, and the mysterious something sweeps, like a meteor, over his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span>
giving a sudden flash that illumines the inner world. The nightingale in its
transport of joy sings to the <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">glory</span> of God, until it becomes half frenzied.
When the mystic is bathed in devotion, he is so intoxicated with the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span>
<span class="t7 t8 t12 hoverable">wisdom</span> that he thinks himself one with the Divine. In this condition the
devotee does not meditate <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> God, he feels him; he does not think of
God, he owns him.
The allegorical method of interpreting religious texts. From very early
times some theologians of both the East and the West [462] have maintained
that the prophets adapt themselves to the mode of thinking of the masses
and <span class="t1 hoverable">use</span> parables and legends to express their views. The sacred texts, they

say, are <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> in a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> which contains a double meaning, the one is the
surface meaning, which can be understood by the masses, and the other is
the inner or hidden <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> meant for the initiated. The Sophists and Stoics
resorted to the method of allegorically interpreting Greek mythology to
meet the attacks of sceptical criticism. The Alexandrian Jewish and Christian
theologians, Philo and Origen, spoke of the literal and <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> meanings of
the sacred books. The first, they wrote, was the bodily part of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">text</span> meant
for the majority and the <span class="t0 t2 t5 t13 t14 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">second</span> was its <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> part which was understood
by those few who could <span class="t5 t14 t15 t24 t27 hoverable">find</span> the revealed kernel, hidden by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> in the outer
textual shell. The Gnostics and the Neo-Platonists <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> attempted to explain
Oriental and Occidental myths by allegorical interpretation. The Ismailis,
the Sect of the Seven and other schools that flourished in Iran from the ninth
century, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> themselves the Bâtinis or the esoterics as opposed to the
Zâhiris or the exoterics or literalists. Their method of interpreting the sacred
<span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> on the allegorical basis is <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> tâ’wil.
This method of interpreting religious <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> persists throughout the various
periods of the history of the religions of the world. Legends and myths,
traditional dogmas and superstitious customs, historical errors and textual
discrepancies, primitive beliefs and practices are all invested with the
mysterious meanings. Statements which often repel both <span class="t5 t15 t21 t27 hoverable">intelligence</span> and
conscience <span class="t5 t14 t15 t24 t27 hoverable">find</span> an easy expedient in allegory. The esoterics generally seek in
the sacred <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> what their own thinking is willing to <span class="t5 t14 t15 t24 t27 hoverable">find</span> and read in them
what is rooted in their minds. They read the subjective <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> into the
<span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> and draw unwarranted implications from them. Forces of nature,
animate or inanimate objects are all given a new <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> and explained as
symbolizing some ethical idea, some aspects of man's consciousness, some
expression of the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> in man. Rational explanations are attempted for
apparently absurd customs to preserve them against rational criticism.
Symbolic significance is attached to puerile legends. Unbridled by the
canons of <span class="t1 t11 t16 t20 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">reason</span> and undeterred by any regard for historical <span class="t0 t1 t7 t12 t13 t14 t17 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">sense</span> and
critical acumen, the esoteric interpreters of religions generally produce
allegorizing extravagances.
[463] Desatir and Dabistan. In the early part of the last century appeared
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">text</span> and translation of the Desatir, alleged to have a heavenly origin, and
to have been <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> down in the reign of Khusru Parviz and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> to throw a

flood of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> on Zoroastrianism. A very heated controversy was the result of
the appearance of this work. One party of eminent European scholars
declared it to be a fraudulent forgery, while others of equal eminence
endeavoured to prove its authenticity. The claim of the Desatir to have been
<span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> in a celestial language was put to a crucial test. Patient research has
since declared the <span class="t6 t8 t10 t11 t16 t20 t21 t27 t28 hoverable">book</span> to be an exotic, outside the pale of Zoroastrianism.
And so it has been held by all Iranian scholars both of East and West.1
1 Bharucha, in Zartoshti, vol. 3, p.121-134;179-191; vol.4, p.257-279,
Bombay, 1275 A. Y.
In this <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> are given the teachings of various mystic schools, and the entire
treatise breathes a totally different atmosphere from that of the genuine
Zoroastrian works, being divergent in tone from the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> from its very
beginning to its close. The Iranian scriptures of all periods have recognized
Gayomard as the primeval man, who was the progenitor of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> race,
and who, first among mortals, <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t18 hoverable">heard</span> the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> of Ohrmazd.1a But this
work, on the contrary, gives a regular hierarchy of prophets who are
supposed to have preceded the first man. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> first revealed his secrets to
one Mahabad, who was followed by thirteen other prophets in the former
cycles of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> bearing his name. Through them the supposed revelation
came down to Gayomard and his descendants. It is alleged in this book,
moreover, that all the early Pishdadian kings conformed to this religion of
Mahabad, until the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> that Zoroaster came and preached his
fundamentally new religion. But even the new prophet's religion, we are told,
was so glossed over by the Yazdanians, the followers of Mahabad, that
Zoroastrianism was ultimately made to confer to the Mahabadian code.2
1a Yt. 13.87. 2 Dabistan, tr. Shea and Troyer, vol. 1, p. 30.
Another Persian <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> entitled Dabistan, or School of Manners, <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> in
India by Mohsan Fani in the seventeenth century, draws the greater part of
its materials from the Desatir. The author of this composition mentions some
fourteen sects into which he finds the Zoroastrians of his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> divided. These
are the Sipasian, Abadian, Jamshaspian, Samradian, Khodaiyan, [464]
Radian, Shidrangian, Paikarian, Milanian, Alarian, Shidabian, Akhshiyan,
Zardushtian, and Mazdakian. Several of these sects are stated to have
flourished from very remote times, going back to the Pahlavi and Avestan
periods, nay stretching even back to a period of which history has not a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> to tell. With the exception of these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> works, however, we have no

inkling of other sects in the genuine Iranian texts. The statements contained
in them are not corroborated by any authority in the writings of the
Zoroastrian priests. They do not mention them by name, they are entirely
unaware of their existence. The <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of the majority of these sects, as
found in the Dabistan, is very meagre. We meet with some attempts in them
to explain the primordial principle from which <span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> came into being, and
we have some sort of crude metaphysics grafted on physics. Sun, fire, air,
nature, water, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> are alternately put forward as having been the
<span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> sources of existence according to various schools of thinkers.3
Others still preach a strict monism, and assume that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> of phenomena
was caused by illusion.4 The teachings of the Yazdanians and others are
characterized by a belief in metempsychosis, as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as in the efficiency of
rigorous austerities and ascetic virtues. Our present concern, however, is
with the author's <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of the Zoroastrian mystics, and we shall now turn
to the matter immediately.
3 Vol. 1, p. 202-207.
4 Ib., p. 195.
Zoroastrian mystics. At this period we meet with some Parsi thinkers who
were not satisfied with the formal side of religion, and looked with
indifference <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the ritual observances, Outward formalism and literal
interpretation of the teachings of the prophet failed to meet with the
longings of these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> of mystic temperament. They ever remained in search
of mysteries hidden beneath the outward garb of dogmas and rituals. The
Parsi priesthood could not satisfy the wants of such ecstatic enthusiasts.
They revolted from authority, and <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">set</span> about thinking for themselves. These
dissenters as a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> lived a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> different from that led by their neighbours.
Many of them found consolation in the teachings of the Hindu Yogis and
became their willing disciples. Under these circumstances we have to turn to
the Dabistan for the general information of this sect, as the historic Parsi
<span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> are silent over the question and do not even notice its existence.
[465] Azar Kaivan and his disciples. The author of the Dabistan gives us an
elaborate <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of the Zoroastrian mystics whom he met in Patna, in
Kashmir, and in Lahore during the seventeenth century.5 The most illustrious
of these mystic teachers was Dastur Azar Kaivan who came from Persia and

settled in Patna,6 and lived for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> in seclusion far from the public gaze.7
Some of the most prominent disciples of this recluse sage were the Mobads
Farzan Bahram of Shiraz, Hushiyyar of Surat, Sarosh, and Khuda Jui. They
extravagantly trace their lineage back to Ma-habad, to Sam, Godrej, Rustam,
Jamasp, Zoroaster, and Noshirvan. Let us now <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t11 t12 t19 t22 hoverable">pass</span> on to a brief notice of the
literary activity of these hermit priests.
5 Vol. 1, 108, 115, 118, 119, 122, 123; vol. 3, 204. 6 Vol. 1, 89.
7 Vol. 1, 93.
Mystic literature during the period. These Parsi mystics composed several
treatises in Persian, which, as we have already seen, was the literary medium
of this period. Among the more important <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> that have <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> come down
to us are Jam-i Kaikhusru, Makashefat-i Kaivani, Khishtab, Zaredasht Afshar,
and Zindah Rud. The author of the last <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> allege that their <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> are
translations into Persian from the original Pahlavi books <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> in the <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span>
of the Sasanian kings Hormazd and Khusru Parviz. A search through the
literary content of these writings, however, shows that their philosophical
dissertations mostly reproduce the teachings of Greek philosophy, current in
India in the seventeenth century through its Arabic version. For instance, the
Khishtab opens with the prophet Mahabad's descriptions of the four
generative principles of things, which are nothing else but the material,
formal, efficient, and final causes of Aristotle. The authors fantastically credit
the legendary and real kings and princes of Persia with the philosophical
ideas, which on very little examination can easily be traced to their original
Greek sources. These royal personages are styled prophets or seers and
depicted as advancing some original argument for the proof of the existence
of God, his <span class="t0 t28 hoverable">eternal</span> attributes, and regarding other kindred subjects. Even the
warrior heroes Zal and Rustam seem occasionally to have proclaimed a truce
to warfare, and to have devoutly sat down in more peaceful pursuit of
metaphysical investigations; for some of the philosophical disquisitions stand
in their names too.
[466] The alleged twofold <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> of the Avesta. These esoteric
interpreters of the sacred <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> asserted that Zoroaster had couched his
teachings in figurative and enigmatic language.8 The Zoroastrian scriptures
were accordingly divided into 'Great Zend' and 'Little Zend,'9 the first being
followed by the adepts and initiates, and the <span class="t0 t2 t5 t13 t14 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">second</span> by the masses.. The

figurative language of the former hid the deeper truths from the ignorant.
8 Db., <span class="t5 t7 t14 t18 t27 t28 hoverable">vol</span> 1.361.
9 Ib., 352.
The author, then, cites some instances and explains the difference between
the exoteric and the esoteric interpretations of the Avestan texts. For
instance; when it is said that the archangel Bahman held a conference with
Zoroaster and asked him to close his eyes, the vulgar, according to the
Dabistan, understand that Bahman assumed <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> and addressed the
prophet like a mortal; but the adept is to understand by this that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span>
essence of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> was uncompounded, and that under such a <span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">state</span> Bahman
manifested himself before Zoroaster, and his asking the prophet to close his
<span class="t2 t6 t19 t20 t26 t29 hoverable">eyes</span> means only that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> asked him to eradicate all bodily attachment
and suppress carnal desires of the <span class="t6 t20 hoverable">flesh</span> in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to enable him to get a vision
of the archangel.10 When the Zoroastrian <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> seem to sanction animal
slaughter, it is to be understood as an injunction to kill the animal
propensities inherent in man.11 The author states further that the passages
which <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of the hermits as partaking of animal <span class="t0 t14 t23 t24 hoverable">food</span> in reasonable bounds
are not to be <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> literally. These simply refer to the gradual control and
ultimate killing of the animal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> in man.12 The legend that Ahriman
appeared at a season festival in the guise of a glutton and devoured
everything to the utter confusion of the assembly, until he was routed by
preparing a dish from the <span class="t6 t20 hoverable">flesh</span> of a certain red cow, mixed with vinegar,
garlic, and rue, at the instance of some miraculous advice, may be <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> by
the masses as literally true. But any one versed in esoteric wisdom, and
acquained with the doctrines inculcated by the Dabistan, knows that the
killing of the red cow stands for the suppression of the sensual appetite,
vinegar for the virtue of abstinence, garlic for reflection, and rue for silent
reflection. All these <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> kill Ahrimanian propensities in man.13 The
ignorant invest Ahriman with a personality; but, really [467] speaking, he has
no independent existence, for he is not an entity and is simply the negation
of existence.14 The aggregate of bodily passions and sensual appetites is
symbolically termed Ahriman, named from the originator of evil,15 and
Ahriman's predominance in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> is to exist only for a limited <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> while
the tumult of youth in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> and the bodily passions in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> are in the
ascendency and until they are ultimately curbed and eradicated.16 Again, the
sacred books <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of Ahriman as the creator of serpents and scorpions. But

these noxious creatures, according to this treatise, are nothing but allegorical
expressions for the vices and passions that haunt the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> mind.17 All such
persons as stick to the exoteric interpretation of the scriptures believe that
Zohak actually carried <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> serpents on his shoulders, but the adept
understand the statement as applying to the venomous tyranny and
sensuality of the wicked usurper.18 The legend of the flight of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">King</span> Kaus to
the heavens, his fall, and the subsequent restoration of this lost monarch to
his kingdom by Rustam, has likewise an esoteric interpretation. The four
eagles that carried the misguided <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">king</span> <span class="t17 t29 hoverable">high</span> up in the air, along with his
throne, signify the four elements. The throne, explains the author, stands for
the predominant bodily passions, the ascent means that a devotee can rise to
a <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span> plane of existence by a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of abstinence and austerity, the fall
denotes the revolt of the passions owing to some neglect in the observance
of the ascetic practices, :while Rustam's achievement, in finally bringing
Kaus back from the forest, indicates the flash of proper <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> that
reclaims the erring aspirant from fatal mishap.19 <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Thus</span> the esoteric writings
veil the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> from the gaze of the vulgar. The real and deep <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> is
hidden <span class="t0 t1 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t28 t29 hoverable">within</span> the: outer husks; and only he who grasps this inner <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span>
can attain to insight into the secret doctrine. This in <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> is a summary of the
mystic teachings of the Parsi ascetics in the Dabistan, based evidently <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
the earlier doctrines of Sufism and developed under Hindu mystic influences
in India.

Ascetic practices of the Parsi mystics. The hermits practised celibacy.20

They abstained from animal food,21 and reduced the quantity of their daily
food, until many of them could live on [468] <span class="t0 t14 t23 t24 hoverable">food</span> weighing ten dirhams, or a
fraction of an ounce, a day22 or in some cases on only one such unit.23 Some
could live <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> any <span class="t23 hoverable">kind</span> of <span class="t0 t14 t23 t24 hoverable">food</span> or drink for <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span> in
succession.24 Such devotees practised many kinds of austerities;25 and all of
these mortifications of the <span class="t6 t20 hoverable">flesh</span> were undergone in religious imitation of
their Hindu brethren. The chief among such austerities were those of
supporting themselves on the extremities of their fingers from midnight until
dawn,26 and of standing on the <span class="t1 t4 t9 t16 hoverable">head</span> with the feet raised in the air from
nightfall <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">unto</span> sunrise.27 By rigorous discipline some such religious
enthusiasts, we are told, attained the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of suppressing their breath for
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> hours,28 or even for twelve.29 They <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> swoon away into a <span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">state</span>
of trance,30 in which respiration and breathing were totally suspended and by
this utter self-abnegation the adepts reached the borders of utter selflessness.
Mobad Hushiyyar, once plunged into deep <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">water</span> and remained underneath
for <span class="t10 t16 hoverable">full</span> six hours before he raised his <span class="t1 t4 t9 t16 hoverable">head</span> above the surface.31 These
devotees, like the Indian Yogis, as shown below, are credited with the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span>
of quitting the bodily frame at pleasure, traversing the <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> regions, and
returning to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> whenever they liked.32 They laid claim to read the
thoughts of others.33 They are further fantastically credited with the
superhuman <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of performing miracles; such as causing the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">sun</span> to hide
his disk and appear at night, or the stars to appear during the day, walking
on the surface of water, showing themselves in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of lightning in the
heavens, metamorphosing animals, rendering themselves invisible to man,
assuming various forms,34 appearing at one and the same <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> at distant
places, bringing the dead to life, or causing the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> of the living,
producing <span class="t0 t14 t23 t24 hoverable">food</span> and wine from nothing,35 causing the rains to fall or to cease,
producing giants to frighten others, converting broken pottery into gold,36
disporting in the midst of a burning fire, or swallowing it,37 and such like.

[469] Unmistakable influence of Hindu Yogism. All this self-mortification
of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> and the assumption of occult powers sounds unfamiliar to
Zoroastrian ears. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">whole</span> fabric of the ascetic and unworldly <span class="t25 hoverable">view</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
is in direct antagonism to the active, and, in the best sense, worldly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of
the Mazdayasnian faith. In its every detail, as indicated above, the Parsi
mystic school savours of the strong influence of the Indian Yogis. The Parsi
ascetics of the period seem to have been in close acquaintance with the
Hindu hermits. The author of the Dabistan informs us that Mobad
Hushiyyar conducted him to see some of these Hindu ascetics,38 and he
speaks equally of Parsi adepts who were in constant touch with such Hindu
monks.39 He further mentions a Parsi ascetic who moved about in Gujarat
clad in the garments of a Hindu hermit,40 and who visited the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Sikh
saint, Guru Har Govind.41 Hirbad, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Parsi mystic, moreover, gave
instructions to his disciple, Mobad Hushiyyar, either to burn or bury his
body, when dead,42 because it mattered not <span class="t0 t5 t8 t10 t14 t15 t21 t24 t28 hoverable">whether</span> a corpse was consigned
to the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> or to the earth.43 Every one of its details shows the total
indifference on the part of these dissenters to what was really <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> of
Zoroastrian observance.
