<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LI
RELIGIOUS CONTROVERSIES
Theological disputations. We <span class="t5 t14 t15 t24 t27 hoverable">find</span> from the extent Persian literature that the
writers of this period occupied themselves in minute quibbling and barren
discussions of the ritualistic ceremonies and purificatory rites. There is no
trace of original thinking on vital problems. Their energy was wholly
expended on endless wranglings about dogmas and theological disquisitions.
Questions were raised <span class="t0 t5 t8 t10 t14 t15 t21 t24 t28 hoverable">whether</span> it was essential to cover the <span class="t3 hoverable">face</span> of a corpse
with the penom, or mouth-covering white veil; <span class="t0 t5 t8 t10 t14 t15 t21 t24 t28 hoverable">whether</span> the legs of a corpse
should be folded or <span class="t1 t7 t12 t29 hoverable">left</span> lengthwise, before it was removed to its final resting
place.1 The community was actually divided into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> parties over the first
question, and so bitter was the feeling aroused that at Surat the corpses <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> such coverings were refused a resting-place in the Tower of Silence. The
relatives of the dead had under these circumstances to carry dead bodies to
Navsari for their final disposal. This resulted in the erection of separate
towers for the contending parties.
1. Patell, Parsi Prakash, 1, 23, Bombay, 1888. Intercalation controversy
provides a powerful incentive to the study of the <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> Zoroastrian
scriptures. In 1720 were planted seeds of a controversy' which gave,
however, a real and abiding impetus to religious studies. A learned Mobad
named Jamasp, who came to India from Persia, in 1721, found that the Indian
Parsis were one month behind the Zoroastrians of Persia in the calculation of
their year, and he strongly advocated a reform in the matter. The question at
first did not arouse much attention, but later it developed into a serious
problem that led to a display of strong passion and to the exchange of bitter
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> on both sides in the community. Learned priests in each party
zealously turned to the study of the original scriptures, as a source to decide
the matter, and the question was threshed out in detail, accompanied by the
publication of innumerable tracts [471]and pamphlets. While the learned in
the community were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> engaged in ransacking their <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> records, the
masses <span class="t2 t4 t6 t9 t18 t19 t22 hoverable">took</span> up the controversy acrimoniously, resorting to abuses and sometimes even to blows. The Shahinshahis, or the Imperials, represented the old

order, and the dissenters styled themselves the Kadimis, or the Ancients. The
former annoyed the latter by their mocking derision. Social intercourse
between the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> became most strained, the community was split into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span>
sects, and separate places of <span class="t0 t5 t11 hoverable">worship</span> were founded. The division of the
community into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> sects endures to the present day, but despite the
differences obtaining between the two, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> and the growth of education
have obliterated the bitter feelings. Modern researches have proved that
both the parties were wrong in their calculations. The accidentals of the
controversy have changed during the <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> period of hard-fought battles, but
the main question has still remained as unsettled as before. Among the chief
causes that have contributed to the indefinite postponement of the reform
are the indifference and apathy of the community. The question is looked at
with misgivings, as not falling in the arena of practical reform, because
fraught with many complications. What we are more concerned with is, that
the controversy gave new <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> to literary activities, and encouraged studious
habits among the learned.
[472]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LII
AN EPOCH-MAKING ERA IN THE HISTORY OF ZOROASTRIAN
RESEARCHES
Introduction of Iranian studies in the West. The inexorable decree of
Providence had ruled that a new <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> from the West should dispel the
darkness that had surrounded the pages of the sacred scriptures for ages, and
add to their better understanding and elucidation. European travellers who
had visited India and Persia during the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries
acquainted the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> of the West with the religious beliefs, manners, and
customs of the followers of Zoroaster. Hyde's masterly <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> on Parsi
religion, which drew its materials from the <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> of the classical authors and
the Persian version of the Sad Dar as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as from kindred works, appeared in
1700. Some important Iranian manuscripts had been carried from India to
England, and were now shelved as curios in the Bodleian library at Oxford.
Anquetil du Perron's pioneer work. To the energetic Frenchman, Anquetil

du Perron, is due the credit of making the first systematic attempt to study
the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> their contents before the Western world.1
Having come across a facsimile of four leaves of the Bodleian manuscript, his
curiosity was aroused, and with characteristic zeal he enlisted as a soldier in
1754 on a ship bound for India with the aim of bringing back to the Western
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of the sacred scriptures of Zoroaster. Unbounded
enthusiasm, combined with the vigour of youth, enabled Anquetil to
overcome the almost insuperable difficulties that stood in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> of his
literary enterprise. Having acquired from Dastur Darab, the <span class="t17 t29 hoverable">High</span> Priest of
the Parsis of Surat, what inadequate <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> he could get in those days,
he returned home after six <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> of strenuous <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> and published the result
of his studies in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> quarto volumes in 1771. This [473]publication created
a stir in literary circles, and gave rise to a heated controversy. One school of
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> of eminent scholars in Europe declined to attach any weight to the
Frenchman's work, and denied that the grotesque stuff that he had placed
before the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> could ever be the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of so <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> a thinker and sage as
Zoroaster, stoutly maintaining that Anquetil's Avesta was either a forgery or
that he had been duped by the Indian Parsi Mobads. The falseness of this
view, however, was ultimately shown.
1. See Mody, Anquetil du Perron and Dastur Darab, Bombay, 1916. Western
scholarship revives Zoroastrian studies. The disinterested labours of various
scholars during the subsequent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> fully substantiated Anquetil's pioneer
work; and when the closer affinity between the languages of the Avesta and
Sanskrit became generally known, the sacred <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> began to be studied in the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of comparative philology, and the authenticity of the Avesta was
completely proved. The seeds sown by Anquetil have since blossomed into
fruitful trees in the West, but some decades passed after the publication of
his <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> before Western scholarship penetrated into India.
[474]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LIII
PROSELYTIZING COMES TO BE VIEWED WITH DISFAVOUR

Beginning of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of exclusiveness among the Parsis.We have already
seen that the handful of the Parsi fugitives who emigrated to India after the
final overthrow of the Persian empire in the middle of the seventh century
had to <span class="t3 hoverable">face</span> enormous difficulties in the earlier centuries of their settlement in
the new home. The precarious condition in which they lived for a considerable period made it impracticable for them to keep up their former
proselytizing zeal. The instinctive <span class="t9 t19 hoverable">fear</span> of disintegration and absorption in
the vast multitudes among whom they lived created in them a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of
exclusiveness and a strong feeling for the preservation of the racial
characteristics and distinctive features of their community. Living in an
atmosphere surcharged with the Hindu caste system, they felt that their own
safety lay in encircling their fold by rigid caste barriers.
The community was divided regarding the question of admitting lower
classes of aliens into its fold. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Though</span> the practice of an active religious
propaganda had <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> fallen into desuetude, the question of conversion does
not seem to have died out entirely, for we <span class="t5 t14 t15 t24 t27 hoverable">find</span> recorded in the Rivayat
literature that a heated polemic regarding the subject was carried on during
the latter part of the eighteenth century. With the beginning of economic
prosperity, the Indian Parsis, we learn, were in the habit of purchasing male
and female slaves of low Hindu castes. These slaves, in many cases, were
invested with sacred shirt and girdle and admitted into the Zoroastrian fold
by the priests at the request of their masters. Those members of the
community who were opposed to the mingling of their blood with that of
such a low class of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> denied to these converts the <span class="t10 t16 hoverable">full</span> privileges of a
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> believer. The contesting parties applied to their coreligionists in Persia
for their advice and decision in the matter. The point made by those who
favoured the cause of the [475]the converts was that the Parsis of India who
owned slaves for their <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> not only often had them admitted to the
Mazdayasnian <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> in accordance with the tenets of the religion, but also,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> and religious scruples, partook of <span class="t0 t14 t23 t24 hoverable">food</span> prepared by them, and even
permitted them, at the season festival to prepare the sacred cakes <span class="t0 t12 hoverable">used</span> for
consecration and sacrificial purposes. It was urged that having allowed the
converted slaves all such rights of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> Zoroastrian in their lifetime, certain
priests as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as laymen objected to the corpses of these slaves being
deposited in the Tower of Silence when they died. The Iranian <span class="t17 t29 hoverable">high</span> priests,
in replying to their inquiring brothers in India advised them in the beginning

to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">take</span> precautionary measures in all such conversions that no harm should
thereby be done to the religion and to the community. It was certainly an act
of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> merit, they proceeded, to purchase alien <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">children</span> and <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> them up
as Zoroastrians. It was unfair and highly objectionable, they added, nay it
was an inexpiable sin, to refuse these unfortunate <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> all the privileges of
a believer after once admitting them into the Zoroastrian religious fold. It is
taught by the scriptures, they argued, that all mankind will be <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> over
to the religion of Mazda in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of the future saviour prophets. It was,
therefore, the pious duty of every <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> Zoroastrian to help this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> cause by
leading all to the path of righteousness. In the <span class="t3 hoverable">face</span> of such commands, they
concluded, those who denied to the proselytes the <span class="t10 t16 hoverable">full</span> rights of a faithful
believer did not deserve to be <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> Zoroastrians. On another occasion in
reply to a question about the conversion of such low-class people, the
Iranian informant wrote that even a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who dug graves or followed the
profession of burning the dead (two inexpiable sins according to
Zoroastrianism), should be admitted into the Zoroastrian fold, provided his
admittance <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> not be harmful to the faith.
The <span class="t9 t19 hoverable">fear</span> that the community might be swamped by the undesirable alien
element was a <span class="t1 t11 t16 t20 t25 t27 t28 hoverable">reason</span> why proselytizing fell into disfavour. We notice in
that discussion that the different sections of the community were divided
more on the social side of the question of proselytizing than on its religious
side. The protest was chiefly based against the admixture of racial blood that
the low class of the aliens introduced into the community. The Zoroastrians
of Persia, who were trampled under the iron [476]foot of their Moslem
conquerors and had lived in servile state, saw no objection whatsoever in
receiving converts even from the lowest strata of the non-Zoroastrian
peoples. But the <span class="t5 t16 t21 t24 t25 hoverable">case</span> was different with the Indian Parsis, among whom the
improved social and economic conditions had aroused a keen <span class="t0 t1 t7 t12 t13 t14 t17 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">sense</span> of racial
pride and <span class="t0 t1 t13 t16 t24 t25 hoverable">consciousness</span> of their past greatness. A very considerable portion
of the community, it seems, looked with disapproval <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the introduction
of the undesirable element of alien races into their small numbers. This
strong feeling was aggravated the more through the <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> that such converts
who sought admission came always from the lowest classes. Members of the
upper classes of the non-Zoroastrian communities were not <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t18 hoverable">heard</span> knocking
at the door of the Mazdayasnian fire-temples seeking admission. The

community was not disposed to any <span class="t23 hoverable">kind</span> of active religious propaganda. The
cases of conversion were consequently confined either to the slaves <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span>
up in Parsi families or to the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">children</span> <span class="t9 t24 hoverable">born</span> to Parsi <span class="t3 hoverable">fathers</span> of their nonZoroastrian mistresses. Proselytizing came to be associated with the low type
of foreign element, and fell into disrepute. A beginning of opposition to the
<span class="t0 hoverable">idea</span> of religious propaganda was <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> made when the entire question of
proselytizing came to be looked <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> by the community with disfavour. No
serious attempt has since been made by the Parsis of India to organize a
proselytizing movement with the sole <span class="t24 t25 hoverable">object</span> of propagating their faiths But
the <span class="t0 t10 t11 t17 t25 t28 t29 hoverable">desire</span> on the part of some Zoroastrians to include in the <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">children</span>
<span class="t9 t24 hoverable">born</span> to them by illegitimate intercourse with non-Zoroastrian mistresses, or
by others seeking a matrimonial alliance with alien women and investing the
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">children</span> <span class="t9 t24 hoverable">born</span> of such unions with the sacred shirt and girdle, has prompted
them to open the question from <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> to the present day. So bitter
have been the controversies <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> arising that they have stopped just short of
<span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> violence.
[477]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LIV
GUJARATI LITERATURE BEARING <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">UPON</span> ZOROASTRIANISM
The last native version of the Avesta independent of the influence of
Western scholarship. So far the Parsi scholars had generally <span class="t2 t11 t15 t19 t25 t27 hoverable">written</span> in the
Persian language, a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of which was limited to a very narrow circle,
and the general public accordingly did not profit by their work. The need
had <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> been felt of producing theological literature in the language of the
people, and several portions of the Persian Rivayats had already been done
into Gujarati. These were followed during the early part of the last century
by a Gujarati version of the Avestan texts, not from the original, but based
on the Pahlavi, Sanskrit, and Persian renderings. This was the last native
attempt to render the Avestan scriptures into another language through the
medium of the Pahlavi translation. The Sanskrit, Persian, and Gujarati
translators had all successively made their renderings on the basis of the
traditional Pahlavi version; it was <span class="t1 t7 t12 t29 hoverable">left</span> for the modern philologists to
approach the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> in the original itself, independently of the

Pahlavi rendering <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> aided by it, and through the methods of strict
linguistic science to give an independent and first-hand translation of the
original Avestan texts. Rendering of other Persian <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> into Gujarati. The
Persian Zartusht Namah was rendered into <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">verse</span> in Gujarati by Mobad
Rustam Peshutan Hamajiar in the early part of the eighteenth century1. The
Gujarati version of the Avesta was soon followed by a translation of some of
the important Pazand-Persian <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> into Gujarati. The most popular among
these were Jamaspi and Arda Viraf Namah. The prognostications of the
former treatise fascinated the gentler sex, who were regaled by the recital of
its contents from the lips of the family priest, [478]or of some male member
of the family who happened to know the language. Viraf's <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of the
beatific visions of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> and the horrors of hell appeared in illustrated
lithographed editions. The pictures of the heavenly persons seated on golden
thrones, and of the wicked falling headlong into hell to be gnawed by
noxious creatures, served vividly to <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> the abstract ethical teachings,
before the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> of young and old. Some devotional literature, both in prose
and verse, appeared during this period. In the same connection, it may be
added that the episodes of the Persian kings and warriors, handed down from
antiquity by tradition, were rendered into Gujarati, and were most enthusiastically read or <span class="t1 t2 t3 t6 t18 hoverable">heard</span> by all. This helped to <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> home to them the greatness
and <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">glory</span> of their ancestors.
1 Meherbanu and Behramgore Anklesaria's Zartosht Namun, Bombay, 1932.

A PERIOD OF REVIVAL
NINETEENTH CENTURY AND AFTER

[481]

CHAPTER LV
MODERNISM VERSUS TRADITIONALISM
The modern <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> is divided between Modernism and Traditionalism.
Religions rest on <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> revelation. This revealed <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> is static. Secular
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> progresses with <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> and, by continuous research and discovery
in the realm of the physics of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> and the laws of life, creates new
knowledge. It knows no end and is ever new. It adapts itself to the times and
satisfies the cravings of the thinking minds. From the earliest times, religion
spoke with authority on matters relating to the spirit. But there were <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span>
problems for which the inquisitive <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> always demanded solution. Science
claimed to make new discoveries in the realm of <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> researches.
Religion adopted science as its handmaid and incorporated the discoveries of
the scientists and the physicists and proclaimed them as the further <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span>
revelation to mankind to explain <span class="t1 hoverable">physical</span> questions. The crude cosmologies
and cosmogonies of the times when science was in its infancy were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span>
made integral parts of the religions of the world. The researches of modern
science have rendered them untenable in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of advanced knowledge.
The doctrine of evolution has revolutionized man's outlook <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
throughout the world. Modern science has changed the attitude of the
thinking <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> everywhere. The intellectual ferment and <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> unrest
have stirred the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">whole</span> world. The enlightened youths are driven to disbelief.
They are not happy in the <span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">state</span> of disbelief. They are anxious to believe and
secure peace of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> but they cannot honestly subscribe to the beliefs in
which they are <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> up. They are disbelievers despite themselves. This
<span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">state</span> of disbelief is produced by honest doubt.
Orthodoxy is obstinacy to forget anything old and learn anything new.
Orthodoxy has always and everywhere professed that the doctrines, dogmas,
rituals, and the established views of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> that a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> has inherited are fixed
and right. All those that dissent from them are heterodox, other than right,
not right, [482]that is, wrong. Orthodoxy has always numbers on its side, for
the average <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> is temperamentally timid and conservative and is unwilling
to be disturbed in the thoughts and views he has inherited with his birth. He
seeks refuge in tradition and is content to live secure in the dead past. All
that is handed down from remote times and forms the tradition of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span>

is sacred. Orthodoxy is jealous of the views it holds and resents all
opposition to them. It aims at making <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> religious in its own way. It
moves about with prying <span class="t2 t6 t19 t20 t26 t29 hoverable">eyes</span> and spies on its neighbour's conscience and
struggles to read his thoughts. Whenever it is powerful enough to inflict its
will <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> others, it clips the wing of thought, gags speech, and cripples
action. The collective orthodox <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> controls the thinking of the <span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span>
and drives the dissenters to secrete their thoughts in the lowest depths of
their souls. Orthodoxy makes <span class="t1 t8 hoverable">free</span> thinking taboo and fails to see that <span class="t17 t29 hoverable">high</span>
thinking is impossible <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> <span class="t1 t8 hoverable">free</span> thinking. Orthodoxy is impervious to the
influence of the times.
[483]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LVI
THE REVIVAL OF LEARNING AMONG THE PARSIS
Awakening of the communal conscience. The advent of the British in India,
and an era of peace, justice, and security of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> and property, ushered in by
them, opened a new page in the history of the Parsis. Having a ready scope,
the means of adaptation, and also elasticity in their religion, they now began
to assert their latent capacity, and soon emerged from the obscurity in which
they had lived, to become henceforth the foremost <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> in India in matters
educational, industrial, and social. They came in the vanguard of progress,
amassed vast fortunes, and munificently gave away large sums in charity.
This unprecedented economic prosperity helped the revival of learning
among the Zoroastrians. The new epoch of the revival of learning gave new
hopes for a period of formation and life. Various educational institution had
been founded, and the Parsis faced the problem of the responsibility of
universal franchise in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> of letters. The average Parsi child of both the
sexes entered the schools founded on European lines by the community
during the first half of the last century, in various centres of Parsi population,
and education on Western standards spread with accelerated rapidity.
The new <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> profoundly modified the religious conceptions of the
young. The inroads of Western ideas and culture undermined the old ideals,
and modified many of the beliefs sanctified by ages. It was the opening of a
new age for the Parsis, in which they witnessed the waning of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of

authority and the waxing of the demand for the verification of religious
truths. The transition from the old to the new was bound to be disruptive.
The new <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> that had <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> hold of the community stirred it to its lowest
depth. It threatened the community with an intellectual revolt from the new
school. The reaction was bound to come, and come it did. It was violent as
all reaction is apt to be, and it ended in indifferentism. The [484]popular
creed as propounded by the traditionalist exponents and orthodox formalists
failed to carry conviction to their intellect. They wanted to verify their
doubts and refused to believe that which, as they said, was not in accord
with reason. The glowing accounts of the reward and retribution of the
materialized <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> and hell ceased to act <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the imagination of the
educated classes. The imaginings of Viraf failed to exert any restraining
influence over the tendency to sin. The inspired visions of this seer, about
the scenes of the hereafter, depicting the pleasures of the souls of the <span class="t2 t15 t24 hoverable">blessed</span>
in paradise and the agonies of the wicked in hell, which satisfied the <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span>
cravings of their elders for ages, failed longer so to do in the <span class="t5 t16 t21 t24 t25 hoverable">case</span> of the new
generation. The waters of Ardvisur had inundated the regions of hell and
quenched the blazing fire, the horrors of hell had vanished into thin air, and
the apocalyptic <span class="t1 t11 t12 t13 t16 t18 t21 t23 t24 t26 t29 hoverable">account</span> of Viraf no longer presented to the minds of the
enlightened youth what they had to the strictly orthodox. A treatment of the
unfortunate souls, such as was portrayed traditionally, seemed to them
monstrous, and subverting man's <span class="t0 hoverable">idea</span> of the goodness of Ohrmazd. They
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> them to be crude and archaic. The germs of new <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> were
sprouting among the young, and they viewed these theological problems
with a changed attitude. They gradually became estranged from all beliefs
that had been instilled into them from childhood. They aimed at reconciling
religion and contemporary knowledge, and bringing religious beliefs and
practices into closer relation with the intellectual ways and thought. Parsi
orthodoxy resented it.
An illiterate priesthood failed to satisfy the intellectual wants of the
enlightened youth. The Parsi priesthood had <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> before degenerated into
ignorance. The situation was not keenly felt so <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> as the laity was equally
illiterate. But now when the latter sought enlightenment, the clergy had kept
less and less abreast of the times. During the <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> period of twelve centuries,
very few priests rose above mediocrity. The priest hitherto had acted as an

intercessor between the layman and Ohrmazd, and through elaborate ritual
had undertaken to gain for him <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> help, being duly paid to recite
penitential prayers for the expiation of the sins of the living, and to <span class="t3 t5 t10 t16 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">sacrifice</span>
for the purchase of paradise for the dead. The youth of the new school
argued that there was no more need of the Mobad's mediation between him
[485]and his Heavenly Father. He demanded that the priest should act as a
moral preceptor, a <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> ministrant to his soul. This, in those times, the
priest could not do. He could not widen his religious outlook and adapt
himself to the demand of the younger generation. The youth now grew up
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> religious instruction and gradually gravitated towards indifferentism.
The apathy, callousness, and disregard towards religion on the part of the
educated youth waxed stronger <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> by day, and culminated in an
atmosphere of agnosticism that withered the beliefs in which they were
<span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> up. Agnosticism became the threatening <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> of the day.
[486]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LVII
INTRODUCTION OF THE WESTERN METHOD OF IRANIAN
SCHOLARSHIP IN INDIA
Parsi scholarship at this period. Up to that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> had been
almost wholly interpreted by the Zoroastrian authorities through the help of
their Pahlavi translations. The original Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> had remained largely
unintelligible <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> the Pahlavi version. It was not then known that the
Gathas were composed in metre, much less the <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> that some other minor
<span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> were also metrical. The rudiments of Avestan grammar that various
inflections modified the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> had been a <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> forgotten fact.
This was due to the circumstance that, owing to the inflectional poverty of
the Pahlavi language, the translators had resorted to the <span class="t1 hoverable">use</span> of particles and
very often had even dropped this only means of indicating the syntactical
relation of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> in a sentence, and had contented themselves with
rendering an inflected Avestan <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> by its uninflected crude Pahlavi
equivalent. Firdausi and other Moslem writers were the sole informants of
the Parsi scholars regarding the <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> and legendary history of Iran. As
these did not record the doings of the Achaemenian kings, the Parsi

community remained <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> any inkling of the greatness and <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">glory</span> of the
illustrious Parsi kings of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> Persian empire. European history had now
for the first <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> startled the English-educated Parsi youth with the
information that there once flourished a mighty dynasty of rulers whom the
modern Parsi can claim as his kith and kin. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> had been denied for
centuries to their legitimate descendants in India and Persia that a Cyrus or a
Darius, a Xerxes or an Artaxerxes, who had carried the Persian banner in war
to the farthest ends of the world, were historically their own coreligionists.
In vain did the august Farohar of Darius hover round the rock of Behistan for
over <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> <span class="t6 hoverable">thousand</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> in pious expectation of some Parsi traveller who
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> one <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> trace his steps [487]to this hallowed place, climb the rock to
read the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> king's record, make it known to the world, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> earn the
royal monarch's blessings whispered in the solemn silence by as many
tongues as there were wedges and angles in the letters of the carved
inscriptions. Such, in short, was the deplorable <span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">state</span> of Parsi scholarship
when comparative philology came to its aid from the West and opened a
new era of critical study in the field of Iranian researches.
Introduction of the science of comparative philology among the Parsis.
Since the year 1771, when that worthy pioneer of romantic renown in
Iranian studies, Anquetil du Perron, published his volumes containing the
first European translation of the Avesta, or Sacred <span class="t6 t8 t10 t11 t16 t20 t21 t27 t28 hoverable">Book</span> of Zoroaster, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
strides forward have been made in Europe and America in the realm of
Iranian research. The field is now replete with the lasting monuments of
Western scholarship <span class="t0 t5 t8 t10 t14 t15 t21 t24 t28 hoverable">whether</span> in the department of standard editions of the
sacred <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> or the compilation of grammars and dictionaries or again in the
preparation of scientific translations as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as in making exegetical,
philological and archeological researches. The service that these scholars
have rendered to the Parsis is greater than can ever be expressed. To K. R.
Kama, Parsi pioneer of the Iranian studies on Western lines in India, who had
studied the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> in Europe under the German savant Spiegel, is due
the credit of introducing among Parsi scholars the science of comparative
philology and the scientific method of interpreting their sacred books. The
inauguration of this new era belongs to the early part of the <span class="t0 t2 t5 t13 t14 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">second</span> half of
the last century.

Textual criticism brings startling revelation for the Parsis. The first
outcome of the critical study of the Avestan literature, as may be judged
from intimations given above, was the discovery made by the Western
scholars that the grammar, style, and internal evidence of the extant Avestan
<span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> show that they were not composed at a single period and by one
person, but that they were the products of many persons who worked at
various times. Scholars such as these undertook to determine the
approximate dates of the component parts of the Avesta. The Gathas were
shown to be the oldest in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> of composition and the authorship of a
considerable portion, if not all, of these [488]hymns was ascribed to
Zoroaster himself.. The prophet's work, it was said, was continued by his
immediate disciples, and must have extended over a very <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> period after
him, even <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">though</span> the immediate impression made by Zoroaster himself may
be acknowledged to have become fainter in succeeding generations. The
religion of the Younger Avesta had departed in certain respects from the
religion of the Gathas, and the subsequent compositions showed signs of
degeneration both in substance and style. The simple and abstract <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of
the Gathas was blurred if not lost, and the development of the later <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span>
tended to become more complex and concrete. We breathe a different
atmosphere, they declared, when we <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t11 t12 t19 t22 hoverable">pass</span> from the Gathic to the Later
Avestan field. Nature-worship, which Zoroaster strove to supplant by a
<span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span> type of ethical religion, was shown to have been reinstated in these
later texts. The masses could not be weaned from the beliefs that loomed
large in their eyes, and thus, the scholars maintained, many practices
abolished by Zoroaster were later resuscitated by the clergy. Startling indeed
were these new ideas that philological re searches <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> to the Parsis, who
had been accustomed to at tribute indiscriminately all Avestan compositions
to Zoroaster himself and who never approached their own sacred books with
a historical perspective.
Back to the Gathas was the war-cry of the new school. This critical
estimate of their scripture by the Iranian scholars of the West greatly
influenced the young Parsi scholars in India. They now hailed the Gathas as
providing a self-sufficient religious system in themselves. They claimed to
have discovered the only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> mirror in which the genuine teachings of
Zoroaster were, reflected. The Later Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> were declared to render

nugatory the pristine purity. An exuberant outgrowth of dogmatic theology
and ceremonial observances, they asserted, had supplanted the buoyant
simplicity of the Gathic teachings, and simply' represented a decline from
the pure teachings of Zoroaster. The names of the Amshaspands in the
Gathas were considered to be merely descriptive of the attributes of
Ohrmazd. These attributes, they insisted, had crystallized into concrete
beings, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> converting the monotheistic religion of Zoroaster into a
veritable system of polytheism. Tradition, they argued, attributed to
Zoroaster doctrines that he never preached. They advocated a return to the
[489]original purity of the <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> by stripping off the accretions that had
gathered round the pure canon of the prophet, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> removing the haze of
ignorance and bigotry that had overclouded the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of their excellent
religion. All this was highly sacrilegious to orthodox ears. Such statements
roused the strong resentment of the community and elicited vehement
protests from priests and laymen alike. The new school was assailed on all
sides. More sober opinion intervened to modify the sweeping assertions, and
declared that while the Gathas, of course, should be <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> as the norm, there
should also be admitted into the Zoroastrian canon such parts of the later
scriptures as were in accord with the Gathic spirit; but whatever could not be
traced to the Gathas was adventitious, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> not deserving of
acceptance. The problem at once arose as to who was going to distinguish
the authoritative from the un-authoritative and a new controversy opened
amid still more bitter feelings.
A new theory to defend the Gathas from the accusation of dualism. The
salient feature of dualism in the Iranian <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> has ever been the chief point
assailed by the non-Zoroastrians, both in <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> and modern times,
whenever they have entered into religious disputations with the followers of
the prophet. They have laid the doctrine of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> to the charge of
Zoroastrianism. The accidentals of the controversy have varied materially in
their character at different periods, but the main point of contention has ever
remained the same. We have already seen how vehemently the learned
prelates of the Pahlavi period strove to vindicate this characteristic feature of
the Zoroastrian teachings. Far from considering it a weak point, they hailed
it the only possible solution of the problem of evil. Not so their modern
descendants. The repeated attack of the Christian missionaries, and the

strong influence of the Western literature, which hailed monotheism as the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t22 t23 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">highest</span> category of theology, <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> about an unprecedented change in
this belief; and so powerful has this influence been, that we hardly ever <span class="t5 t14 t15 t24 t27 hoverable">find</span>
even at this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> any learned Parsi priest or layman marshalling arguments in
vindication of the doctrine. Attempts are now generally made either to
explain it away by ingenious arguments or to <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of it apologetically. Haug
was the first to <span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> it to the notice of the Parsis that [490]the leading <span class="t0 hoverable">idea</span>
of the Gathas was monotheism. Ahura Mazda, he declared, is the supreme
godhead, who has produced the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> rival principles Spenta Mainyu and
Angra Mainyu as his twin spirits. Separated as they seem, they are united in
action. They are indispensable to each other in the formation and conduct of
the universe. They are the creative and the destroying, constructive and
destructive powers of God, and are as inseparable from each other as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> and
night. The opposition rests with the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> rival spirits, and nowhere in the
Gathas does Angra Mainyu, the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> Spirit, stand in direct opposition to
Ahura Mazda. This fundamental distinction, he said, is lost sight of in the
late period, and we <span class="t5 t14 t15 t24 t27 hoverable">find</span> in the Vendidad that the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Good</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Spirit</span> Spenta Mainyu
is identified with Ahura Mazda himself, and the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Spirit</span> Angra Mainyu
stands in direct antagonism to God. The Parsi scholars who were ever in
search for some new arguments to remove the so-called weak point of their
<span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> eagerly embraced this new explanation, which, they thought, saved the
Gathas at least from the stain of dualism. If the Vendidad and other later
<span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> introduced it in the Zoroastrian theology, it was a decided fall, they
claimed, from the original pure monotheism. The prophet himself never
taught dualism, they argued, and it is unfair to ascribe that doctrine to him,
for which the enlightened youth had to blush before modern criticism!
[491]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LVIII
CHRISTIAN MISSIONARIES ATTACK ZOROASTRIANISM
Indifference on the part of the Parsi youth arouses the proselytizing zeal
of the Christian missionaries. These <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> that they could easily turn the
apathy of the newly educated Parsi youth for his own religion to interest in
the <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> of Jesus, if they could convince him of the superiority of

Christianity over his national creed. The impressionable youth once secured,
they imagined, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> prove a valuable asset in bringing over his enlightened
coreligionists to the Christian fold. Christianity <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> easily spread
downwards among the masses, they thought, if only they could capture the
upper educated classes. The missionaries felt that this handful of the
progressive people, who approached nearest to the Western <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> in their
modes of living, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> ultimately be easily won over to their faith. With this
<span class="t24 t25 hoverable">object</span> in <span class="t25 hoverable">view</span> some of them began to study the Zoroastrian scriptures first
hand, during the latter part of the first half of the last century. They picked
out what seemed to them to be vulnerable points in the Zoroastrian faith,
and exposed them to the ridicule of the Parsi youth newly tinged with
Western ideas. The community was alarmed at this aggression, the more so
when a couple of converts were actually made to Christianity from this class.
Salient features of Zoroastrianism assailed by the missionaries. The
religion of Zoroaster, the controversialists alleged, abounded in absurdities
and incongruities. It was based on the idolatry of nature. The Parsi scholars
repudiated the accusation with indignation, and said that in their reverence
for the elements of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> they never worshipped fire, sun, and such other
elements, but venerated the angels presiding over these noble productions of
God, holding them to be his purest symbols.1 1. A Parsi Priest, Tâlim-i
Zurtoosht, p. 15, Bombay, 1840; Aspandiarji, Hâdie Gum Râhân (Eng. version),
p. 44, Bombay, 1841. [492]An erroneous rendering of Vd. 19. 9 had led
Anquetil du Perron, the first translator of the Avestan <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">text</span> into a European
tongue, to depict Boundless <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> as the first principle of the Universe.2 This
interpretation was <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> as an unequivocal testimony of the Zoroastrian
scriptures to corroborate the statement of the Greek and Armenian writers
who had alleged that both Ohrmazd and Ahriman had sprung from Time.
Anquetil's mistake was repeated in the <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> of the European writers for a
considerable time, until it was finally corrected by the unanimous verdict of
the Iranian scholars of the West during the latter half of the last century.
When the Zoroastrian scriptures were adversely criticized by the
missionaries on the ground that the doctrine of Boundless <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> at the apex
of existence proved the derivative and secondary character of Ormazd,3 the
Parsi priests repudiated the charge and vigorously maintained that the
concept simply designated eternity and nothing more. Far from being

Ormazd's superior, Boundless Time, they affirmed was his creation. 2. ZendAvesta, vol. 1, p. 414; vol. 2, p. 592, Paris 1771.
3. Wilson, The Parsi Religion, p. 134, Bombay, 1843. More heated was the
controversy that hinged <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the alleged belief of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> rival spirits. We have
already seen 'how dualism has been the main question of inveterate
controversies,; we shall here only advert to it in passing When the missionaries derisively <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> the Parsis the worshippers of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> gods, which certainly
they never were, they at once vehemently denied the charge and hastened to
repudiate it by denying downright an objective existence to Ahriman. The
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> Spirit, they argued, is not an entity, but merely the symbolic
personification of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> owing his origin to man's errant
thoughts. Outside of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> he has no existence at all. He is a gratuitous
invention. The concept of his existence is purely negative, a chimera. He is
man's creation, as are also the infernal host of demons and fiends, which are
nothing more than the lusts and passions of man.4
4. A Parsi Priest, Tâlim-i Zurtoosht, p. 62-64, 83, 84; Aspandiarji, Hâdie Gum
Râhân (Eng. version); p. 35-37, 73, 74. Parsi apologists meet the charges of
their opponents by resorting to allegorical explanations. This attempt at
giving allegorical interpretations of the scriptures was carried still further.
Tradition had always seen some geographical data in the first [493]chapter
of the Vendidad, and modern scholarship had accepted that view; but in
their polemics with the missionaries the Parsi scholars explained the opening
of the <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">chapter</span> by asserting that the act of Ohrmazd in creating Iran Vej, the
first region of the world, was to be interpreted as a mere figurative expression
for religious faith, and Ahriman's counter <span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> of winter was emblematic
of infidelity. Similarly, the various places said to have been created by
Ohrmazd indicated man's body, and the obnoxious creatures of Ahriman
signified man's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> passions.5 Another instance of the same <span class="t23 hoverable">kind</span> of
interpretation may be cited. Druj Nasu, or the Demon of Defilement is
spoken of in the Vendidad as taking possession of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> who has touched
the corpse of a dog or a man,6 and a minute description is given as to how
the demon is successively driven out from the top of the <span class="t1 t4 t9 t16 hoverable">head</span> of the defiled
<span class="t0 t4 t5 t10 t22 t25 t28 hoverable">person</span> to the tips of his toes, as the ablution ceremony is being performed.
This rite was criticized as being revolting to common sense.7 Instead of

defending it on hygienic principles, the learned controversialists again
expatiated <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the mystic significance of the text, and alleged that the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">whole</span> ceremony referred to the internal purification of man, and that Nasu
represented his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> nature, while the successive expulsion of the fiend from
one part of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> to the other, until finally eradicated, meant the gradual
improvement of a man's character.8 Zoroastrianism teaches that the <span class="t2 t5 t8 t17 t18 t19 hoverable">sin</span> of
burying corpses is inexpiable.9 The pulling down of the dakhmas, wherein lie
interred the dead bodies of such men, is a means of the expiation of one's
sins in thought, word, and deed; and is equivalent to the recital of a Patit.10
Responding to a criticism on this passage, recourse was again <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> to
declare it as couched in mysterious language. It was curiously explained to
mean that the dakhma referred to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> of man, the corpse stood for his
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> passions, its disinterment meant the expulsion of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> propensities,
and the final exposure to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t18 t19 t21 t22 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">sun</span> signified the enlightenment of
the inner <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> by the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> wisdom.11
5. A Parsi Priest, Tâlim-i Zurtoosht, p. 35, 36.
6. Vd. 8. 35-71.
7. Wilson, The Parsi Religion, p. 161.
8. Aspandiarji, Hâdie Gum Râhân (Eng. version), p. 74; A Parsi Priest Tâtim-i
Zurtoosht, p. 180.
9. Vd. 1. 12; 3. 38, 39.
10. Vd. 7. 51; 13. 57.
11. Aspandiarji, Hâdie Gum Râhân, p. 79, 80.
[494] The outcome of this controversy. The Parsis further retaliated by
seizing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the weak points of the Christian scriptures and turning them
into ridicule, just as we have seen, the author of the Shikand Gumanik Vijar
did in the Pahlavi period. Theological questions were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> discussed with
acrimonious zeal on both sides, and a considerable polemic literature was

produced. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> that came out of this controversy was that the study of
their own religion began to be prosecuted by the Parsi priests with greater
avidity than before.
[495]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LIX
THE REFORM MOVEMENT
Crusade against the non-Zoroastrian practices engrafted <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span>
Zoroastrianism. The compromises and concessions made on the part of the
early Parsi settlers in India were needed to conciliate the prejudices of the
Hindu rulers. The Parsis were a handful of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> living in the midst of the
teeming millions of India, and even the twelve centuries of their residence in
this country have failed to merge them in the ocean of Indian humanity. This
<span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> is largely due to their intensely communal spirit, fostered by the dread of
being assimilated into greater communities, and of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> losing their
individuality. But the average Parsi did not fail to borrow many superstitious
customs and habits from the Hindus as <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> as from the Mohammedans during the later period. The Hindu augur and the Moslem diviner became
important factors in the family <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the Parsis. These seers were <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">called</span> in to
cast the horoscope of the new-born Zoroastrian child; they foretold the
future, administered amulets to heal every sickness and disease in the family,
prescribed charms to ward off the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> eye, exorcised demoniacal influences
from persons possessed by the powers of darkness, and, in many ways,
proved indispensable auxiliaries to a Parsi from birth to death. The mediation
of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Brahman</span> or of a Mullah was often rated <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span> than that of a Mobad,,
and a Sanskrit mantra or an Arabic kalma was regarded more efficacious for
the purchase of heavenly boons than an Avestan manthra. The Zoroastrian
priest ruled in the fire-temple, but the non-Zoroastrian priest had a powerful
sway over the hearts of the Parsi populace. With rich offerings did the
faithful repair to the tombs of Moslem saints and to Hindu shrines. They laid
their <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> all altars and turned to strange <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">gods</span> in their extremities. The
grandeur of the Mazdayasnian teachings had faded, and Zoroaster had partly
ceased to be a living force in the <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the community. [496]Many
alien customs had <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">thus</span> worked their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> into Zoroastrianism. These were

hard facts for the orthodox to admit but they were facts all the same. With
the vigour of youth and with unquenchable zeal the reformers of that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span>
undertook to liberate the community from the thraldom of superimposed
non-Zoroastrian customs, and to wean it from superstitions.
The reformers protested against reciting their prayers parrot-wise in an
unintelligible language. The Avesta language had <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> since fallen into
disuse. It was not a living language. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Yet</span> the belief in its being of celestial
origin, the tongue in which Ohrmazd addressed his heavenly court, and even
that in which Ahriman harangued his ribald crew, had preserved it as the
only <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> vehicle for conveying prayers. The reformers now argued that it
was meaningless to mumble an unintelligible gibberish which neither the
priest himself nor the layman understood. Ejaculations and genuflexions were
of no avail, when they recited their prayers in a dead language. No amount
of such formulas <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> affect the character of the devotees and ennoble their
