thoughts. A prayer that had no subjective value was no prayer. It failed to
awaken any ethical fervour, for a truly devout prayer should spur the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span>
<span class="t0 t1 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t28 t29 hoverable">within</span> to a <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span> life. This was not possible so <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> as the priest
perfunctorily droned prayers, not a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> of which was understood. The
orthodox vehemently retorted that the Avestan language Was divine, and as
such it possessed inherent magical efficacy. Miraculously composed as these
Avestan prayers were, they had indescribable objective value, it was claimed,
quite independent of the motive of one who recited them. The mere
utterance of the sacred texts, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> knowing in the least what they meant,
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> produce marvellous effect. The ultra-orthodox viewed the situation
with pious dread and entertained serious apprehension that, if once the
community permitted the <span class="t1 hoverable">use</span> of Gujarati or English compositions for daily
prayers, nothing short of a revolutionary change <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> come, and with the
lapse of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be supplanted by prayer-books
composed in the modern vernaculars. The reformers pointed out that there
already existed some monajat prayers composed in Persian by some of the
learned Dasturs even in their own lifetime, which the orthodox were using
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> any scruple at the end of their daily Avestan prayers. [497]A fierce
controversy raged around this question, with the result that the orthodox
<span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">went</span> on praying in their own way, and the reformers, neither having <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> in
the recital of their prayers in an unintelligible language nor having a proper

substitute to satisfy their demand, <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">went</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> prayers of any kind. And the
situation remains, in large measure, unchanged up to this very day.
The Avesta <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">text</span> metamorphosed into an ungrammatical jargon. The
reformers further said that the Avestan <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> were recited with the most
incorrect pronunciations. In vindication of their statement they quoted
passages from the original <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> and put by their side the corrupt formulas in
vogue in the community. An example of this <span class="t23 hoverable">kind</span> may not be out of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span>
here, and we shall insert the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t7 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">text</span> of Ahunavar, the most important
Zoroastrian formula, first in its correct <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> and then in the corrupt <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span>
which obtains among a considerable portion of the community up to this
hour. The original formula is as follows :
yathâ ahu vairyo athâ ratush ashât chit hachâ
vangheush dazdâ manangho shyaothananâm angheush Mazdâi
khshathremchâ ahurâi â yim dregubyo dadat vâstârem.
The corrupt <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of the same:
athâu veryo thâre tose sâde chide châvanghoise dezdâ manengho sotthenanâm anghyos
Mazdâe khosetharamchâe orâe âiyem daregobyo daredar vâstârem.
This, however, did not trouble the orthodox, for they complacently
remarked that as <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> as they had implicit <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> in what they recited, and
recited it whole-heartedly, it mattered very little <span class="t0 t5 t8 t10 t14 t15 t21 t24 t28 hoverable">whether</span> they <span class="t0 t12 hoverable">used</span> correct
pronunciation or not. Ohrmazd looked to their hearts, and not to their <span class="t0 t1 t7 t12 t13 t14 t17 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">sense</span>
of grammar and orthography. So <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> as their motives were good, their
prayers were acceptable to the Heavenly Father. The redeeming feature of
this entire controversy has been a growing tendency in the community to
avail itself of the help of the philologist, who has <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> nearer home to
them the correct and carefully edited version of their sacred scriptures, and
they have consequently begun to recite their daily prayers from books that
have based their <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> on the standard and authorized version of the liturgy.
[498] Too much ritualism, protested the reformer. The mechanical
handling of the ritual, which was as much unintelligible in its real purport to
the priest who performed it as it was to the layman who ordered it, failed to
satisfy the new school. The orthodox maintained that although the priestly

authorities themselves had lost the key of the mysteries of the ceremonies
and were unable to understand their meaning, nevertheless untold <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> accrued to those who devoutly ordered such ceremonies for their own merit.
They entertained a pious hope that the lost key <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> be
recovered, and the hidden secrets <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of the day. The
reformers urged that a vast structure of formalism and ritual had replaced the
edifice of the simple faith, and religion had simply turned into ritualism.
They dwelt especially on the subjective value of the ritual, and argued that
however elaborate and expensive the ceremony might be, it was of no value
if it failed to symbolize a moral <span class="t0 hoverable">idea</span> for the faithful who ordered it.
Ceremonial observances, they complained, were given greater importance
than moral observance. Righteousness was identified with rituals. They were
only a clothing of religion, but the ethical substance of religion was of
greater importance than the clothing itself. Religion, they urged, does not
consist in laying up merit by ceremonials. The orthodox retorted that the
ritual as such had an intrinsic value and inherent merit, and the more such
rites were performed, the greater was the merit assured to the faithful. The
new school said that these ceremonials may perhaps serve as a means of
conveying ethical ideas to a backward people, but the Parsis were not a
backward people. Hence they did not need them. Righteousness did not
depend <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> such ceremonial observances, but <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the purity of man's
inner life. Besides, the ceremonials became an economic drain on the slender
resources of the credulous poor, who incurred heavy debts for their
performance, which was displeasing in the sight of Ohrmazd. The orthodox
declared these statements an Ahrimanian onslaught <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the Mazdayasnian
rites.
The progressives denounced the intercessory prayers for the dead. The
philological researches had for the first <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">time</span> <span class="t1 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t15 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> to the notice of the
Parsis the <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> of the sharp distinction between man's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> and his Farohar.
From what has been stated in the earlier pages, it can be clearly seen how
this essential [499]difference was lost sight of, as early as during the later
Pahlavi period. The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> and the Farohar were <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> to be one and the same
by the Zoroastrians before the philologist pointed out the error. Priest and
layman, the learned and the illiterate alike, believed implicitly that the souls
of the dead profited by the ceremonials performed in their honour by their

relatives in this world. The Avestan and Pahlavi passages, which <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of the
coming of the Farohars to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">earth</span> at the period of the Fravar-digan festival,
seeking invocation and sacrifice, were understood by the entire Community
as indubitably referring to the coming of the souls of the dead.1 1. K. M.
Modi, Kholâase Majdiasne, p. 91-95, 101-106, Bombay, 1853; Suryoday, vol.
2, p. 113-117, 158-161, Bombay, 1868. According to the general conviction,
the supplications offered by the living procured either a remission of the sins
committed by the deceased in this world, or else a specific merit for the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> deeds he had done. It was this strong <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> in the efficacy of the
ceremonials to help the struggling <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> in either making its <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> out of hell,
or in ascending upwards through the graded <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">heaven</span> in the next world, that
inspired the loving and dutiful survivors to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> elaborate rituals for the
<span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> welfare of the departed. Propitiatory offerings were made, and
penitential prayers were recited to secure a better lot for the souls of the
dead, and the performance of these periodical rites was most zealously
observed. Rich viands were consecrated in the name of the deceased.
Whatever <span class="t23 hoverable">kind</span> of <span class="t0 t14 t23 t24 hoverable">food</span> or drink the departed ones had best liked in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> were
specially prepared. On the last <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> of the festival, moreover, when the souls
were believed to leave this <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> and return to that beyond, <span class="t0 t14 t23 t24 hoverable">food</span> and drink
were offered them to assuage the hunger and thirst on their return journey,
while money in copper and silver was dedicated to them to meet their
travelling expenses. The recital of the Patit, or expiatory prayer, forms an important part of the ceremonies performed in honour of the dead. The
relatives and friends of the deceased still engage a priest to recite it, and do
the same themselves for the expiation and welfare of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> when it is
embarking on its journey to the next <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> after death. The devout generally
keep up this observance daily for at least a month, or throughout the first
year, or in many cases for a still longer period. [500]The reformers <span class="t2 t4 t6 t9 t18 t19 t22 hoverable">took</span> up
the question and said that Zoroastrian-ism enjoined that a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">went</span> to the
abode of weal or woe according to his deserts, and that no amount of
ceremonials performed by the living could either mitigate his sufferings or
improve his condition in the <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> world. His sins could not be atoned for
by elaborate rituals performed in his name, nor <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> he be one whit the
happier for them. It is true, they further said, that according to the scriptures,
the benefit of the ceremonials performed for the dead accrues to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span>
during the first <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> nights after death, while it still hovers over the body,

but from the period of the dawn of the fourth day, when justice is
administered to the soul, and it is awarded its special place, the rituals do not
affect its position. Any ceremonies performed after this day, that is, on the
monthly and yearly anniversaries or on any other occasions, are mainly for
the Farohar of the dead man, and not for his soul. In fact, it was claimed,
these rites are more for the interest of the living than for the imagined
interest of the dead. Zoroastrianism, they said, never stood for any <span class="t23 hoverable">kind</span> of
vicarious salvation, for the question of salvation or damnation rested on the
individual's own deeds. Neither <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> the expiatory prayers recited by the
living wash out the sins of the dead, nor <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> the propitiatory sacrifices
offered by them induce the heavenly judges to revoke their decision. As the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> sows, so shall he reap, is the immortal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> taught by Zoroaster. Merit,
they contended, cannot be purchased at a price, and <span class="t2 t5 t8 t17 t18 t19 hoverable">sin</span> cannot be expiated
by proxy. It was destroying the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of the prophet's <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> religion to
entertain such degrading ideas of vicarious expiation which had been
fastened on Zoroastrianism. These scathing criticisms seriously wounded the
religious susceptibilities of the orthodox, who became unsparing in the vehement denunciation of the reformers, charging them as reactionaries with
carrying the religious barque to ruin. They branded the attempts of the
reformers as blasphemous and as an irreverent prying into the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> of
Ohrmazd. Bitter <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">words</span> were exchanged between the rival parties, and abuses
and invectives, ridicule and obloquy, became rampant over these and several
other controversial questions.
The <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> <span class="t0 t1 t7 t12 t13 t14 t17 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">sense</span> of the disputants saved the community from being split
into sects. The reformers were termed the [501]Parsi Protestants and were
charged with thinking in terms of Christianity. They were said to be fired by
the sole ambitition of being original, and of setting at naught the
achievements of their elders for the last <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> <span class="t6 hoverable">thousand</span> years. The reformers
replied that they were simply looking to antiquity for models for their
conduct and were profiting solely by the vast experience of the past. But at
the same time, they rejoined, the orthodox should remember that the
ancients had tackled the religious and ceremonial questions that arose in
their own <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t24 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">days</span> according to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> that had prevailed in the past. Those of
that <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">day</span> had not done the thinking for all times to come, with injunctions to
the future generations to act in strict accordance with them. They alone had

not the monopoly to think, and had not given the final mandate to acquiesce
in all that they had believed. Besides, a return to the past could not being
unalloyed happiness to the Parsis in the present times. The community, it
was urged, cannot afford to transplant itself back to the age of the Vendidad.
There was no <span class="t1 hoverable">use</span> sticking to outworn forms and seeking to give them a new
life. It was futile to attempt to support delusions, and the orthodox, they
said, should not throw all possible shackles in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">way</span> of progress by
hampering and paralyzing the well-meant efforts of the new school. Such, in
brief form, is the story of the opening of the conflict between conservative
and <span class="t1 t8 hoverable">free</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> among the Parsis in India, which rent the community into
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> sections. The rival parties, however, did not make any formal division
between themselves. The reformers did not. venture to contemplate so
complete a break with the orthodox as <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> culminate in the establishment
of a reformed Church. The orthodox could not excommunicate the
reformers even if they would. The orthodox had to content themselves with
condemning the reformers, and the reformers by satrizing the orthodox.
Even to-day the main disputes over some of these vital problems remain
much the same as they were nine decades ago, and the battle goes on, still to
be won.
[502]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LX
PARSI THEOSOPHISTS
Inquiring minds seek a deeper <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">meaning</span> of life. At this period of transition,
when the old practices seemed to have spent their force, and the younger
generation was drifting towards indifference in religious matters, there were
other forces at <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> which heralded the rise of a new class of dissenters.
Those of a prosaic and matter-of-fact turn of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> in the community had
steadily doubted the statements that did not admit of a rational justification,
and refused to believe in anything mysterious and mystical in religion. But
<span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> cannot altogether be stripped of mystery. Rationalism is not the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">whole</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> nature. Besides, the <span class="t0 t1 t10 t14 t21 t23 t25 t29 hoverable">state</span> of doubts and disbeliefs that
prevailed in the community could not last long. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> is essentially a religious
being. He feels an inherent need in himself for some <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of religious belief

which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> satisfy the yearnings of his spirit-that irrepressible heart-hunger
of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> soul. The Parsi priesthood, as custodians of the conscience of
the community, zealously guarded and conserved the dogmatic teachings
and traditions, but they were uuable to <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">work</span> for the adaptation of the
traditional material to the contemporary situation. They were incapable, at
the time, of helping the community in its religious crisis. Persons who
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> that the rationalism of the new school ignored an essential part of
<span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> when it discarded the emotional side of man, to which <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span>
was indebted for some of his noblest virtues, yearned for new light. If that
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> did not come from within, they <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> welcome it from without. At this
juncture the Theosophical <span class="t5 t11 hoverable">Society</span> opened its propaganda in India, and a
<span class="t8 t21 t27 hoverable">number</span> of Parsis eagerly embraced the movement.
Parsi theosophists. In the early eighties of the last century the Parsi
members of the Theosophical <span class="t5 t11 hoverable">Society</span> entered the arena of religious
controversy and gave new zest to it. They became a potent factor in shaping
the religious beliefs of a section of the [503]community through their active
propaganda. Hitherto ritual observances, theological dogmas, and
ecclesiastical usages had occupied a most conspicuous <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in the religious
controversies. The Parsi theosophists introduced metaphysical themes such
as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of Being, a personal or an impersonal God, <span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> or
emanation, reincarnation, and such like for discussion. This is significant as
an indication of a <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span> phase in religious polemics. They showed a strong
tendency towards mysticism in religion. They did not flee from the sight and
sound of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> and withdrew themselves to the fastness of the jungle, nor did
they mortify their flesh, but their code of ethics comprised the ascetic
virtues, tempered by the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of the age.
Custodians of the only key to Zoroastrianism. Zoroaster and his disciples,
the theosophical interpreters said, wrote in a mystic language which
conveyed a double meaning. The exoteric, or surface meaning, was intended
for the vulgar, and the esoteric, or inner meaning, was designed only for the
initiates. The adepts of various periods were the ones who possessed the
mysterious key to the chamber of hidden truths. The last of such Parsi adept
was Azar Kaivan, who died at Patna in 1614. With his <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> this key was
lost. Occult science alone, it was asserted, could explain and vindicate the

allegorical teachings of Zoroaster. Providence had <span class="t2 t15 t24 hoverable">blessed</span> the founders of
the Theosophical <span class="t5 t11 hoverable">Society</span> with the possession of a master-key that opened
the secret chambers of the hidden <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of all religions. The
Zoroastrian theosophists applied this key to Zoroastrianism to unravel the
mysteries of its exoteric teachings. They aimed at an adjustment of the
fundamental Zoroastrian concept according to the standard philosophy of
their society, which was an eclectic system drawing its materials mostly from
Hinduism and Buddhism.
The theosophists summarily rejected the method of the philologist
adopted in interpreting the sacred texts. In their zeal for discovering <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span>
truths buried under the seemingly simple texts, but alleged to be pregnant
with deep meaning, these esoterics often invested legends and myths with a
symbolic significance, and included much in the sphere of serious literature
that could be relegated to the realm of poetry. They alleged that the
philologists, being bound by the fetters of literalism in the interpretation of
the sacred texts, generally <span class="t2 t4 t6 t9 t18 t19 t22 hoverable">took</span> a statement at its <span class="t3 hoverable">face</span> value and adhered to
the surface meaning. The theosophists [504]chose to lean <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the
miraculous and mysterious, rather than to follow the recognized canons of
the method of reasoning. Consequently, the <span class="t0 t1 t7 t12 t13 t14 t17 t23 t27 t28 hoverable">sense</span> of proportion, critical
acumen, the historical sense, accurate thinking, and such preliminary
requisites of modern scholarship became conspicuous by. their absence in
most of their interpretations. Flashes of vague <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> came to be regarded
as inspiration, and visions as verities. <span class="t28 hoverable">Passage</span> after <span class="t28 hoverable">passage</span> in the Zoroastrian
scriptures was explained to signify what it did not mean in the original. The
following may be adduced as a specimen: The pastoral <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> in <span class="t21 hoverable">Ancient</span>
Iran had found a faithful sentinel in the dog, and that animal, as shown by
the Avesta, occupied an exalted <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> among the Iranians from the earliest
ages; <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> chapters of the Vendidad in <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> were devoted to this
indispensable companion of the household, All scholars in accord with the
traditional interpretation have naturally <span class="t2 t5 t11 t18 t19 t23 t26 hoverable">taken</span> these passages as the
fragments of an old Iranian canine literature. But the theosophists branded
this explanation as absurd, and discerned in the chapters an allegorical
description of conscience and its workings. Space here precludes the citation
of other examples of this kind. When the linguists challenged such
interpretation of the <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> texts, they were informed that their inability to

reconcile themselves to the new esoteric explanations was due to the <span class="t7 t12 t13 hoverable">fact</span> of
not having <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> sufficiently developed their <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> faculties. They were
dubbed 'mere philologists,' 'dry-as-dust' grammarians. Highly pungent
bitterness was marked in the controversy carried on between the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> parties.
The theosophists in this controversy denounced the philologists, and the
philologists denounced the theosophists.
Parsi theosophists as champions of the cause of orthodoxy. The advocacy
on the part of the theosophists of the revival of the past, and their seeing in
such a revival the sole panacea of communal ills, <span class="t0 t5 t8 t10 t14 t15 t21 t24 t28 hoverable">whether</span> real or imaginary,
their readiness to allege religious sanction for the time-hallowed customs,
matched with their zeal for ritual, and their eagerness to vindicate the sacred
ceremonies by giving strained allegorical interpretations to explain them,
won for them the applause of the orthodox ? party, who cast in their lot with
them. Inasmuch as the Parsi, theosophists declared that they were working to
<span class="t3 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t27 t29 hoverable">bring</span> out the youth of the community from the, trough of materialism, and
[505]endeavoring to defend Zoroastrianism against innovations of the
reformers, they were regarded as the pillars of <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> and the guardians of the
edifice of ceremonialism.
Avestan prayers, however unintelligible, were declared the most
efficacious owing to their occult significance. We have already seen the
arguments advanced by the reformers against addressing to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> prayers in a
language unintelligible to the suppliant, and we have noted the discussion
that followed. We now need only notice the part that the theosophists <span class="t2 t4 t6 t9 t18 t19 t22 hoverable">took</span>
in the controversy. The syllables composed in the Avestan texts, they
averred, were so mysteriously adjusted to each other in the prayers, that they
produced vibrations on the ethereal plane, when pronounced. The potency
of such rhythmical sound was so <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> that, like every <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t17 t18 t20 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 hoverable">thought</span> that
flashed out with strong occult force and sent forth a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> "elemental," it
created forms in the ethereal world, attracted <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> "elementals," and
repelled <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> ones. Every single sentence conveyed an occult meaning, and
the prayers composed in the celestial tongue of the prophet and other seers
had an unspeakable efficacy conducing to the welfare of the <span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span>
concerned, but their renderings into any modern vernacular <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> make
them totally ineffectual as prayers.

Zoroastrianism in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">light</span> of theosophy. These followers of an eclectic
philosophy, and interpreters of the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> scriptures through a claimed
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">knowledge</span> of occult and hidden meanings, applied the theosophic principles
of explanation to the teachings of Zoroaster, and adapted them to the
Zoroastrian theology. Such an interpretation, however, led them to credit
the religion of Zoroaster with ideas that in no period of its religious history
were ever included in its sphere. When these theosophic interpreters of
Zoroastrianism were reminded that the thoughts they claimed to read in the
canonical Zoroastrian <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> were not there, they argued with a doubtful
historical perspective that if they did not meet them in the plain words, in
the authentic texts, it was because the twenty-one Nasks of the prophet had
not been preserved. If the bulk of the Zoroastrian canon had not been
irrevocably lost, they should undoubtedly have found such doctrines to be
indissolubly associated with the cardinal <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> of the Zoroastrian faith. Every
Iranian student knows that the historical sources and records of the teachings
of the prophet that were in vogue at any particular [506]period of
Zoroastrian history have not perished altogether Something of every period,
<span class="t0 t5 t8 t10 t14 t15 t21 t24 t28 hoverable">whether</span> the Gathic, Avestan, Pahlavi, or the later periods, has fortunately
survived the vandalism of the conquering hordes and the ravages of time,
and consequently has come down to the present day. For instance, in the
controversy regarding the rebirth theory, to which we shall advert below,
the theosophic interpreters, having recourse to similar arguments, stated that
we should have found the theory of transmigration of souls taught in the
Zoroastrian works, if these had reached us intact. It might be pointed out,
however, that the fragmentary <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t7 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">works</span> of all periods of Zoroastrian history
have come down to us; they contain the authentic teachings on the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> after
death, but they all persistently and systematically <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of only one bodily
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> on the earth, and never once suggest the theory of rebirth.
Zrvan Akarana as an impersonal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> in the theosophic light. The
theosophists attempted a readjustment of the Zoroastrian doctrine of a
personal God, or rather in accordance with their theory of an impersonal
God. Personality, they alleged implied limitation and was a characteristic of
the finite. A personal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> meant that the godhead was a limited God, and
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> an incomplete God. In Zrvan Akarana, or Boundless Time, the

Parsi theosophists saw this impersonal neuter being of whom nothing could
be predicated. This supposititious being was the rootless root from which
issued Ohrmazd. Ahriman was but Ohrmazd's manifested shadow. Zrvan
Akarana, the primeval impersonal principle, according to their interpretation,
was like a central <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">fire</span> from which all <span class="t0 t1 t5 t7 t9 t11 t12 t13 t16 t17 t20 t23 t24 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">creation</span> had emanated. The <span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span>
was only a vital spark, and his final resting-place was in it. Passionately
loving the light, the moth finally immolated itself in the flame; in like
manner the <span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span> had to throw off the illusory shackles of personality
and be merged in the Universal, the One. This doctrine is certainly not
Zoroastrian, because through the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">whole</span> history of the religion individuality
is not an illusion. It is ever a stern fact. Personality is not an imperfection, but
it is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t22 t23 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">highest</span> expression of life, that ultimately strives for the divine. Not
the losing of individuality and the loss of the personal self, and not the
weakening of personality, but the gaining and strengthening of it, is the
Zoroastrian ideal. This has been the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> taught by Zoroastrianism in the
striving [507] for the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t22 t23 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">highest</span> aims comprehensible to mankind from the
remotest antiquity. Zrvan was extolled above Ohrmazd, who was ranked by
them as a mere manifestation of Time. The one was elevated by debasing the
other. The personal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> who could be loved and feared, who responded to
the gentle aspirations of the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> heart, was dethroned to make room for a
monistic principle that might answer the stern canons of cold intellectualism,
but which evaporated into an unthinkable abstraction and mercilessly <span class="t1 t7 t12 t29 hoverable">left</span> its
hapless votaries <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> of solace or hope. Affection, <span class="t0 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t18 t20 t24 t27 t28 hoverable">love</span> and
devotion, however, can centre about some personality only. We <span class="t5 t14 t15 t24 t27 hoverable">find</span> in the
authoritative teachings of the Zoroastrian Church that Ohrmazd knows no
peer, and he always sits supreme at the <span class="t1 t4 t9 t16 hoverable">head</span> of the <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">divine</span> hierarchy. These
modern votaries of Zrvan were, however, not to be confounded with the
Zarvanite sect of old, which looked to Zrvan Akarana as a personality as
much defined as Ohrmazd. We have already seen that, in postulating
impersonated <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> as the originator of Ohrmazd and Ahriman, the sect
aimed at supplanting Zoroastrian dualism by monotheism, in <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">order</span> to save
their religion from the so-called stigma of dualism. Not so the theosophists,
who grafted this new feature on the pure teachings of Zoroaster. They did
not personify Time, but reckoned this abstract principle of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Time</span> as <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span>
than Ohrmazd himself, because, in common with all mystic schools, they
held the <span class="t0 hoverable">idea</span> of an impersonal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">God</span> as the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t22 t23 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">highest</span> category of philosophical

thought.
Zoroastrianism declared by the thesophic claim to be incomplete <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span>
the doctrine of transmigration of souls. From first to last Zoroastrianism,
like Judaism, Christianity, and Mohammedanism, shows no sign of this
theory of rebirth. But this dogma occupied a pre-eminent <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> among the
theosophists, being, in fact, one of the most conspicuous characteristics of
their doctrines. To teach <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> to attain liberation from the bondage of
rebirth was the ultimate aim of their ethics. It was not regarded by the
theosophists as one of the many solutions put forward by the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">mind</span> to
solve the mysteries of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> after death, but as the only rational explanation
that satisfied <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> instinct of justice, and the only solution of the
anomalies in this world. They persuaded themselves that the theory was fast
becoming a recognized <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">truth</span> in the West, and that, at no distant [508]date,
it <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> be hailed as an inexorable <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">law</span> of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> proved with scientific
certitude. With a <span class="t25 hoverable">view</span> to investing their statements with scriptural authority
they tore one or <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> passages from their context, and basing their arguments
on these, they declared that they had unearthed the theory from the
labyrinth of Zoroastrianism. When the Dasturs and other Parsi scholars
asserted, in accord with all Iranian scholars of the West, that in no period of
the religious history of Iran was metempsychosis ever hinted at in the
remotest form, and that the passages referred to had no bearing <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the
question, they retorted that the scholarship of the scholars must be at fault,
for so <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> a <span class="t0 t1 t8 t11 t15 t21 t23 t24 hoverable">master</span> as Zoroaster simply could not fail to have taught this
fundamental truth. But this was not all. Enthused by a zeal for the theory,
they <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">went</span> a step further and alleged that Zoroaster himself was an
Amshaspand incarnate. This is contrary to the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of Zoroastrianism. The
sacred books <span class="t6 t9 t11 t19 t20 t22 hoverable">speak</span> of the prophet as the greatest of the mortals, the most
brilliant among men, even as the star Tishtar is among the infinite stars,1 and
as the noblest <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">soul</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">whose</span> ideal is a leaven of righteousness to humanity. He
is the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t9 t10 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t22 t23 t25 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">highest</span> and the greatest ideal of <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> perfection, the very
embodiment of piety. The Gathas give a distinctly visualized image of the
personality of Zoroaster. His <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> is surrounded by a nimbus of miracles in
the later period, and most extravagant legends are woven about his
personality, but after all that the <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> language can sing in his praise, he is

simply a man, and not an arch angel incarnate. So was he during life, and so
he is after death,

1. Yt. 8. 44. These modern successors of the Parsi Yogists of the seventeenth
century have caused several members of the community to drift towards a
growing fondness for occult mystery. Many <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> and women, with or
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> <span class="t0 t1 t11 t12 t21 t25 hoverable">higher</span> education, are seen to-day running after any <span class="t0 t1 t2 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">form</span> of
occultism that they come across. These continue to interpret and explain the
sacred <span class="t9 t12 t13 t25 hoverable">texts</span> on the allegorical basis, With overweening presumption,
common to the occultists of all ages and places, they claim to be the only
correct interpreters of Zoroastrianism and are busy producing a novel type of
Zoroastrian ideological literature.
[509]
<span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t5 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">CHAPTER</span> LXI
CONCLUSION
And now we have reached the completion of our study down to the present
day. We have traced the gradual development of the religion of Zarathushtra
during the various periods of its history. Nearly <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">three</span> <span class="t6 hoverable">thousand</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">years</span> have
elapsed since the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> prophet first gave the message of Mazda to the
<span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> of Iran. Many millions of <span class="t0 t1 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">human</span> souls have lived a happy <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> and
died a peaceful <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">death</span> under the shadow of the protecting wings of the faith.
Zarathushtra's immortal triad of 'good thoughts, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> words, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span>
deeds' has kindled the religious zeal, intensified the desire, ennobled the
thoughts, illumined the minds, and warmed the hearts of the countless
numbers of his followers. Throughout its history Zoroastrianism has seen its
bright and dark days, accompanied by the rise and fall of the political <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span>

of its adherents. During these ages, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> and mighty kings, in whom was
concentrated the temporal <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> of Persia, have ruled over Iran. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Yet</span> they are
no more. But the one personality in whom was sanctified the <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> power,
the everlastingly greater than kings, has ruled over the hearts of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">men</span> in all
periods of the nation's history and will ever continue to rule so in the ages to
come. Zarathushtra, the chosen of Ahura Mazda, does not belong to any
single period and particular people, but to all ages and to all peoples. He is
unchanging. His religion it was that inspired the Iranian nation with the
loftiest of ideals when Iran was at the zenith of her power. His ever
optimistic teachings and the ever cheerful <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spirit</span> of his sublime doctrines
saved its remnants from falling into the slough of pessimism and gloom,
thirteen centuries ago, when the Zoroastrian community stood appalled by
the national catastrophe that sounded the death-knell of their empire. With
the downfall of the empire the hope of regaining <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">power</span> had disappeared
forever. They could never see visions of its restoration. History has recorded
this one and unique pathetic instance of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> nation [510]of millions being
reduced to a small community of a little over a hundred <span class="t6 hoverable">thousand</span> souls all
told, still <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> to its <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> faith. Everything that was nearest and dearest to
them in the fatherland was gone. Zarathushtra remained their only hope, and
with his religion as the only cherished heritage, the Parsi exiles sought an
asylum in Iran. Thirteen centuries have dragged their weary course since
they first landed on this the <span class="t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t29 hoverable">land</span> of their hope and began their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> anew.
Rulers of nations they have not become, but they have proved themselves to
be the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> bearers of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> name and fame of their illustrious forebears.
The pages of their national history are still thrilling with the noble deeds of
the <span class="t21 hoverable">ancient</span> Iranians, and their dutiful descendants have faithfully reflected
their past national <span class="t3 t22 t28 hoverable">glory</span> in the mirror of their small community. Zoroastrian
virtues have made the modern Parsis great. The community has secured a
pioneer <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in the social, intellectual, and industrial <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of the teeming
millions of India. They have amassed vast fortunes and have given away
equally vast sums for philanthropic purposes <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> distinction of caste,
color, or creed. An <span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span> member among the Parsis to-day is a better
cared-for unit than one in any society. The Parsis yearly contribute for his
relief at a rate which no <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">people</span> in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> does for its <span class="t22 t25 hoverable">individual</span> member.
The virtue of charity has been built into the very communal fibre, and is
woven into the tissues of every individual's being. A religion that produces

such results in the practical <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span> of a community <span class="t0 t1 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">well</span> deserves the epithet
'excellent,' which the Mazda-worshipping religion of Zarathushtra is given
in the Confession of Faith. With sublime confidence Zarathushtra foretold to
the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Evil</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Spirit</span> that his religion will ever live and his followers will do battle
with the forces of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> up to the end of the world.1 His noble <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> has
weathered the heaviest of storms and survived them; and a religion which
stood these trials in the past will stand any trial in the future. Zoroastrianism
will live by its <span class="t0 t28 hoverable">eternal</span> verities of the belief in the personality of Ohrmazd, an
abiding <span class="t7 t13 t19 t20 t29 hoverable">faith</span> in the triad of <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> thoughts, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> words, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> deeds, the
inexorable <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">law</span> of righteousness, the reward and retribution in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">life</span>
hereafter, the progress of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">world</span> towards perfection, and the ultimate
triumph of the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">good</span> over <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">evil</span> through the coming of the Kingdom of
Ohrmazd with the [511] co-operation of man. These are the truest and the
greatest realities in life. They are valid for all times. They constitute the
lasting element of Zoroastrianism. In the midst of the accretions that have
gathered round it during the <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">long</span> period of its life, these immortal truths
have remained substantially unchanged, and by them Zoroastrianism will live
for all time. Dogmas and rituals are based <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">upon</span> the needs of the times, and as
such they are subject to the natural laws of growth and decay. They have
their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">place</span> in the <span class="t0 t4 t6 t7 t8 t11 t14 t16 t17 t21 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">spiritual</span> development of man. They are the accompaniments of religion, but not religion itself. <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Man</span> may fall away from
dogmas and from rituals, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> he may remain religious. Righteousness
rests on the individual's piety, and not on a scrupulous observance of
ceremonials, or a practice of elaborate lustrations. Let the Parsi individually,
and his community collectively, abide steadfast in the path of righteousness,
and they will be practising <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">true</span> Zoroastrianism. In the fret and fever of
modern civilization, which renders <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">man</span> exceedingly sensitive to suffering,
and lets loose on him the demons of restlessness and discontent,
Zarathushtra's religion is the best sedative for him to-day. So will it be in all
social unrests, economic crises, and religious upheavals of the future.
Zarathushtra has been the hope of the Parsis in the past. So is he now, and
so will he be forever. 1. Vd. 19. 5.

frajajt pavan darût u shâtîh u râmishnîh.
“Completed in peace and joy and pleasure.”
